Global output of this black and sticky material is now on the order of 100 megatons, with 85 percent of it going to paving (hot and warm asphalt mixes) and most of the rest to roofing.[39] And hydrocarbons have yet another indispensable non-fuel use: as feedstocks for many different chemical syntheses (dominated by ethane, propane, and butane from natural gas liquids) producing a variety of synthetic fibers, resins, adhesives, dyes, paints and coatings, detergents, and pesticides, all vital in myriad ways to our modern world.[40] Given these advantages and benefits, it was predictable—indeed unavoidable—that our dependence on crude oil would grow once the product became more affordable and once it could be reliably delivered on a global scale.

从煤炭到原油的转变历经数代人的时间才得以完成。商业原油开采始于19世纪50年代的俄罗斯、加拿大和美国。当时的油井采用古老的冲击式钻井法，即通过上下移动重型钻头进行钻探，井深较浅，日产量低，原油提炼的主要产品是煤油（取代了鲸油和蜡烛），用于照明。[41]只有在内燃机得到广泛应用后，精炼石油产品的新市场才得以出现：首先是用于汽车、公共汽车和卡车的汽油发动机（奥托循环）；然后是鲁道夫·狄塞尔发明的更高效的发动机，使用更重、更便宜的馏分油（没错，就是柴油），主要用于船舶、卡车和重型机械（更多相关内容，请参见第四章“全球化”）。这些新型动力装置的普及速度缓慢，在第二次世界大战之前，美国和加拿大是仅有的两个汽车拥有率较高的国家。

The shift from coal to crude oil took generations to accomplish. Commercial crude oil extraction began during the 1850s in Russia, Canada, and the US. The wells, drilled using the ancient percussion method involving the raising and dropping of a heavy cutting bit, were shallow, their daily productivities were low, and kerosene for lamps (which displaced whale oil and candles) was the main product of the simple refining of crude oil.[41] New markets for refined oil products were created only with the widespread adoption of internal combustion engines: first the gasoline-fueled (Otto cycle) machines for cars, buses, and trucks; then Rudolf Diesel’s more efficient machines, fueled by a heavier and cheaper fraction (you guessed it, diesel) and used above all for ships, trucks, and heavy machinery (for much more on this, see chapter 4 on globalization). Diffusion of these new prime movers was slow, and the US and Canada were the only two countries with high rates of car ownership prior to the Second World War.

原油成为全球燃料，并最终成为世界上最重要的初级能源，这要归功于中东和苏联巨型油田的发现——当然，也得益于大型油轮的引入。一些中东巨型油田最早于20世纪20年代和30年代开采（例如1927年的伊朗加奇萨兰油田和伊拉克基尔库克油田，以及1937年的科威特布尔干油田），但大多数油田是在战后发现的，包括1948年发现的沙特阿拉伯的加瓦尔油田（当时世界上最大的油田）、1951年的萨法尼亚油田和1957年的马尼法油田。苏联最大的油田发现分别在1948年（伏尔加-乌拉尔盆地的罗曼什金油田）和1965年（西伯利亚的萨莫特洛尔油田）。[42]

Crude oil became a global fuel, and eventually the world’s most important source of primary energy, thanks to the discoveries of giant oil fields in the Middle East and in the USSR—and, of course, also thanks to the introduction of large tankers. Some Middle Eastern giants were first drilled in the 1920s and 1930s (Iranian Gachsaran and Iraqi Kirkuk in 1927, Kuwaiti Burgan in 1937) but most of them were discovered after the war, including Ghawar (the world’s largest) in 1948, Safaniya in 1951, and Manifa in 1957, all in Saudi Arabia. The largest Soviet discoveries were in 1948 (Romashkino in the Volga-Ural Basin) and in 1965 (Samotlor in Western Siberia).[42]

原油价格的上涨与相对回落

Crude oil’s rise and relative retreat

欧洲和日本的大规模汽车普及以及两国经济从煤炭转向原油，后来又转向天然气，都始于20世纪50年代。与此同时，对外贸易和旅行（包括第一批喷气式客机）的扩张，以及用于合成氨和塑料的石化原料的使用也开始兴起。20世纪50年代，全球原油开采量翻了一番，到1964年，原油超过煤炭，成为世界上最重要的化石燃料。尽管原油产量持续增长，但供应仍然充足，因此价格开始下降。按不变价格（经通货膨胀调整后）计算，1950年的世界石油价格低于1940年，1960年低于1950年，1970年则低于1960年。[43]

Mass-scale car usage in Europe and Japan and the concurrent conversion of their economies from coal to crude oil, and later to natural gas, began only during the 1950s, as did the expansion of foreign trade and travel (including the first jetliners) and the use of petrochemical feedstocks for the synthesis of ammonia and plastics. Global oil extraction of crude oil doubled during the 1950s, and by 1964 crude oil surpassed coal as the world’s most important fossil fuel, but although its output kept on rising, supply remained plentiful and so prices were falling. In constant (inflation-adjusted) monies, the world oil price was lower in 1950 than it was in 1940, lower in 1960 than in 1950—and lower still in 1970 than in 1960.[43]

不出所料，各行各业都对石油有需求。实际上，原油价格低廉，因此缺乏高效利用石油的动力：美国寒冷地区的房屋越来越多地使用燃油炉取暖，这些房屋建造时只安装了单层玻璃窗，墙体隔热性能也不足；1933年至1973年间，美国汽车的平均能效实际上有所下降；能源密集型产业仍然沿用低效的生产工艺。[44]尤其值得注意的是，美国用更先进的氧气转炉取代老旧的平炉炼钢的速度远慢于日本和西欧。

Not surprisingly, demand was coming from all sectors. In real terms, crude oil was so cheap that there were no incentives to use it efficiently: American houses in regions with a cold climate, increasingly heated by oil furnaces, were built with single-glazed windows and without adequate wall insulation; the average efficiency of American cars actually declined between 1933 and 1973; and energy-intensive industries continued to operate by using inefficient processes.[44] Perhaps most notably, America’s pace of replacing old open-hearth furnaces with superior oxygen furnaces to make steel was much slower than in Japan and Western Europe.

20世纪60年代末，美国本已高企的石油需求又增长了近25%，全球需求更是增长了近50%。1965年至1973年间，欧洲石油需求几乎翻了一番，日本的进口量也增长了约2.3倍。[45]如前所述，新发现的石油足以满足这一激增的需求，石油售价与1950年基本持平。然而，好景不长。1950年，美国石油产量仍占世界总产量的约53%；到1970年，尽管美国仍是最大的石油生产国，但其份额已降至不足23%——显然，美国需要增加石油进口——而石油输出国组织（欧佩克）的产量则占到了48%。

During the late 1960s, the already high American demand for oil rose by nearly 25 percent, and global demand increased by nearly 50 percent. European demand had nearly doubled between 1965 and 1973, and Japanese imports became about 2.3 times higher.[45] As mentioned, new discoveries of oil covered this surge in demand and oil was selling at what was essentially the same price as in 1950. This was too good to last, however. In 1950 the US still produced about 53 percent of the world’s oil; by 1970, although still the largest producer, its share fell to less than 23 percent—and it was clear that the country would need increased imports—while the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) produced 48 percent.

欧佩克于1960年在巴格达由五个国家成立，旨在阻止油价进一步下跌。欧佩克当时占据了时间优势：在20世纪60年代，其规模不足以使其占据主导地位；但到了1970年，其产量份额不断增长，加上美国石油开采的萎缩（1970年达到顶峰），使得欧佩克的要求不容忽视。[46] 1972年4月，德克萨斯州铁路委员会取消了对该州石油产量的限制，从而放弃了自20世纪30年代以来一直掌控的油价。1971年，阿尔及利亚和利比亚开始将石油生产国有化，伊拉克于1972年效仿。同年，科威特、卡塔尔和沙特阿拉伯也开始逐步收回其油田——此前这些油田一直由外国公司控制。随后在1973年4月，美国取消了对落基山脉以东原油进口的限制。突然间，石油市场变成了卖方市场。1973 年 10 月 1 日，欧佩克将公布的油价提高了 16%，达到每桶 3.01 美元。随后，六个阿拉伯海湾国家又将油价提高了 17%。1973 年 10 月，以色列在西奈半岛战胜埃及后，欧佩克对所有对美石油出口实施了禁运。

OPEC, set up in 1960 in Baghdad by just five countries in order to prevent further price reductions, had time on its side: it wasn’t large enough to assert itself during the 1960s, but by 1970 its production share, combined with the retreat of American extraction (which peaked in 1970), made it impossible to ignore its demands.[46] In April 1972 the Texas Railroad Commission lifted its limits on the state’s output and hence surrendered its control of the price that it had held since the 1930s. In 1971, Algeria and Libya began to nationalize their oil production, and Iraq followed in 1972, the same year that Kuwait, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia began their gradual takeover of their oilfields—which until that point had been in the hands of foreign corporations. Then in April 1973, the US ended its limits on the import of crude oil east of the Rocky Mountains. Suddenly, it was a sellers’ market, and on October 1 1973 OPEC raised its posted price by 16 percent to $3.01/barrel, followed by an additional 17 percent rise by six Arab Gulf states and, after the Israeli victory over Egypt in Sinai in October 1973, it embargoed all oil exports to the US.

1974年1月1日，海湾国家将石油标价提高至每桶11.65美元，一年之内，这种重要能源的价格上涨了4.5倍——这也终结了由廉价石油推动的快速经济扩张时代。从1950年到1973年，西欧的经济产出几乎增长了两倍，而美国国内生产总值在短短一代人的时间内也增长了一倍多。 1973 年至 1975 年间，全球经济增长率下降了约 90%。受油价上涨影响的经济体开始适应这些新的现实——尤其是在工业能源效率方面取得了显著进步——但伊朗君主制的垮台以及伊朗被原教旨主义神权政权接管，导致油价第二次上涨，从 1978 年的约 13 美元涨至 1981 年的 34 美元，并在 1979 年至 1982 年间导致全球经济增长率再次下降了 90%。[47]

On January 1 1974, the Gulf states raised their posted price to $11.65/barrel, completing a 4.5-fold rise in the cost of this essential energy source in a single year—and this ended the era of rapid economic expansion that had been energized by cheap oil. From 1950 to 1973 the Western European economic product had nearly tripled, and the US GDP had more than doubled in that single generation. Between 1973 and 1975 the global economic growth rate dropped by about 90 percent, and as soon as the economies affected by higher oil prices began to adjust to these new realities—above all by impressive improvements in industrial energy efficiency—the fall of the Iranian monarchy and the takeover of Iran by a fundamentalist theocracy led to a second wave of oil price rises, from about $13 in 1978 to $34 in 1981, and to another 90 percent decline in the global rate of economic growth between 1979 and 1982.[47]

每桶30美元以上的油价足以摧毁需求，到1986年，石油价格再次跌至每桶13美元，为新一轮全球化奠定了基础——这一次的全球化以中国为中心。快速现代化是由邓小平的经济改革和大量外资推动的。两代人之后，只有那些经历过那段价格和供应动荡岁月的人（或者那些研究过其影响的人，尽管人数越来越少）才能体会到这两波价格上涨带来的创伤。由此产生的经济逆转的后果在四十年后的今天仍然影响着我们，因为一旦石油需求开始增长，许多节油措施就被保留了下来，而一些措施——特别是向更高效的工业用途转型——则不断加强。[48]

More than $30 a barrel was a demand-destroying price and by 1986 oil was again selling at just $13 a barrel, setting the stage for yet another round of globalization—this time centered on China, whose rapid modernization was driven by Deng Xiaoping’s economic reforms and by massive foreign investment. Two generations later, only those who lived through those years of price and supply turmoil (or those, increasingly few, who studied their impact) appreciate how traumatic these two waves of price rises were. Consequences of the resulting economic reversals are still felt four decades later, because once demand for oil began to increase, many oil-saving measures remained in place and some—notably the transitions to more efficient industrial uses—kept on intensifying.[48]

1995年，原油开采量终于超过了1979年的纪录，并持续增长，以满足经济改革中的中国以及亚洲其他地区不断增长的需求——但石油尚未恢复到1975年之前的相对主导地位。[49]其在全球商业一次能源供应中的份额从1970年的45%下降到2000年的38%，再到2019年的33%——而且可以肯定的是，随着天然气消费量以及风能和太阳能发电量的持续增长，石油的相对份额还将继续下降。利用光伏电池和风力涡轮机发电蕴藏着巨大的潜力，但从这些间歇性能源中获取20%至40%电力的系统（德国和西班牙是大型经济体中的最佳例证）与完全依赖这些可再生能源的国家电力供应之间存在着根本差异。

In 1995, crude oil extraction finally surpassed the 1979 record and then continued to rise, meeting the demand of an economically reforming China as well as the rising demand elsewhere in Asia—but oil has not regained its pre-1975 relative dominance.[49] Its share of the global commercial primary energy supply fell from 45 percent in 1970 to 38 percent in the year 2000 and to 33 percent in 2019—and it is now certain that its further relative decline will continue as natural gas consumption and wind and solar electricity generation keep increasing. There are enormous opportunities to generate more electricity with photovoltaic cells and wind turbines, but there is a fundamental difference between systems that derive 20–40 percent of electricity from these intermittent sources (Germany and Spain are the best examples among large economies) and a national electricity supply that relies completely on these renewable flows.

在人口众多的大国，完全依赖这些可再生能源需要我们目前仍然缺乏的东西：要么是能够长期（数天至数周）储存电力以应对间歇性发电的大规模储能系统，要么是能够跨越时区，将电力从阳光充足、风力强劲的地区输送到主要城市和工业中心的庞大高压输电线路网络。这些新型可再生能源能否产生足够的电力，不仅取代目前煤炭和天然气发电，还能通过交通运输的全面电气化，取代目前车辆、船舶和飞机使用的所有液态燃料？而且，它们真的能像某些计划所承诺的那样，在短短二三十年内实现这一切吗？

In large, populous nations, the complete reliance on these renewables would require what we are still missing: either mass-scale, long-term (days to weeks) electricity storage that would back up intermittent electricity generation, or extensive grids of high-voltage lines to transmit electricity across time zones and from sunny and windy regions to major urban and industrial concentrations. Could these new renewables produce enough electricity to replace not only today’s generation fueled by coal and natural gas, but also all the energy now supplied by liquid fuels to vehicles, ships, and planes by way of a complete electrification of transport? And could they really do so, as some plans now promise, in a matter of just two or three decades?

电力的诸多优点

The many advantages of electricity

如果按照费曼的说法，能量是“那种抽象的东西”，那么电就是能量最抽象的形式之一。你不需要具备科学知识就能直接体验到几种不同类型的能量，区分它们的形式并利用它们的转换。固体或液体燃料（化学能）是看得见摸得着的（树干、煤块、汽油罐），它们的燃烧——无论是森林大火、旧石器时代的洞穴、火车产生蒸汽，还是汽车——都会释放热量（热能）。落水和流水是重力和动能无处不在的体现，通过建造简单的木制水车，可以很容易地将其转化为有用的动能（机械能）。而要将风的动能转化为机械能，用于磨谷物或榨油，只需要一个风车和木制齿轮，将动能传递给磨盘即可。

If energy, according to Feynman, is “that abstract thing,” then electricity is one of its most abstract forms. You don’t need a scientific understanding to have direct experience of several different types of energy, to distinguish their forms and take advantage of their conversions. Solid or liquid fuels (chemical energy) are tangible (a tree trunk, a lump of coal, a canister of gasoline), and their burning—be it in forest fires, in Paleolithic caves, in locomotives to produce steam, or in motor vehicles—releases heat (thermal energy). Falling and running waters are ubiquitous displays of gravitational and kinetic energy that are fairly easily converted to useful kinetic (mechanical) energy by building simple wooden waterwheels—and all it takes to convert wind’s kinetic energy into mechanical energy for grinding grain or pressing oil seeds is a windmill and wooden gears to transfer the motion to millstones.

相比之下，电是无形的，我们无法像感知燃料那样直观地感知它。但它的影响可以从静电、火花和闪电中看出；微弱的电流可以被感觉到，而超过100毫安的电流则可能致命。电的常用定义并非凭直觉就能理解，它们需要预先了解其他一些功能性术语，例如“电子”、“流动”、“电荷”和“电流”。尽管费曼在他那部鸿篇巨著《物理学讲义》的第一卷中只是草草带过——“存在电能，它与电荷的推拉作用有关”——但当他在第二卷中详细讨论机械能、电能和稳电流时，他运用了微积分。[50]

In contrast, electricity is intangible and we can’t get an intuitive sense of it in the same way as we do with fuels. But its effects can be seen in static electricity, sparks, lightning; small currents can be felt, and currents above 100 milliamperes may be deadly. Common definitions of electricity are not instinctively accessible, they require a prior knowledge of other functional terms such as “electrons,” “flow,” “charge,” and “current.” Although Feynman, in the opening volume of his magisterial Lectures on Physics, was quite perfunctory—“there is electrical energy, which has to do with pushing and pulling by electric charges”—when he returned to the topic in detail in the second volume, dealing with mechanical and electrical energies and with steady currents, he did so by deploying calculus.[50]

对于大多数现代人来说，现代世界充满了黑匣子，这些设备的内部运作在不同程度上对用户而言仍然是个谜。电力可以被视为一个无处不在且终极的黑匣子系统：尽管许多人对电力系统的运作原理相当了解（例如大型火力发电厂中化石燃料的燃烧；水电站中水的流动；光伏电池吸收太阳辐射；反应堆中铀的裂解）每个人都从中受益（光、热、运动），但只有少数人完全了解发电厂、变压器、输电线路和最终使用设备内部发生的事情。

For most of its inhabitants, the modern world is full of black boxes, devices whose internal workings remain—to different degrees—a mystery to their users. Electricity can be thought of as a ubiquitous and ultimate black box system: although many people have a fairly good understanding of what goes in (combustion of fossil fuel in a large thermal plant; falling water in a hydro station; solar radiation absorbed by a photovoltaic cell; the splitting of uranium in a reactor) and everybody benefits from what comes out (light, heat, motion), only a minority fully understand what goes on inside the generating plants, transformers, transmission lines, and final-use devices.

闪电是电力最常见的自然表现形式，但它威力太大、持续时间太短（仅几分之一秒），而且破坏性太强，因此（或许永远）无法将其用于生产用途。虽然任何人都可以通过摩擦合适的材料产生微量的静电，或者使用无需充电即可持续数小时为手电筒和便携式电子设备提供轻型照明的小型电池，但大规模商业用电却是一项成本高昂且复杂的工程。将电力从发电地输送到用电最集中的地区——城市、工业和电气化快速交通工具——同样复杂：这需要变压器和庞大的高压输电线路网络，并在进一步转换后，通过低压架空或地下电线输送给数十亿用户。

Lightning, electricity’s most common natural demonstration, is too powerful, too short-lived (only a fraction of a second), and too destructive to be (ever?) tapped for productive use. And while anybody can produce minute quantities of static electricity by rubbing suitable materials or use small batteries that can last, without recharging, for hours of light-duty service in flashlights and portable electronics, generating electricity for mass-scale commercial use is a costly and complicated undertaking. Its distribution from where it is generated to the places and regions of its largest use—to cities, industries, and electrified forms of rapid transportation—is equally complicated: it requires transformers and extensive grids of high-voltage transmission lines and, after further transformation, distribution by low-voltage overhead or underground wires to billions of consumers.

即使在如今高科技电子奇迹层出不穷的时代，我们仍然无法以经济实惠的方式储存足够数量的电力，以满足一座中等规模城市（50万人口）一两周的用电需求，或者为一座特大城市（超过1000万人口）提供半天的用电。[51]尽管存在这些复杂性、高昂的成本和技术挑战，我们仍然致力于推动现代经济的电气化，而且这种对更高电气化水平的追求还将继续，因为这种能源形式兼具诸多无可比拟的优势。最显而易见的是，在最终消费环节，电力的使用始终便捷、清洁，而且大多数情况下效率极高。只需拨动开关、按下按钮或调节恒温器（现在通常只需要一个手势或语音指令），即可打开电灯、电机或电暖器、电冷器——无需笨重的燃料储存，无需费力地搬运和添柴，没有不完全燃烧（排放有毒的一氧化碳）的危险，也无需清洁灯具、炉灶或熔炉。

And even in this era of high-tech electronic miracles, it is still impossible to store electricity affordably in quantities sufficient to meet the demand of a medium-sized city (500,000 people) for only a week or two, or to supply a megacity (more than 10 million people) for just half a day.[51] But despite these complications, high costs, and technical challenges, we have been striving to electrify modern economies, and this quest for ever-higher electrification will continue because this form of energy combines many unequaled advantages. Most obviously, at the point of its final consumption, electricity’s use is always effortless and clean, and the majority of the time it is also exceptionally efficient. With just the flip of a switch, push of a button, or adjustment of a thermostat (now often requiring only a hand signal or voice command), electric lights and motors or electric heaters and coolers are turned on—with no bulky fuel storages, no laborious carrying and stoking, no dangers of incomplete combustion (emitting poisonous carbon monoxide), and no cleaning of lamps or stoves or furnaces.

电力是照明的最佳能源形式：无论在私人照明还是公共照明领域，它都无可匹敌。很少有创新能像电力一样，突破日光的限制，照亮黑夜，对现代文明产生如此深远的影响。[52]从古代的蜡烛和油灯到早期的工业煤气灯和煤油罐，所有之前的替代照明方式都十分微弱、昂贵且效率低下。比较不同光源最直观的指标是其发光效率——即光源产生视觉信号的能力，通常用总光通量（光源输出的总能量，单位为流明）与光源功率（单位为瓦特）的比值来衡量。如果将蜡烛的发光效率设定为1，那么早期工业城市的煤气灯的发光效率是蜡烛的5到10倍；第一次世界大战前，钨丝电灯泡的发光效率是蜡烛的60倍；而如今最好的荧光灯的发光效率约为蜡烛的500倍。钠灯​​（用于户外照明）的效率比金属灯高出 1000 倍。[53]

Electricity is the best form of energy for lighting: it has no competitor on any scale of private or public illumination, and very few innovations have produced such an impact on modern civilization as has the ability to remove the limits of daylight and to illuminate the night.[52] All previous alternatives, from ancient wax candles and oil lamps to early industrial gas lights and kerosene cylinders, were feeble, costly, and highly inefficient. The most telling comparison of light sources is in terms of their luminous efficacy—their ability to produce a visual signal, measured as the quotient of the total luminous flux (the total amount of energy put out by a source, in lumens) and the source’s power (in watts). When setting the luminous efficacy of candles as equal to 1, coal gas lights in the early industrial cities produced 5–10 times more; before the First World War electric light bulbs with tungsten filaments emitted up to 60 times more; today’s best fluorescent lights produce about 500 times as much; and sodium lamps (used for outdoor lighting) are up to 1,000 times more efficacious.[53]

很难说哪种电力转换器——照明和电动机——的影响更大。电动机将电能转化为动能，首先彻底改变了几乎所有工业生产领域，随后又渗透到家庭生活的方方面面。那些对体力要求不高的体力劳动，以及那些原本依靠蒸汽机进行起重、压制、切割、编织和其他工业操作的领域，几乎完全实现了电气化。在美国，这一切在第一批交流电动机问世后的短短四十年内就发生了。[54]到1930年，电力驱动使美国制造业的生产率几乎翻了一番，到20世纪60年代末，又一次实现了这一增长。[55]与此同时，电动机开始逐步征服铁路运输，先是应用于有轨电车，然后是客运列车。

It is impossible to decide which class of electricity converters has had a greater impact—lights or motors. The conversion of electricity into kinetic energy by electric motors first revolutionized nearly every sector of industrial production and later penetrated every household niche. Less demanding manual tasks and those that deployed steam engines to lift, press, cut, weave, and other industrial operations were almost completely electrified. In the US this took place within just four decades after the introduction of the first AC electric motors.[54] By 1930, electric drive had nearly doubled American manufacturing productivity, and had done so again by the late 1960s.[55] Concurrently, electric motors began their gradual conquest of rail transportation, beginning with electric streetcars and then with passenger trains.

服务业如今主导着所有现代经济体，其运作完全依赖于电力。电动机驱动电梯和自动扶梯、为建筑物提供空调、开启门窗，并压缩垃圾。它们对于电子商务也至关重要，因为它们驱动着巨型仓库中错综复杂的传送带。然而，依赖它们的人们却从未见过这些最普遍的装置。每天都有。它们是激活手机振动器的微型单元：最小的单元尺寸小于 4 毫米 × 3 毫米，宽度不到成年人小指甲盖宽度的一半。你只能通过拆解手机或在网上观看相关视频才能看到它们。[56]

The service sector now dominates all modern economies, and its operation is completely dependent on electricity. Electric motors power elevators and escalators, air-condition buildings, open doors, and compact garbage. They are also indispensable for e-commerce, as they power mazes of conveyor belts in giant warehouses. But the most ubiquitous units are never seen by people who rely on them every day. They are the tiny units activating mobile phone vibrators: the smallest ones measure less than 4 mm × 3 mm, their width being less than half the width of an average adult’s pinky nail. You can see one only by dismantling your phone, or watching a video of that operation online.[56]

在一些国家，几乎所有铁路运输都已实现电气化，所有高速列车（最高时速可达300公里）都由电力机车或多点安装的电动机驱动，例如日本于1964年开通的开创性新干线。[57]即使是基本款汽车，现在也配备了20到40个小型电动机，而高档汽车的电动机数量更多——这增加了车辆的重量，也增加了电池的消耗。[58]在家庭中，除了照明和为所有电子设备（现在通常包括安防系统）供电外，电力还主导着机械作业，并为厨房提供供暖和制冷，以及为热水和许多房屋提供能源。[59]

In some countries, virtually all rail transport is now electrified, and all high-speed trains (up to 300 km/h) are powered either by electric locomotives or by motors mounted in multiple locations, as is the case with Japan’s pioneering Shinkansen launched in 1964.[57] And even basic car models now have between 20 and 40 small electric motors, with many more in expensive cars—adding to the vehicle’s weight and increasing the drain on its batteries.[58] In households, besides lighting and powering all electronic devices—now commonly including security systems—electricity dominates mechanical tasks and supplies both heat and refrigeration in kitchens and energy for water heating, as well as heating for many houses.[59]

如果没有电力，所有城市的饮用水以及各地液态和气态化石燃料都将无法获得。强大的电动水泵将水输送到市政供水系统，在商业和住宅密度高的城市，由于需要将水提升到很高的高度，电动水泵的任务尤为艰巨。[60]电动机驱动所有燃油泵，将汽油、煤油和柴油输送到油箱和机翼。虽然天然气管道中可能储存着大量的天然气——通常使用燃气轮机来输送燃料——但在北美，由于强制通风供暖占主导地位，小型电动机驱动风扇，将天然气加热的空气吹过管道。[61]

Without electricity, drinking water in all cities—as well as liquid and gaseous fossil fuels everywhere—would be unavailable. Powerful electric pumps feed water into the municipal supply, and they have an especially demanding task in cities with high commercial and residential densities where water must be lifted to a great height.[60] Electric motors run all the fuel pumps needed to move gasoline, kerosene, and diesel into tanks and wings. And while there may be plenty of natural gas in distribution gas pipelines—gas turbines are often used to move the fuel—in North America, where forced-air heating dominates, small electric motors operate fans that push the air heated by natural gas through the ducts.[61]

社会电气化（即燃料转化为电力而非直接消耗的比例不断上升）的长期趋势已毋庸置疑。新兴可再生能源——太阳能和风能（与始于1882年的水力发电相对）——将迅速推动这一进程，但电力生产的历史提醒我们，这一过程伴随着诸多复杂因素；而且，尽管电力的重要性日益凸显，但其在全球最终能源消费中所占比例仍然相对较小，仅为18%。

The long-term trend toward the electrification of societies (rising share of fuels converted to electricity rather than consumed directly) has been unmistakable. The new renewables—solar and wind, as opposed to hydroelectricity whose beginnings go back to 1882—will readily feed into this progression, but the history of electricity generation reminds us that many complications and complexities accompany the process; and that, despite its profound and rising importance, electricity still supplies only a relatively small share of final global energy consumption, just 18 percent.

在你拨动开关之前

Before you flip a switch

我们需要追溯电力行业的起源，才能了解其基础、基础设施以及这140年发展历程的遗产。商业发电始于1882年，并创造了三个第一。其中两个是由托马斯·爱迪生设计的先驱性燃煤发电站（伦敦霍尔本高架桥发电站于1882年1月投入运营；纽约珍珠街发电站于1882年9月投入运营），第三个是第一座水力发电站（位于威斯康星州阿普尔顿的福克斯河上，也于1882年9月开始发电）。[62] 19世纪90年代，随着交流电(AC)输电取代了现有的直流电网络，以及工业和家庭开始采用新型交流电动机，发电量开始迅速增长。1900年，全球化石燃料产量中只有不到2%用于发电；到1950年，这一比例仍然不到10%；如今已达到约25%。[63]

We need to go back to the industry’s beginnings to appreciate its foundations, its infrastructure, and the legacy of these 140 years of development. Commercial electricity generation began in 1882, with three firsts. Two of them were the pioneering coal-fired generating stations designed by Thomas Edison (Holborn Viaduct in London began operating in January 1882; Pearl Street station in New York in September 1882), and the third was the first hydroelectric station (on the Fox River in Appleton, Wisconsin, also generating since September 1882).[62] Generation began to expand quickly during the 1890s, when alternating current (AC) transmission prevailed over the existing direct current networks, and when new designs of AC electric motors began to be adopted by industry and households. In 1900, less than 2 percent of the world’s fossil fuel production was used to generate electricity; by 1950 that share was still less than 10 percent; it now stands at about 25 percent.[63]

20世纪30年代，随着美国和苏联大规模国家资助水电项目的兴建，水力发电装机容量迅速扩张，并在二战后达到新高，最终在巴西（伊泰普水电站，2007年竣工，装机容量14吉瓦）和中国（三峡水电站，2012年竣工，装机容量22.5吉瓦）建成了规模空前的巨型水电站。[64]与此同时，核裂变发电于1956年在英国卡尔德霍尔核电站开始商业化发电，并在20世纪80年代经历了最快速的发展，于2006年达到顶峰，此后略有下降，目前约占全球发电量的10%。[65] 2020年，水力发电占全球发电量的近16%；风能和太阳能发电占近7%；其余约三分之二来自主要以煤炭和天然气为燃料的大型中央电站。

The concurrent expansion of hydroelectric capacity accelerated during the 1930s, with large state-funded projects in the USA and the USSR, and reached new highs after the Second World War, culminating in the construction of record-size projects in Brazil (Itaipu, completed in 2007, 14 gigawatts) and China (Three Gorges, completed in 2012, 22.5 gigawatts).[64] Meanwhile, nuclear fission began to generate commercial electricity in 1956 at Britain’s Calder Hall, saw its greatest expansion during the 1980s, peaked in 2006, and has since declined slightly to about 10 percent of global electricity generation.[65] Hydro generation accounted for nearly 16 percent in 2020; wind and solar added almost 7 percent; and the rest (about two-thirds) came from large central stations fueled mostly by coal and natural gas.

不出所料，电力需求增长速度远超其他所有商业能源的需求：在1970年至2020年的50年间，全球发电量增长了五倍，而一次能源总需求仅增长了三倍。[66]基荷发电量（即最低限度的电力需求）的增长也推动了电力需求的增长。随着越来越多的人口涌入城市，每日、每月或每年的电力需求进一步增加。几十年前，美国电力需求在夏夜最低，商店和工厂关门，公共交通停运，除了少数人外，所有人都开着窗户睡觉。如今，在炎热潮湿的天气里，人们关上窗户，空调整夜运转，以便入睡；在大城市和特大城市，许多工厂实行两班制，许多商店和机场24小时营业。只有新冠疫情才使纽约地铁停止了24小时运营，而东京地铁每天只休息5个小时（从东京站到新宿的首班车是早上5:16，末班车是凌晨0:20）。[67]相隔数年的卫星夜间图像显示，街道、停车场和建筑物的灯光越来越亮，照亮的区域越来越大，这些区域往往与附近的城市相连，形成巨大的灯火通明的城市群。[68]

Not surprisingly, demand for electricity has been growing much faster than the demand for all other commercial energy: in the 50 years between 1970 and 2020, global electricity generation quintupled while the total primary energy demand only tripled.[66] And the growth of baseload generation—the minimum amount of electricity that has to be supplied on a daily, monthly, or annual basis—was further increased as progressively larger shares of populations moved to cities. Decades ago, American demand was lowest during summer nights, with shops and factories closed, public transport shut down, and all but a small share of the population asleep, with open windows. Now the windows are shut as air conditioners hum through the night to make sleep possible during hot, muggy weather; in large cities and megacities, many factories run two shifts and many shops and airports remain open 24 hours a day. Only COVID-19 stopped New York’s subway operating 24/7, and the Tokyo subway sleeps for just five hours (the first train from Tokyo Station to Shinjuku leaves at 5:16 a.m., the last one at 0:20 a.m.).[67] Satellite nighttime images taken years apart show how street, parking, and building lights shine ever brighter over ever-larger areas that often join with nearby cities to form huge illuminated conurbations.[68]

电力供应的极高可靠性至关重要——电网管理人员谈到，他们希望达到六个九：可靠性达到99.9999%意味着一年中只有32秒的供电中断！——在电力驱动一切的社会中，从医院、跑道或紧急疏散指示灯到心肺机和无数工业流程，无所不包。[69]如果说新冠疫情带来了混乱、痛苦和不可避免的死亡，那么与人口稠密地区几天严重断电相比，这些影响都微不足道；而如果断电持续数周，全国范围内都将是一场灾难性的事件，后果前所未有。[70]

A very high reliability of electricity supply—grid managers talk about the desirability of reaching six nines: with 99.9999 percent reliability there are only 32 seconds of interrupted supply in a year!—is imperative in societies where electricity powers everything from lights (be they in hospitals, along runways, or to indicate emergency escapes) to heart-lung machines and myriad industrial processes.[69] If the COVID-19 pandemic brought disruption, anguish, and unavoidable deaths, those effects would be minor compared to having just a few days of a severely reduced electricity supply in any densely populated region, and if prolonged for weeks nationwide it would be a catastrophic event with unprecedented consequences.[70]

脱碳：速度与规模

Decarbonization: pace and scale

地球地壳中的化石燃料资源并不匮乏，煤炭和碳氢化合物也不存在即将枯竭的危险：按照2020年的产量水平，煤炭储量大约可以维持120年，石油和天然气储量大约可以维持50年，而且持续的勘探会将更多的资源从“资源”类别转化为“储量”（技术和经济上可行的）类别。对化石燃料的依赖已经现代世界是由化石燃料创造的，但人们对全球变暖速度相对较快的担忧，促使人们广泛呼吁尽快淘汰化石燃料。理想情况下，全球能源供应的脱碳进程应足够迅速，以将全球平均升温幅度限制在1.5摄氏度以内（最坏情况下不超过2摄氏度）。根据大多数气候模型，这意味着到2050年全球二氧化碳净排放量将降至零，并在本世纪剩余时间内保持负排放。

There is no shortage of fossil fuel resources in the Earth’s crust, no danger of imminently running out of coal and hydrocarbons: at the 2020 level of production, coal reserves would last for about 120 years, oil and gas reserves for about 50 years, and continued exploration would transfer more of them from the resource to the reserve (technically and economically viable) category. Reliance on fossil fuels has created the modern world, but concerns about the relatively rapid rate of global warming have led to widespread calls for doing away with fossil carbon as expeditiously as possible. Ideally, the decarbonization of the global energy supply should proceed fast enough to limit average global warming to no more than 1.5°C (at worst 2°C). That, according to most climate models, would mean reducing net global CO2 emissions to zero by 2050 and keeping them negative for the remainder of the century.

注意关键的限定形容词：目标并非完全脱碳，而是“净零排放”或碳中和。这一定义允许通过（目前尚不存在的！）大规模从大气中移除二氧化碳并将其永久储存在地下，或通过大规模植树造林等临时措施来抵消持续排放。 [ 71]到2020年，设定以5或0结尾的年份的净零排放目标已成为一种跟风之举：超过100个国家加入了这一行列，从2030年的挪威和2035年的芬兰，到2050年的整个欧盟以及加拿大、日本和南非，再到2060年的中国（世界上最大的化石燃料消费国）。[72]鉴于2019年化石燃料燃烧产生的二氧化碳年排放量超过370亿吨，到2050年实现净零排放目标将需要一场速度和规模都前所未有的能源转型。仔细审视其关键组成部分，就能发现挑战的严峻性。

Notice the key qualifying adjective: the target is not total decarbonization but “net zero” or carbon neutrality. This definition allows for continued emissions to be compensated by (as yet non-existent!) large-scale removal of CO2 from the atmosphere and its permanent storage underground, or by such temporary measures as the mass-scale planting of trees.[71] By 2020, setting net-zero goals for years ending in five or zero has become a me-too game: more than 100 nations have joined the lineup, ranging from Norway in 2030 and Finland in 2035 to the entire European Union, as well as Canada, Japan, and South Africa, in 2050, and China (the world’s largest consumer of fossil fuels) in 2060.[72] Given the fact that annual CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion surpassed 37 billion tons in 2019, the net-zero goal by 2050 will call for an energy transition unprecedented in both pace and scale. A closer look at its key components reveals the magnitude of the challenges.

电力生产脱碳进程可能最为迅速，因为太阳能或风能单位装机成本如今已能与最便宜的化石燃料发电方式相媲美，而且一些国家已经实现了相当大的发电转型。在大型经济体中，德国是最显著的例子：自2000年以来，德国的风能和太阳能装机容量增长了10倍，可再生能源（风能、太阳能和水力发电）占总发电量的比重从11%提高到40%。只要这些新增可再生能源在总需求中所占比例相对较小，或者任何缺口都能通过进口弥补，风能和太阳能发电的间歇性就不会构成问题。

Decarbonization of electricity generation can make the fastest progress, because installation costs per unit of solar or wind capacity can now compete with the least expensive fossil-fueled choices, and some countries have already transformed their generation to a considerable degree. Among large economies, Germany is the most notable example: since the year 2000, it has boosted its wind and solar capacity 10-fold and raised the share of renewables (wind, solar, and hydro) from 11 percent to 40 percent of total generation. Intermittency of wind and solar electricity poses no problems as long as these new renewables supply relatively small shares of the total demand, or as long as any shortfalls can be made up by imports.

因此，许多国家现在无需进行任何重大调整，就能利用间歇性能源生产高达15%的电力。丹麦的例子表明，一个规模相对较小且互联互通良好的市场可以实现更高的增长。[73] 2019年，丹麦45%的电力来自风力发电，如此高的比例无需大规模的国内备用容量即可维持，因为任何电力缺口都可以通过从瑞典（水力发电和核电）和德国（电力来源多样）进口来弥补。德国则无法做到这一点：其电力需求是丹麦的20多倍，因此必须维持足够的备用容量，以便在新的可再生能源发电项目闲置时启用。[74] 2019年，德国发电量为577太瓦时，比2000年仅增长不到5%，但其装机容量却增长了约73%（从121吉瓦增至约209吉瓦）。造成这种差异的原因显而易见。

As a result, many countries now produce up to 15 percent of all electricity from intermittent sources without any major adjustments, and Denmark shows how a relatively small and well-interconnected market can go far higher.[73] In 2019, 45 percent of its electricity came from wind generation, and this exceptionally high share can be sustained without any massive domestic reserve capacities, because any shortfalls can be readily made up by imports from Sweden (hydro and nuclear electricity) and Germany (electricity coming from many sources). Germany could not do the same: its demand is more than 20 times the Danish total, and the country must maintain a sufficient reserve capacity that could be activated when new renewables are dormant.[74] In 2019, Germany generated 577 terawatt-hours of electricity, less than 5 percent more than in 2000—but its installed generating capacity expanded by about 73 percent (from 121 to about 209 gigawatts). The reason for this discrepancy is obvious.

2020年，在德国启动“能源转型”（Energiewende） ——一项旨在加速能源转型的计划——二十年后，为了满足阴天和无风天气下的用电需求，德国仍然不得不保留其大部分化石燃料发电能力（实际上高达89%）。毕竟，在阴雨连绵的德国，光伏发电的平均运行时间仅为11%至12%，而化石燃料燃烧在2020年仍然贡献了近一半（48%）的电力。此外，尽管风力发电的份额不断增加，但德国建设新的高压输电线路，将风力资源丰富的北部地区输送到南部高需求地区，却进展缓慢。而在美国，虽然需要建设规模更大的输电项目，才能将大平原的风力发电和西南地区的太阳能发电输送到高需求的沿海地区，但几乎没有任何长期规划的输电线路建设得以实现。[75]

In 2020, two decades after the beginning of Energiewende, its deliberately accelerated energy transition, Germany still had to keep most of its fossil-fired capacity (89 percent of it, actually) in order to meet demand on cloudy and calm days. After all, in gloomy Germany, photovoltaic generation works on average only 11–12 percent of time, and the combustion of fossil fuels still produced nearly half (48 percent) of all electricity in 2020. Moreover, as its share of wind generation has increased, its construction of new high-voltage lines to transmit this electricity from the windy north to the southern regions of high demand has fallen behind. And in the US, where much larger transmission projects would be needed to move wind electricity from the Great Plains and solar electricity from the Southwest to high-demand coastal areas, hardly any long-standing plans to build these links have been realized.[75]

尽管此类安排充满挑战，但它们依赖于技术成熟（且仍在不断改进）的解决方案——即更高效的光伏电池、大型陆上和海上风力涡轮机以及高压（包括长距离直流）输电。如果成本、审批流程和“邻避效应”等因素不构成障碍，这些技术就能以相当快的速度和经济的方式部署。此外，重新依赖核能发电可以解决太阳能和风能发电的间歇性问题。核能的复兴将尤其具有重要意义。如果我们无法尽快开发出更好的大规模储能方法，这将有所帮助。

As challenging as such arrangements are, they rely on technically mature (and still improving) solutions—that is, on more efficient PV cells, large onshore and offshore wind turbines, and high-voltage (including long-distance direct current) transmission. If costs, permitting processes, and not-in-my-backyard sentiments were no obstacles, these techniques could be deployed fairly rapidly and economically. Moreover, the problems of intermittency of solar and wind generation could be resolved by renewed reliance on nuclear electricity generation. A nuclear renaissance would be particularly helpful if we cannot develop better ways of large-scale electricity storage soon.

我们需要为大城市和特大城市提供超大型（数吉瓦时）储能系统，但目前唯一可行的方案是抽水蓄能（PHS）：它利用夜间更便宜的电力将水从低洼水库抽到高处蓄水池，其放水可立即提供电力。[76]如果使用可再生能源发电，抽水可以在太阳能或风能发电过剩时进行，但显然抽水蓄能只能在具有合适高差的地区运行，而且抽水过程会消耗大约四分之一的发电量。其他储能方式，例如电池、压缩空气和超级电容器，其容量仍然比大城市所需的容量低几个数量级，即使是满足一天的储能需求也远远不够。[77]

We need very large (multi-gigawatt-hour) storage for big cities and megacities, but so far the only viable option to serve them is pumped hydro storage (PHS): it uses cheaper nighttime electricity to pump water from a low-lying reservoir to high-lying storage, and its discharge provides instantly available generation.[76] With renewably generated electricity, the pumping could be done whenever surplus solar or wind capacity is available, but obviously PHS can work only in places with suitable elevation differences and the operation consumes about a quarter of generated electricity for the uphill pumping of water. Other energy storages, such as batteries, compressed air, and supercapacitors, still have capacities orders of magnitude lower than needed by large cities, even for a single day’s worth of storage.[77]

相比之下，现代核反应堆如果建造得当、运行谨慎，就能提供安全、持久且高度可靠的发电方式；正如前文所述，它们的运行时间可超过90%，使用寿命可超过40年。然而，核电的未来仍然充满不确定性。目前只有中国、印度和韩国致力于进一步扩大核电产能。在西方，高昂的资本成本、严重的建设延误以及更经济的选择（例如美国的天然气、欧洲的风能和太阳能）使得新建核裂变反应堆缺乏吸引力。此外，美国新型小型模块化本质安全反应堆（最早于20世纪80年代提出）尚未实现商业化，而德国决定在2022年前全面停止核电，这只是欧洲普遍存在的根深蒂固的反核情绪的一个最明显的例子（关于核电实际风险的评估，请参见第五章）。

In contrast, modern nuclear reactors, if properly built and carefully run, offer safe, long-lasting, and highly reliable ways of electricity generation; as already noted, they are able to operate more than 90 percent of the time, and their lifespan can exceed 40 years. Still, the future of nuclear generation remains uncertain. Only China, India, and South Korea are committed to further expansion of their capacities. In the West, the combination of high capital costs, major construction delays, and the availability of less expensive choices (natural gas in the US, wind and solar in Europe) has made new fission capacities unattractive. Moreover, America’s new small, modular, and inherently safe reactors (first proposed during the 1980s) have yet to be commercialized, and Germany, with its decision to abandon all nuclear generation by 2022, is only the most obvious example of Europe’s widely shared, deep anti-nuclear sentiment (for the assessment of real nuclear generation risks, see chapter 5).

但这种情况可能不会持续：就连欧盟现在也承认，如果没有核反应堆，它根本无法实现其雄心勃勃的脱碳目标。欧盟2050年净零排放情景摒弃了核工业数十年来停滞不前和被忽视的局面，并设想高达20%的能源消耗将来自核裂变。[78]请注意，这里指的是一次能源总消耗量，而不仅仅是电力。电力仅占其中的一小部分。占全球最终能源消耗总量18%的运输环节，以及超过80%的最终能源用途（包括工业、家庭、商业和交通运输）的脱碳，将比电力生产的脱碳更具挑战性。扩大发电规模可用于空间供暖和许多目前依赖化石燃料的工业流程，但现代长途运输的脱碳路径仍不明朗。

But this may not last: even the European Union now recognizes that it could not come close to its extraordinarily ambitious decarbonization target without nuclear reactors. Its 2050 net-zero emissions scenarios set aside the decades-long stagnation and neglect of the nuclear industry, and envisage up to 20 percent of all energy consumption coming from nuclear fission.[78] Notice that this refers to total primary energy consumption, not just to electricity. Electricity is only 18 percent of total final global energy consumption, and the decarbonization of more than 80 percent of final energy uses—by industries, households, commerce, and transportation—will be even more challenging than the decarbonization of electricity generation. Expanded electricity generation can be used for space heating and by many industrial processes now relying on fossil fuels, but the course of decarbonizing modern long-distance transportation remains unclear.

我们何时才能乘坐电池驱动的宽体喷气式客机进行洲际飞行？新闻标题纷纷宣称，航空的未来是电动的——却巧妙地忽略了涡扇发动机燃烧煤油的能量密度与目前最先进的锂离子电池（假想中的电动飞机所搭载的电池）能量密度之间存在的巨大差距。喷气式客机使用的涡扇发动机燃烧的燃料能量密度为每千克46兆焦耳（约合每千克12000瓦时），将化学能转化为热能和动能——而目前最先进的锂离子电池的能量密度不足300瓦时/千克，两者相差超过40倍。[79]诚然，电动机的能量转换效率大约是燃气轮机的两倍，因此实际的能量密度差距“仅”约为20倍。但在过去 30 年里，电池的最大能量密度大约增加了两倍，即使我们再增加两倍，到 2050 年，能量密度仍然远低于 3,000 Wh/kg——远远不足以乘坐宽体客机从纽约飞往东京或从巴黎飞往新加坡，而几十年来，我们每天都在乘坐以煤油为燃料的波音和空客飞机进行这样的飞行。[80]

How soon will we fly intercontinentally on a wide-body jet powered by batteries? News headlines assure us that the future of flight is electric—touchingly ignoring the huge gap between the energy density of kerosene burned by turbofans and today’s best lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries that would be on board these hypothetically electric planes. Turbofan engines powering jetliners burn fuel whose energy density is 46 megajoules per kilogram (that’s nearly 12,000 watt-hours per kilogram), converting chemical to thermal and kinetic energy—while today’s best Li-ion batteries supply less than 300 Wh/kg, more than a 40-fold difference.[79] Admittedly, electric motors are roughly twice as efficient energy converters as gas turbines, and hence the effective density gap is “only” about 20-fold. But during the past 30 years the maximum energy density of batteries has roughly tripled, and even if we were to triple that again densities would still be well below 3,000 Wh/kg in 2050—falling far short of taking a wide-body plane from New York to Tokyo or from Paris to Singapore, something we have been doing daily for decades with kerosene-fueled Boeings and Airbuses.[80]

此外（正如第三章将要阐述的），我们目前还没有现成的、可大规模商业化的替代方案，能够仅依靠电力来满足现代文明四大物质支柱的生产需求。这意味着，即使拥有充足可靠的可再生电力供应，我们也必须开发新的大规模工艺来生产钢铁、氨、水泥和塑料。

Moreover (as will be explained in chapter 3), we have no readily deployable commercial-scale alternatives for energizing the production of the four material pillars of modern civilization solely by electricity. This means that even with an abundant and reliable renewable electricity supply, we would have to develop new large-scale processes to produce steel, ammonia, cement, and plastics.

不出所料，电力生产以外的脱碳进程进展缓慢。德国即将实现一半电力来自可再生能源，但在过去二十年的能源转型过程中，化石燃料在该国一次能源供应中的份额仅从约84%下降到78%。德国人喜欢在高速公路上不受限制的速度行驶，也喜欢频繁的洲际飞行，德国工业也依赖天然气和石油。[81]如果德国继续保持过去的增长速度，那么到2040年，其对化石燃料的依赖程度仍将接近70%。

Not surprisingly, decarbonization outside of electricity generation has progressed slowly. Germany will soon generate half of its electricity from renewables, but during the two decades of Energiewende the share of fossil fuels in the country’s primary energy supply has only declined from about 84 percent to 78 percent: Germans like their unrestricted Autobahn speeds and their frequent intercontinental flying, and German industries hum on natural gas and oil.[81] If the country replicates its past record, then in 2040 its dependence on fossil fuels will still be close to 70 percent.

那么，那些没有投入巨资大力发展可再生能源的国家又如何呢？日本就是一个典型的例子：2000年，日本约83%的一次能源来自化石燃料；而到了2019年，由于福岛核事故后核电停运以及对更多燃料进口的需求，这一比例高达90%！[82]尽管美国已大幅降低了对煤炭的依赖——发电领域以天然气取而代之——但2019年，美国一次能源供应中化石燃料的占比仍然高达80%。与此同时，中国的化石燃料占比从2000年的93%下降到2019年的85%——但与此同时，中国的化石燃料需求却增长了近三倍。中国的经济崛起是 21 世纪头二十年全球化石燃料消费量增长约 45% 的主要原因，也是尽管可再生能源得到了广泛而昂贵的发展，但化石燃料在世界一次能源供应中的份额仅略有下降，从 87% 下降到约 84% 的原因。[83]

And what about countries that have not pushed renewables at extraordinary expense? Japan is the foremost example: in the year 2000 about 83 percent of its primary energy came from fossil fuels; in 2019 that share (due to the post-Fukushima loss of nuclear generation and the need for higher fuel imports) was 90 percent![82] And while the US has greatly reduced its dependence on coal—replaced by natural gas in electricity generation—the country’s share of fossil fuels in primary energy supply was still 80 percent fossil in 2019. Meanwhile China’s share of fossil fuels fell from 93 percent in the year 2000 to 85 percent in 2019—but this relative decline was accompanied by a near tripling of the country’s fossil fuel demand. The economic rise of China was the main reason why the global consumption of fossil fuels rose by about 45 percent during the first two decades of the 21st century, and why, despite extensive and expensive expansion of renewable energies, the share of fossil fuels in the world’s primary energy supply fell only marginally, from 87 percent to about 84 percent.[83]

全球每年对化石碳的需求量略高于100亿吨——这一数字几乎是近年来人类主要粮食作物年产量的五倍，也是全球近80亿人口每年饮用水总量的两倍多——显而易见，要取代如此巨大的化石碳需求，仅靠政府设定的以零或五结尾的年份目标是远远不够的。化石碳的高占比和其巨大的依赖规模，使得任何快速的替代都成为不可能：这并非源于对全球能源系统缺乏了解的个人偏见，而是基于工程和经济现实得出的结论。

Annual global demand for fossil carbon is now just above 10 billion tons a year—a mass nearly five times more than the recent annual harvest of all staple grains feeding humanity, and more than twice the total mass of water drunk annually by the world’s nearly 8 billion inhabitants—and it should be obvious that displacing and replacing such a mass is not something best handled by government targets for years ending in zero or five. Both the high relative share and the scale of our dependence on fossil carbon make any rapid substitutions impossible: this is not a biased personal impression stemming from a poor understanding of the global energy system – but a realistic conclusion based on engineering and economic realities.

与近期仓促的政治承诺相反，所有经过深思熟虑的长期能源供应方案都已认识到这些现实。国际能源署（IEA）2020年发布的既定政策情景预测化石燃料的份额将下降。2019 年全球总需求的 80% 到 2040 年将降至 72%，而国际能源署的可持续发展情景（迄今为止最激进的脱碳情景，允许大幅加速全球脱碳）设想，到 2040 年化石燃料仍将满足全球一次能源需求的 56%，因此，在短短十年内将这一高比例削减至接近零的可能性极小。[84]

In contrast to recent hasty political pledges, these realities have been recognized by all carefully considered long-term energy supply scenarios. The Stated Policies Scenario published by the International Energy Agency (IEA) in 2020 sees the share of fossil fuels declining from 80 percent of the total global demand in 2019 to 72 percent by 2040, while the IEA’s Sustainable Development Scenario (its most aggressive decarbonization scenario so far, allowing for substantially accelerated global decarbonization) envisages fossil fuels supplying 56 percent of the global primary energy demand by 2040, making it highly improbable that this high share could be cut close to zero in a single decade.[84]

当然，富裕国家——鉴于其财富、技术能力、高人均消费水平以及随之而来的大量浪费——可以采取一些令人瞩目且相对迅速的脱碳措施（坦率地说，就是减少各种能源的使用）。但对于超过50亿人口而言，情况并非如此。他们的能源消耗量远低于富裕国家，却需要更多的氨来提高作物产量以养活不断增长的人口，需要更多的钢铁、水泥和塑料来建设必要的基础设施。我们需要的是逐步减少对现代世界赖以生存的能源的依赖。我们仍然不了解即将到来的转型的大多数细节，但有一点是肯定的：这不会（也不可能是）突然放弃化石碳，甚至不会使其迅速消亡——而是逐步减少。[85]

Certainly, the affluent world—given its wealth, technical capabilities, high level of per capita consumption and the concomitant level of waste—can take some impressive and relatively rapid decarbonization steps (to put it bluntly, it should do with using less energy of any kind). But that is not the case with the more than 5 billion people whose energy consumption is a fraction of those affluent levels, who need much more ammonia to raise their crop yields to feed their increasing populations, and much more steel and cement and plastics to build their essential infrastructures. What we need is to pursue a steady reduction of our dependence on the energies that made the modern world. We still do not know most of the particulars of this coming transition, but one thing remains certain: it will not be (it cannot be) a sudden abandonment of fossil carbon, nor even its rapid demise—but rather its gradual decline.[85]

2. 了解食品生产

2. Understanding Food Production

食用化石燃料

Eating Fossil Fuels

对所有物种而言，获取充足且营养丰富的食物是生存的根本。在漫长的进化过程中，我们的人类祖先进化出了关键的生理优势——直立行走、双足行走以及相对较大的脑容量——这些优势使他们区别于猿类祖先。这些特征的结合使他们能够更好地觅食腐肉、采集植物以及猎捕小型动物。

Securing a sufficient quantity and nutritional variety of food is the existential imperative for every species. During their long evolution, our hominin ancestors evolved key physical advantages—erect posture, bipedalism, and relatively large brains—that set them apart from their simian ancestors. This combination of traits enabled them to become better scavengers, collectors of plants, and hunters of small animals.

早期人类仅拥有最简单的石器工具（石锤、砍砸器），这些工具可用于屠宰动物，但他们没有任何辅助狩猎和捕猎的工具。他们能够轻易杀死受伤或生病的动物以及行动缓慢的小型哺乳动物，但大型猎物的肉大多来自野生捕食者的残骸。[1]长矛、斧柄、弓箭、编织网、篮子和钓竿的最终出现，使得狩猎和捕猎多种物种成为可能。一些群体——尤其是旧石器时代晚期（大约在12000年前结束）的猛犸象猎人——掌握了屠杀大型野兽的技巧，而许多沿海居民也成为了技艺精湛的渔民：有些人甚至使用船只捕杀迁徙的小型鲸鱼。

Early hominins had only the simplest stone tools (hammerstones, choppers), which were useful for butchering animals, but they had no artifacts to aid hunting and catching. They could easily kill injured or sick animals and small, slower-moving mammals, but most of the meat of larger prey came from scavenging kills made by wild predators.[1] The eventual deployment of long spears, shafted axes, bows and arrows, woven nets, baskets, and fishing rods made it possible to hunt and catch a wide variety of species. Some groups—most notably the mammoth hunters of the Upper Paleolithic (this age ended about 12,000 years ago)—mastered the slaughter of large beasts, while many coastal dwellers became accomplished fishers: some even used boats to kill small migrating whales.

从采集（狩猎和采集）生活方式向定居生活方式的转变，得益于早期农业的发展以及多种哺乳动物和鸟类的驯化，使得食物供应总体上更加可预测，但仍然常常不稳定，从而能够支撑比早期群体高得多的人口密度——但这并不一定意味着平均营养状况更好。在干旱环境中采集食物可能需要超过100平方公里的土地才能养活一个家庭。对于今天的伦敦人来说，这大约相当于从白金汉宫到狗岛的距离；对于纽约人来说，这相当于一只海鸥的飞行距离。从曼哈顿最南端到中央公园中心：为了生存，需要跨越很远的距离。

The transition from foraging (hunting and collecting) to sedentary living, supported by early agriculture and the domestication of several mammalian and avian species, resulted in a generally more predictable, but still often unreliable, food supply that was able to support much higher population densities than was the case for earlier groups—but this didn’t necessarily mean better average nutrition. Foraging in arid environments could require an area of more than 100 square kilometers to support a single family. For today’s Londoners, that is roughly the distance from Buckingham Palace to the Isle of Dogs; for New Yorkers, that’s how a seagull flies from Manhattan’s tip to the middle of Central Park: a lot of ground to cover simply to survive.

在生产力较高的地区，人口密度可高达每100公顷2-3人（相当于约140个标准足球场）。[2]人口密度高的采集狩猎社会仅限于沿海群体（尤其是在太平洋西北地区），他们可以利用每年的鱼类洄游，并有充足的机会猎捕水生哺乳动物：稳定的高蛋白、高脂肪食物供应使他们中的一些人得以转为定居生活，居住在大型的公共木屋中，并有闲暇时间雕刻令人印象深刻的图腾柱。相比之下，早期农业，即刚刚驯化的作物被收获的时期，意味着每公顷耕地可以养活不止一个人。

In more productive regions, population densities could rise to as many as 2–3 people per 100 hectares (equal to about 140 standard soccer fields).[2] The only foraging societies with high population densities were coastal groups (most notably in the Pacific Northwest), who had access to annual fish migrations and plentiful opportunities to hunt aquatic mammals: reliable supply of high-protein, high-fat food allowed some of them to switch to sedentary lives in large communal wooden homes, and left them with spare time to carve impressive totem poles. In contrast, early agriculture, where the just-domesticated crops were harvested, meant that more than one person per hectare of cultivated land could be fed.

与采集者可以采集数十种野生植物不同，早期农业的实践者不得不缩小种植植物的种类，因为少数几种主粮作物（小麦、大麦、水稻、玉米、豆类、土豆）主导了典型的、以植物为主的饮食——但这些作物能够养活比采集社会高出两到三个数量级的人口密度。在古埃及，人口密度从前王朝时期（公元前3150年以前）每公顷耕地约1.3人上升到3500年后，即埃及成为罗马帝国行省时，每公顷耕地约2.5人。[3]这相当于需要4000平方米的土地才能养活一个人——几乎正好是六个网球场的面积。但如此高的生产密度（由于尼罗河每年稳定的泛滥）是一项极其出色的成就。

Unlike the foragers who might have gathered scores of wild species, practitioners of early agriculture had to narrow the variety of the plants they cultivated, as a few staple crops (wheat, barley, rice, corn, legumes, potatoes) dominated typical, overwhelmingly plant-based, diets—but these crops could support population densities that were two or three orders of magnitude higher than in foraging societies. In ancient Egypt, the density rate rose from about 1.3 people per hectare of cultivated land during the predynastic period (pre–3150 bce) to about 2.5 people per hectare 3,500 years later, when the country was a province of the Roman Empire.[3] This is equivalent to needing an area of 4,000 square meters to feed one person—or almost exactly six tennis courts. But this high production density was (due to the Nile’s reliable annual flooding) an exceptionally good performance.

随着时间的推移，前工业时代的粮食生产率缓慢上升，但直到16世纪，每公顷3人的粮食产量才达到，而且仅在明朝集约化耕作的地区实现；在欧洲，直到18世纪，每公顷粮食产量仍低于2人。在漫长的前工业时代，粮食生产能力的停滞不前，或者至少是极其缓慢的增长，意味着直到几代人以前，只有少数衣食无忧的精英阶层才不必为温饱担忧。即使在偶尔的丰收年份，人们的饮食也依然单调乏味，营养不良和营养不足的现象十分普遍。收成可能歉收，农作物也常常在战争中被毁——饥荒是家常便饭。因此，近年来发生的任何变革——例如个人流动性的增强或私人财产范围的扩大——都不如我们年复一年生产充足食物的能力那样具有根本性的生存意义。如今，大多数富裕和中等收入国家的人们担心的是如何吃（以及吃多少）才能保持或改善健康、延长寿命，而不是是否有足够的食物来维持生存。

Over time, and very slowly, preindustrial rates of food production rose even higher—but rates of 3 people per hectare were not achieved until the 16th century, and only then in intensively cultivated regions of Ming China; in Europe they remained below 2 people per hectare until the 18th century. This stagnation, or at least very slow gains, in feeding capacity during the long course of preindustrial history meant that until a few generations ago only a small share of well-fed elites did not have to worry about having enough to eat. Even during the occasional years of above-average harvests, typical diets remained monotonous, and malnutrition and undernutrition were common. Harvests could fail, and crops were often destroyed in wars—famine was a regular occurrence. As a result, no recent transformation—such as increased personal mobility or a greater range of private possessions—has been so existentially fundamental as our ability to produce, year after year, a surfeit of food. Now most people in affluent and middle-income countries worry about what (and how much) is best to eat in order to maintain or improve their health and extend their longevity, not whether they will have enough to survive.

尽管仍有相当数量的儿童、青少年和成年人面临粮食短缺，尤其是在撒哈拉以南非洲国家，但在过去三代人的时间里，这一比例已从世界大多数下降到不足十分之一。联合国粮食及农业组织（粮农组织）估计，全球营养不良人口比例从1950年的约65%下降到1970年的25%，到2000年进一步下降到约15%。持续的改善（尽管受自然灾害或武装冲突造成的暂时性国家或地区挫折的影响而有所波动）使这一比例在2019年降至8.9%——这意味着粮食产量的提高使营养不良率从1950年的三分之二下降到2019年的十一分之一。[4]

There are still significant numbers of children, adolescents, and adults who experience food shortages, particularly in the countries of sub-Saharan Africa, but during the past three generations their total has declined from the world’s majority to less than 1 in 10 of the world’s inhabitants. The United Nations’ Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) estimates that the worldwide share of undernourished people decreased from about 65 percent in 1950 to 25 percent by 1970, and to about 15 percent by the year 2000. Continued improvements (with fluctuations caused by temporary national or regional setbacks due to natural disasters or armed conflicts) lowered the rate to 8.9 percent by 2019—which means that rising food production reduced the malnutrition rate from 2 in 3 people in 1950 to 1 in 11 by 2019.[4]

如果考虑到全球人口在此期间的大规模增长（从1950年的约25亿人增长到2019年的77亿人），这一令人瞩目的成就就更加值得关注了。全球营养不良人口的急剧减少意味着，1950年世界能够为约8.9亿人提供充足的食物，但到2019年，这一数字已上升到超过70亿：绝对值增长了近八倍！

This impressive achievement is even more noteworthy if expressed in a way that accounts for the intervening large-scale increase of the global population, from about 2.5 billion people in 1950 to 7.7 billion in 2019. The steep reduction in global undernutrition means that in 1950 the world was able to supply adequate food to about 890 million people, but by 2019 that had risen to just over 7 billion: a nearly eight-fold increase in absolute terms!

是什么造就了这一令人瞩目的成就？回答说这一定是作物产量提高的结果，这当然是老生常谈。说产量增长是作物品种改良、农业机械化、施肥、灌溉和作物保护等因素共同作用的结果，虽然正确地描述了关键投入要素的变化，但仍然忽略了根本原因。现代粮食生产，无论是田间作物种植还是野生海洋物种捕捞，都是一种特殊的混合模式，依赖于两种不同的能源。第一种，也是最重要的一种，是……显而易见，太阳是主要能源。但我们也需要如今不可或缺的化石燃料，以及人类生产和产生的电力。

What explains this impressive achievement? Answering that it must be due to higher crop yields is a truism. Saying that the increase has been the combined effect of better crop varieties, agricultural mechanization, fertilization, irrigation, and crop protection correctly describes the changes in key inputs—but it still misses the fundamental explanation. Modern food production, be it field cultivation of crops or the capture of wild marine species, is a peculiar hybrid dependent on two different kinds of energy. The first, and most obvious, is the Sun. But we also need the now indispensable input of fossil fuels, and the electricity produced and generated by humans.

当被问及我们对化石燃料依赖的常见例子时，欧洲和北美寒冷地区的居民会立刻想到用于房屋供暖的天然气。世界各地的人们都会指出，液态燃料的燃烧为我们的大部分交通工具提供动力，但现代世界对化石燃料最重要——也是关乎生存的根本——的依赖，在于它们在粮食生产中的直接和间接应用。直接应​​用包括为所有农用机械（主要是拖拉机、联合收割机和其他收割机）提供动力，将农作物从田间运输到储存和加工场所，以及灌溉水泵所需的燃料。间接应用的范围则更广，涵盖了用于生产农业机械、化肥和农用化学品（除草剂、杀虫剂、杀菌剂）的燃料和电力，以及其他投入品，例如温室使用的玻璃和塑料薄膜，以及实现精准农业的全球定位设备。

When asked to give common examples of our reliance on fossil fuels, inhabitants of the colder parts of Europe and North America will think immediately about the natural gas used to heat their houses. People everywhere will point out the combustion of liquid fuels that power most of our transportation but the modern world’s most important—and fundamentally existential—dependence on fossil fuels is their direct and indirect use in the production of our food. Direct use includes fuels to power all field machinery (mostly tractors, combines, and other harvesters), the transportation of harvests from fields to storage and processing sites, and irrigation pumps. Indirect use is much broader, taking into account the fuels and electricity used to produce agricultural machinery, fertilizers, and agrochemicals (herbicides, insecticides, fungicides), and other inputs ranging from glass and plastic sheets for greenhouses, to global positioning devices that enable precision farming.

生产我们食物的基本能量转化过程并未改变：我们依然在食用光合作用的产物，无论是直接食用植物性食物还是间接食用动物性食物——光合作用是生物圈最重要的能量转化过程，其能量来源是太阳辐射。改变的是农作物和畜牧业的生产强度：如果没有化石燃料和电力投入的持续增长，我们不可能以如此高的频率和可预测的方式获得如此丰收。如果没有这些人为能源补贴，我们就无法为90%的人类提供充足的营养，也无法将全球营养不良率降低到如此高的水平，同时还能稳步减少养活一个人所需的耕地面积和时间。

The fundamental energy conversion producing our food has not changed: as always, we are eating, whether directly as plant foods or indirectly as animal foodstuffs, products of photosynthesis—the biosphere’s most important energy conversion, powered by solar radiation. What has changed is the intensity of our crop, and animal, production: we could not harvest such abundance, and in such a highly predictable manner, without the still-rising inputs of fossil fuels and electricity. Without these anthropogenic energy subsidies, we could not have supplied 90 percent of humanity with adequate nutrition and we could not have reduced global malnutrition to such a degree, while simultaneously steadily decreasing the amount of time and the area of cropland needed to feed one person.

农业——种植供人类食用的粮食作物和供动物食用的饲料——必须依靠太阳辐射，特别是可见光谱中的蓝色和红色部分来提供能量。[5]叶绿素和类胡萝卜素是植物细胞中的光敏分子，它们吸收这些波长的光，并利用这些光进行光合作用。光合作用是一个多步骤的化学反应过程，它将大气中的二氧化碳和水以及少量其他元素（包括……）结合起来。尤其重要的是氮和磷——用于生产谷物、豆类、块茎、油料作物和糖料作物所需的新植物物质。这些作物的一部分被用作家畜的饲料，以生产肉、奶和蛋；此外，还有哺乳动物以草和水生生物为食，而这些水生生物的生长最终依赖于浮游植物，浮游植物是水生光合作用产生的主要植物物质。[6]

Agriculture—growing food crops for people and feed for animals—must be energized by solar radiation, specifically by the blue and red parts of the visible spectrum.[5] Chlorophylls and carotenoids, light-sensitive molecules in plant cells, absorb light at these wavelengths and use it to power photosynthesis, a multi-step sequence of chemical reactions that combines atmospheric carbon dioxide and water—as well as small amounts of elements including, notably, nitrogen and phosphorus—to produce new plant mass for grain, legume, tuber, oil, and sugar crops. Part of these harvests is fed to domestic animals to produce meat, milk, and eggs, and additional animal foods come from mammals that graze on grasses and aquatic species whose growth depends ultimately on phytoplankton, the dominant plant mass produced by aquatic photosynthesis.[6]

自一万年前人类定居耕作之初，情况一直如此——但两个世纪前，非太阳能形式的引入开始影响作物生产，后来也影响了野生海洋物种的捕捞。最初这种影响微乎其微，直到20世纪初才变得显著。

This has always been so, from the very beginnings of settled cultivation going back some 10 millennia—but two centuries ago the addition of non-solar forms of energy began to affect the crop production and later also the capture of wild marine species. Initially this impact was marginal, and it became notable only in the early decades of the 20th century.

为了追溯这一划时代转变的演变历程，接下来我们将考察过去两个世纪美国的小麦产量。然而，我完全可以选择英国或法国的小麦产量，或者中国或日本的水稻产量；尽管北美、西欧和东亚等耕作地区的农业进步发生的时间可能有所不同，但基于美国数据的这一比较序列并无独特之处。

To trace the evolution of this epochal shift, we’ll look next at the past two centuries of American wheat production. However, I could quite easily have chosen English or French wheat yields, or Chinese or Japanese rice yields; while agricultural advances may have happened at different times in cultivated parts of North America, Western Europe, and East Asia, there is nothing unique about this comparative sequence that is based on US data.

三个山谷，相隔两个世纪

Three valleys, two centuries apart

我们将从 1801 年的纽约州西部杰纳西河谷开始。这个新生的共和国已经成立 26 年了，然而美国农民种植面包小麦的方式，不仅与几代人之前他们的祖先从英国移民到英属北美之前的方式相同，而且与两千多年前古埃及的做法也并无太大不同。

We’ll start in the Genesee Valley, western New York, in 1801. The new republic is in the 26th year of its existence and yet American farmers grow bread wheat not just the same way their ancestors did before they emigrated from England to British North America a few generations ago, but in a manner not too different from practices in ancient Egypt more than two millennia ago.

耕作始于两头牛拉着木制犁，犁刃上钉着铁板。播种的是去年留下的种子，用人工播种，然后用耙子覆盖。每公顷播种大约需要27个小时的人工。[7]而最繁重的工序还在后面。收割作物时，用镰刀割下；割下的秸秆被手工捆扎成捆，然后竖直堆放。（捆成垛）晾晒。然后将麦捆运到谷仓，在硬地上用鞭子抽打脱粒，堆放好秸秆，扬谷（去除谷壳），称量后装袋。每公顷收割至少需要120小时的人工。

The sequence begins with two oxen harnessed to a wooden plow whose cutting edge is shod with an iron plate. Seed, saved from the previous year’s crop, is sown by hand, and brush harrows are used to cover it up. Putting the crop in takes about 27 hours of human labor for every seeded hectare.[7] And the most laborious tasks are still to come. The crop is harvested by cutting with sickles; cut stalks are bundled and tied manually in sheaves, and they are stacked upright (to make shocks or stooks) and left to dry. The sheaves are then hauled to a barn and threshed by flailing them on a hard floor, straw is stacked, and grain is winnowed (separated from the chaff), measured, and put into sacks. Securing the crop takes at least 120 hours of human labor per hectare.

整个生产流程每公顷需要约150小时的人工劳动，以及约70小时的牛力劳动。每公顷仅产出一吨谷物，其中至少10%必须留作来年播种。总​​而言之，生产一公斤小麦大约需要10分钟的人工劳动，而这些小麦如果磨成全麦面粉，可以制成1.6公斤（两个面包）面包。这种耕作方式劳动强度大、效率低、产量低，但它完全依靠太阳能，除了太阳辐射外无需其他能源投入：作物为人类提供食物，为动物提供饲料；树木提供烹饪和取暖所需的木材；木材还可以用来制作冶金木炭，用于冶炼铁矿石，以及生产小型金属制品，例如犁铧、镰刀、大镰、刀具和用于覆盖木制车轮的轮辋。用现代的话来说，这种农业不需要不可再生（化石燃料）能源投入，只需要极少的不可再生材料补贴（铁部件、磨坊的石头），而且作物和材料的生产完全依赖于通过人类和动物肌肉的劳动而产生的可再生能源。

The complete production sequence demands about 150 hours of human labor per hectare, as well as about 70 ox-hours. The yield is just one ton of grain per hectare, and of that at least 10 percent has to be set aside as seed for the next year’s crop. Altogether, it takes about 10 minutes of human labor to produce a kilogram of wheat, and that would, with wholegrain flour, yield 1.6 kilograms (two loaves) of bread. This is laborious, slow, and low-yielding farming—but it is completely solar, and no other energy inputs are required beyond the Sun’s radiation: the crops produce food for people and feed for animals; trees yield wood for cooking and heating; and wood is also used to make metallurgical charcoal for smelting iron ores and producing small metal objects including plow plates, sickles, scythes, knives, and strakes to cover wooden wagon wheels. In modern parlance, we would say that this farming requires no non-renewable (fossil fuel) energy inputs and only a minimum of non-renewable material subsidies (iron components, stones for gristmills), and that the production of both crops and materials relies solely on renewable energies deployed through the exertion of human and animal muscles.

一个世纪后的1901年，全国大部分小麦产自大平原，因此我们转向北达科他州东部的红河谷。大平原地区在过去两代人的时间里已经有人定居，工业化取得了巨大的进步——尽管小麦种植仍然依赖役畜，但达科他州大型农场的小麦种植已经高度机械化。四匹强壮的马拉着多联式钢犁和耙，播种机用于播种，收割机负责收割秸秆和捆扎麦捆，只有堆垛工作需要人工完成。麦捆被运到垛口，送入蒸汽机驱动的脱粒机，然后谷物被运往粮仓。整个过程每公顷耗时不到22小时，约为1801年的七分之一。[8]在这种大规模耕作中，大面积弥补了低产量：产量仍然很低，只有1吨。每公顷的人工投入仅为每公斤谷物约 1.5 分钟（1801 年为 10 分钟），而使用役畜则相当于每公顷约 37 马小时，即每公斤谷物超过 2 分钟。

A century later, in 1901, most of the country’s wheat comes from the Great Plains and so we move to the Red River Valley, in eastern North Dakota. The Great Plains have been settled and industrialization has made enormous advances during the past two generations—although wheat farming still relies on draft animals, the wheat growing on large Dakota farms is highly mechanized. Teams of four powerful horses pull gang (multi-share) steel plows and harrows, mechanical seed drills are used for planting, mechanical harvesters cut the stalks and bind the sheaves, and only the stooking is done manually. Sheaves are hauled to stacks and fed to threshing machines powered by steam engines, and grain is taken to granaries. The entire sequence takes less than 22 hours per hectare, about 1/7 of the time it did in 1801.[8] In this extensive cultivation, large areas make up for low yields: yields remain low at 1 ton per hectare but the investment of human labor is only about 1.5 minutes per kilogram of grain (compared to 10 minutes in 1801), while the use of draft animals adds up to about 37 horse-hours per hectare, or more than 2 minutes per kilogram of grain.

这是一种新型的混合农业模式，除了不可或缺的太阳能之外，还大量使用主要来自煤炭的不可再生能源。这种新的耕作方式需要更多的动物劳动而非人类劳动，而且由于役用马匹（以及美国南部的骡子）需要谷物饲料（主要是燕麦）以及新鲜的牧草和干草，它们的数量庞大，对美国的农作物生产提出了很高的要求：美国大约四分之一的农田都用于种植役畜饲料。[9]

This is a new, hybrid kind of farming, as the indispensable solar input is augmented by non-renewable anthropogenic energies derived overwhelmingly from coal. The new arrangement requires more animal labor than human labor, and as working horses (and mules in the American South) need grain feed—mainly oats—as well as fresh grass and hay, their large numbers make substantial demands on the country’s crop production: about one-quarter of all American farmland is devoted to growing fodder for draft animals.[9]

化石能源投入的不断增加使得高产作物成为可能。煤炭用于制造冶金焦炭，冶金焦炭被送入高炉炼钢；铸铁则在平炉中炼成钢（参见第三章）。钢铁是农业机械以及蒸汽机、铁轨、货车、机车和船舶制造的必需品。煤炭也为蒸汽机提供动力，并产生制造犁、钻机、收割机（包括最早的联合收割机）、货车和筒仓所需的热能和电力，以及用于运营将粮食运送给最终消费者的铁路和船舶所需的能源。随着智利硝酸盐的进口和佛罗里达州开采的磷酸盐的应用，无机肥料正逐步得到推广。

High-productivity harvests are possible thanks to increasing infusions of fossil energies. Coal is used to make metallurgical coke charged into blast furnaces, and cast iron is converted to steel in open hearth furnaces (see chapter 3). Steel is needed for agricultural machinery as well as for making steam engines, rails, wagons, locomotives, and ships. Coal also powers steam engines and produces the heat and electricity required to manufacture plows, drills, harvesters (also the first combines), wagons, and silos, and to operate railroads and ships that distribute the grain to its final consumers. Inorganic fertilizers are making their first inroads with the imports of Chilean nitrates and with the application of phosphates mined in Florida.

2021年，堪萨斯州是美国最大的小麦产区，因此我们来到了阿肯色河谷。在这个美国小麦产区的核心地带，如今的农场规模通常是一百年前的三到四倍[10] ——然而，大部分田间作业却只由一两个人操作大型机械完成。美国农业部于1961年停止统计役畜数量，如今田间作业主要由动力强劲的拖拉机主导——许多型号的拖拉机马力超过400匹，配备八个巨型轮胎——牵引着诸如钢犁（带有十几个犁铧）、播种机和施肥机等宽大农具。[11]

In 2021, Kansas is the country’s leading wheat-growing state and so we move to the Arkansas River Valley. In this heart of American wheat country, farms are now commonly three to four times larger than they were a century ago[10]—and yet most of the field work is done by only one or two people operating large machinery. The US Department of Agriculture stopped counting draft animals in 1961, and field work is now dominated by powerful tractors—many models have more than 400 horsepower and eight giant tires—pulling wide implements such as steel plows (with a dozen or more shares), seeders, and fertilizer applicators.[11]

种子来自经过认证的种植者，幼苗会获得最佳量的无机肥料——尤其是大量的氮肥（以氨或尿素的形式施用）——并得到针对性的虫害防治。真菌和杂草会抑制小麦生长。收割和同时进行的脱粒工作由大型联合收割机完成，这些联合收割机将谷物直接装上卡车，运往粮仓储存，然后销往全国各地，或出口到亚洲或非洲。如今，每公顷小麦的生产仅需不到两小时的人工劳动（而1801年则需要150小时），每公顷产量约为3.5吨，这意味着每公斤谷物的生产时间不到两秒。[12]

Seed comes from certified growers, and young plants receive optimum amounts of inorganic fertilizers—above all, plenty of nitrogen applied as ammonia or urea—and targeted protection against insects, fungi, and competing weeds. Harvesting, and the concurrent threshing, is done by large combines that transfer grain directly to trucks to be transported to storage silos and sold around the country, or shipped to Asia or Africa. Producing wheat now takes less than two hours of human labor per hectare (compared to 150 hours in 1801), and with yields of around 3.5 tons per hectare this translates to less than two seconds per kilogram of grain.[12]

如今，许多人赞叹现代计算机（“数据量如此庞大”）或电信（“成本如此低廉”）的性能提升——但收成呢？短短两个世纪，生产一公斤美国小麦所需的人力就从十分钟缩短到不到两秒。这就是我们现代世界的真实运作方式。正如前文所述，我同样可以对中国或印度的水稻进行类似的惊人重建，展现劳动力投入的减少、产量的提高和生产率的飙升。虽然时间跨度不同，但相对收益却大同小异。

Many people nowadays admiringly quote the performance gains of modern computing (“so much data”) or telecommunication (“so much cheaper”)—but what about harvests? In two centuries, the human labor to produce a kilogram of American wheat was reduced from 10 minutes to less than two seconds. This is how our modern world really works. And as mentioned, I could have done similarly stunning reconstructions of falling labor inputs, rising yields, and soaring productivity for Chinese or Indian rice. The time frames would be different but the relative gains would be similar.

大多数令人赞叹且无疑意义非凡的技术进步，彻底改变了工业、交通、通讯和日常生活，如果超过80%的人口必须留在农村才能生产每日所需的面包（1800年美国农民人口比例为83%）或米饭（1800年日本近90%的人口居住在农村），那么这些进步都将不复存在。通往现代世界的道路始于廉价的钢犁和无机肥料，我们需要更深入地探究这些不可或缺的投入，正是它们让我们理所当然地拥有了食物充足的文明。

Most of the admired and undoubtedly remarkable technical advances that have transformed industries, transportation, communication, and everyday living would have been impossible if more than 80 percent of all people had to remain in the countryside in order to produce their daily bread (the share of the US population who were farmers in 1800 was 83 percent) or their daily bowl of rice (in Japan, close to 90 percent of people lived in villages in 1800). The road to the modern world began with inexpensive steel plows and inorganic fertilizers, and a closer look is needed to explain these indispensable inputs that have made us take a well-fed civilization for granted.

放入什么

What goes in

前工业时代的农业依靠人力和畜力，使用简单的木制和铁制工具，以太阳为唯一的能源。如今，和以往一样，没有太阳能驱动的光合作用，任何作物都无法收获；但如果没有直接或间接的化石能源投入，就无法实现以最少的劳动力投入获得如此高的产量，从而以空前的低成本耕作。这些人为能源投入中，有些来自电力，电力可以由煤炭、天然气或可再生能源产生；但大部分是液态和气态碳氢化合物，作为机器燃料和原材料供应。

Preindustrial farming done with human and animal labor and with simple wooden and iron tools had the Sun as the only source of energy. Today, as ever, no harvests would be possible without Sun-driven photosynthesis, but the high yields produced with minimal labor inputs and hence with unprecedented low costs would be impossible without direct and indirect infusions of fossil energies. Some of these anthropogenic energy inputs are coming from electricity, which can be generated from coal or natural gas or renewables, but most of them are liquid and gaseous hydrocarbons supplied as machine fuels and raw materials.

机器直接消耗化石能源，例如柴油或汽油，用于田间作业，包括从井中抽取灌溉用水、作物加工和烘干、用卡车、火车和驳船在国内运输收成，以及用大型散货船的货舱出口海外。制造这些机器的间接能源消耗则复杂得多，因为化石燃料和电力不仅用于制造钢铁、橡胶、塑料、玻璃和电子产品，还用于组装这些原材料，以制造拖拉机、农具、联合收割机、卡车、粮食烘干机和筒仓。[13]

Machines consume fossil energies directly as diesel or gasoline for field operations including the pumping of irrigation water from wells, for crop processing and drying, for transporting the harvests within the country by trucks, trains, and barges, and for overseas exports in the holds of large bulk carriers. Indirect energy use in making those machines is far more complex, as fossil fuels and electricity go into making not only the steel, rubber, plastics, glass, and electronics but also assembling these inputs to make tractors, implements, combines, trucks, grain dryers, and silos.[13]

但制造和驱动农用机械所需的能量与生产农用化学品所需的能量相比，简直微不足道。现代农业需要杀菌剂和杀虫剂来最大限度地减少作物损失，还需要除草剂来防止杂草与作物争夺可利用的养分和水分。所有这些都是高能耗产品，但它们的用量相对较小（每公顷仅几分之一公斤）。[14]相比之下，提供植物必需的三种主要营养元素——氮、磷、钾——的肥料，虽然单位最终产品所需的能量较少，但为了确保作物高产，需要大量施用。[15]

But the energy required to make and to power farm machinery is dwarfed by the energy requirements of producing agrochemicals. Modern farming requires fungicides and insecticides to minimize crop losses, and herbicides to prevent weeds from competing for the available plant nutrients and water. All of these are highly energy-intensive products but they are applied in relatively small quantities (just fractions of a kilogram per hectare).[14] In contrast, fertilizers that supply the three essential plant macronutrients—nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium—require less energy per unit of the final product but are needed in large quantities to ensure high crop yields.[15]

钾肥的生产成本最低，只需从露天或地下矿山开采氯化钾（KCl）即可。磷肥的生产始于磷酸盐的开采，然后经过加工制成合成过磷酸钙化合物。氨是所有合成氮肥的起始原料。每季高产小麦和水稻，以及许多蔬菜，每公顷需要超过100公斤（有时高达200公斤）的氮肥，如此高的需求使得氮肥的合成成为现代农业中最重要的间接能源投入。[16]

Potassium is the least costly to produce, as all it takes is potash (KCl) from surface or underground mines. Phosphatic fertilizers begin with the excavation of phosphates, followed by their processing to yield synthetic superphosphate compounds. Ammonia is the starting compound for making all synthetic nitrogenous fertilizers. Every crop of high-yielding wheat and rice, as well as of many vegetables, requires more than 100 (sometimes as much as 200) kilograms of nitrogen per hectare, and these high needs make the synthesis of nitrogenous fertilizers the most important indirect energy input in modern farming.[16]

氮元素之所以如此重要，是因为它存在于每一个活细胞中：它存在于叶绿素中，叶绿素的激发驱动着光合作用；它存在于核酸DNA和RNA中，这些核酸储存和加工氮元素。所有遗传信息；以及构成我们组织生长和维持所需所有蛋白质的氨基酸，都离不开氮。这种元素含量丰富——它几乎占大气层的80%，生物体生活在其中——然而，它却是作物产量和人类生长发育的关键限制因素。这是生物圈的一大悖论，其解释很简单：氮在大气中以非活性分子（N₂）的形式存在，只有少数自然过程能够打破两个氮原子之间的化学键，使氮元素能够形成活性化合物。[17]

Nitrogen is needed in such great quantities because it is in every living cell: it is in chlorophyll, whose excitation powers photosynthesis; in the nucleic acids DNA and RNA, which store and process all genetic information; and in amino acids, which make up all the proteins required for the growth and maintenance of our tissues. The element is abundant—it makes up nearly 80 percent of the atmosphere, organisms live submerged in it—and yet it is a key limiting factor in crop productivity as well as in human growth. This is one of the great paradoxical realities of the biosphere and its explanation is simple: nitrogen exists in the atmosphere as a non-reactive molecule (N2), and only a few natural processes can split the bond between the two nitrogen atoms and make the element available to form reactive compounds.[17]

闪电确实能做到这一点：它产生氮氧化物，这些氮氧化物溶解在雨水中形成硝酸盐，然后森林、田野和草原就能从天而降获得肥料——但显然，这种自然输入量太少，不足以养活全球近80亿人口。闪电在极高温度和压力下所能做到的事情，一种酶（固氮酶）在正常条件下也能做到：它由与豆科植物（豆类以及某些树木）根系相关的细菌产生，或由土壤或植物体内自由生活的细菌产生。附着在豆科植物根系上的细菌负责大部分的自然固氮作用——即分解惰性氮气（N₂ ）并将氮转化为氨（NH₃ ）。氨是一种高活性化合物，很容易转化为可溶性硝酸盐，可以为植物提供所需的氮，而植物则需要利用自身合成的有机酸。

Lightning will do it: it produces nitrogen oxides, which dissolve in rain and form nitrates, and then forests, fields, and grasslands get fertilizer from above—but obviously this natural input is too small to produce crop harvests to feed the world’s nearly 8 billion people. What lightning can do with tremendous temperatures and pressures, an enzyme (nitrogenase) can do in normal conditions: it is produced by bacteria associated with the roots of leguminous plants (pulses, as well as some trees) or that live freely in soil or in plants. Bacteria attached to the roots of leguminous plants are responsible for most natural nitrogen fixation—that is, for the cleavage of non-reactive N2 and for the incorporation of nitrogen into ammonia (NH3), a highly reactive compound that is readily converted into soluble nitrates and can supply plants with their nitrogen needs in return for organic acids synthesized by the plants.

因此，包括大豆、菜豆、豌豆、扁豆和花生在内的豆科粮食作物能够自行固氮，苜蓿、三叶草和野豌豆等豆科覆盖作物也能做到这一点。但是，主粮、油料作物（大豆和花生除外）以及块茎作物都无法做到这一点。它们要想利用豆科作物的固氮能力，唯一的办法就是与苜蓿、三叶草或野豌豆轮作，先种植这些固氮作物几个月，然后将其翻耕入土，这样土壤就能补充活性氮，供后续种植的小麦、水稻或马铃薯吸收。[18]在传统农业中，增加土壤氮储备的唯一其他方法是收集和施用人畜粪便。但这本身就是一种费力且效率低下的方法。提供营养。这些废弃物氮含量很低，而且容易挥发损失（液体转化为气体——粪便散发的氨气味可能非常刺鼻）。

As a result, leguminous food crops, including soybeans, beans, peas, lentils, and peanuts, are able to provide (fix) their own nitrogen supply, as can such leguminous cover crops as alfalfa, clovers, and vetches. But no staple grains, no oil crops (except for soybeans and peanuts), and no tubers can do that. The only way for them to benefit from the nitrogen-fixing abilities of legumes is to rotate them with alfalfa, clovers, or vetches, grow these nitrogen fixers for a few months, and then plow them under so the soils are replenished with reactive nitrogen to be picked up by the succeeding wheat, rice, or potatoes.[18] In traditional agricultures, the only other option to enrich soil nitrogen stores was to collect and apply human and animal wastes. But this is an inherently laborious and inefficient way to supply the nutrient. These wastes have very low nitrogen content and they are subject to volatilization losses (the conversion of liquids to gases—the ammonia smell from manure can be overpowering).

在工业化之前的耕作方式中，农作物废料必须在村庄、城镇和城市中收集起来，堆放在堆肥堆或粪坑中进行发酵，然后由于氮含量低，大量施用于田地，通常每公顷10吨，有时甚至高达30吨（后者相当于25-30辆小型欧洲汽车的重量），以补充所需的氮肥。毫不奇怪，这通常是传统农业中最耗时的工作，至少占耕作中所有（人力和畜力）劳动的五分之一，甚至高达三分之一。有机废料的回收利用几乎不是著名小说家关注的话题，但始终坚持现实主义的埃米尔·左拉却在描写年轻的巴黎画家克劳德时，敏锐地捕捉到了它的重要性。克劳德“非常喜欢粪便”。克劳德自告奋勇地将“市场上的残渣，从那张巨大的桌子上掉下来的垃圾，扔进坑里，这些残渣仍然充满生命力，回到了蔬菜先前发芽的地方……它们再次长成肥沃的作物，又一次蔓延到市场广场上。巴黎腐烂了一切，又将一切归还给土壤，而土壤从未厌倦地修复死亡的蹂躏。” [19]

In preindustrial cropping, the wastes had to be collected in villages, towns, and cities, fermented in heaps or pits and—because of their low nitrogen content—applied to fields in massive amounts, commonly 10 tons per hectare but sometimes up to 30 tons (the latter mass being equivalent to 25–30 small European cars), in order to provide the needed nitrogen. Not surprisingly, this was commonly the most time-consuming task in traditional farming, claiming at least a fifth, and as much as a third, of all (human and animal) labor in cropping. Recycling organic wastes is hardly a topic addressed by famous novelists, but Émile Zola, always a complete realist, captured its importance when he described Claude, a young Parisian painter who “had quite a liking for manure.” Claude volunteers to toss into the pit “the scourings of markets, the refuse that fell from that colossal table, remained full of life, and returned to the spot where the vegetables had previously sprouted . . . They rose again in fertile crops, and once more went to spread themselves out upon the market square. Paris rotted everything, and returned everything to the soil, which never wearied of repairing the ravages of death.”[19]

然而，这背后付出了多么沉重的人力代价！直到19世纪，智利硝酸盐（第一种无机氮肥）的开采和出口才开始打破氮肥对提高作物产量的巨大阻碍。1909年，弗里茨·哈伯发明了氨合成法，并迅速将其商业化（氨于1913年首次出口），这一障碍才被彻底打破。但随后的产量增长缓慢，氮肥的广泛应用直到二战后才得以实现。[20] 20世纪60年代引进的高产小麦和水稻新品种，如果没有合成氮肥，就无法充分发挥其产量潜力。而被称为“绿色革命”的巨大生产力转变，也离不开作物改良和氮肥施用量的提高。[21]

But at what cost of human toil! This great nitrogen barrier to higher crop yields was nudged only during the 19th century with the mining and export of Chilean nitrates, the first inorganic nitrogenous fertilizer. The barrier was then broken decisively with the invention of ammonia synthesis by Fritz Haber in 1909 and with its rapid commercialization (ammonia was first shipped in 1913), but subsequent production grew slowly and the widespread application of nitrogenous fertilizers had to wait until after the Second World War.[20] New high-yielding varieties of wheat and rice introduced during the 1960s could not express their full yield potential without synthetic nitrogenous fertilizers. And the great productivity shift known as the Green Revolution could not have taken place without this combination of better crops and higher nitrogen applications.[21]

自20世纪70年代以来，氮肥的合成无疑是农业能源补贴中的重中之重——但只有详细考察各种常见食品的生产所需能量，才能揭示这种依赖的全貌。我选择了其中三种作为例证，因为它们在营养方面占据主导地位。面包数千年来一直是欧洲文明的主食。由于宗教禁止食用猪肉和牛肉，鸡肉是唯一一种普遍受到青睐的肉类。而没有任何其他蔬菜（尽管从植物学角度来说是一种水果）的年产量能超过番茄，如今番茄不仅在大田种植，而且越来越多地在塑料或玻璃温室中种植。

Since the 1970s, the synthesis of nitrogenous fertilizers has undoubtedly been the primus inter pares among agricultural energy subsidies—but the full scale of this dependence is only revealed by looking at detailed accounts of the energy required to produce various common foodstuffs. I have chosen three of them to use as examples, and I picked them because of their nutritional dominance. Bread has been the staple of European civilization for millennia. Given the religious proscriptions on the consumption of pork and beef, chicken is the only universally favored meat.
