A new, much larger, ammonia factory was completed in 1917 in Leuna, but it did little to prevent Germany’s defeat. The postwar expansion of ammonia synthesis proceeded despite the economic crisis of the 1930s, and continued during the Second World War, but by 1950 synthetic ammonia was still far less common than animal manures.[18]

接下来的二十年里，氨的产量增长了八倍，达到每年3000多万吨。这得益于合成肥料推动了绿色革命（始于20世纪60年代）。绿色革命推广了新的优质小麦和水稻品种，这些品种在充足的氮肥供应下，产量达到了前所未有的高度。这一增长背后的关键创新是利用天然气作为氢气来源，以及引入高效离心式压缩机和更好的催化剂。[19]

The next two decades saw an eightfold increase of ammonia production to just over 30 million tons a year as synthetic fertilizer enabled the Green Revolution (starting during the 1960s)—the adoption of new superior wheat and rice varieties that, when supplied with adequate nitrogen, produced unprecedented yields. The key innovations behind this rise were the use of natural gas as the source of hydrogen, and the introduction of efficient centrifugal compressors and better catalysts.[19]

随后，如同许多其他现代工业发展案例一样，后毛泽东时代的中国走在了前列。毛泽东造成了历史上最致命的饥荒（1958-1961年），1976年他去世时，中国的人均粮食供应量几乎与他1949年宣布建立共产主义国家时一样糟糕。[20] 1972年尼克松总统访华后，中国达成的第一笔重大商业交易是向德克萨斯州的MW Kellogg公司订购13套当时世界上最先进的氨尿素装置。[21]到1984年，中国取消了城市粮食配给制，到2000年，其人均日均粮食供应量超过了日本。[22]实现这一目标的唯一途径是突破中国的氮肥瓶颈，并将年粮食产量提高到6.5亿吨以上。

Then, as in so many other instances of modern industrial development, post-Mao China took the lead. Mao was responsible for the deadliest famine in history (1958–1961), and when he died in 1976 the country’s per capita food supply was hardly better than when he had proclaimed the existence of the communist state in 1949.[20] China’s first major business deal to follow President Nixon’s trip to Beijing in 1972 was an order for 13 of the world’s most advanced ammonia-urea plants from M. W. Kellogg of Texas.[21] By 1984 the country abolished urban food rationing, and by the year 2000 its average daily per capita food supply was higher than Japan’s.[22] The only way to make this happen was by breaking the country’s nitrogen barrier and raising the annual grain harvest to more than 650 million tons a year.

对近期中国农业氮素流动情况的最佳研究表明，该国作物可利用的养分约有60%来自合成氨：五分之三的作物都依赖合成氨。因此，中国人口依赖于这种化合物的合成。[23]全球平均水平约为50%。这种依赖性足以证明，哈伯-博施法合成氨或许是历史上最重大的技术进步。正如威廉·克鲁克斯正确指出的那样，其他发明提升了我们的舒适、便利、奢华、财富或生产力，还有一些发明拯救了我们免于过早死亡和慢性疾病——但如果没有氨的合成，我们就无法确保当今和未来很大一部分人口的生存。[24]

The best account of recent nitrogen flows in China’s agriculture shows that about 60 percent of the nutrient available to the country’s crops comes from synthetic ammonia: feeding three out of five of the Chinese population thus depends on the synthesis of this compound.[23] The corresponding global mean is about 50 percent. This dependence easily justifies calling the Haber-Bosch synthesis of ammonia perhaps the most momentous technical advance in history. Other inventions, as William Crookes correctly judged, minister to our comforts, convenience, luxury, wealth, or productivity, and others yet save our lives from premature death and chronic disease—but without the synthesis of ammonia, we could not ensure the very survival of large shares of today’s and tomorrow’s population.[24]

我必须补充一点，人类中有50%依赖氨的说法并非绝对准确。在目前的饮食和耕作方式下，合成氮肥养活了半数人类——或者说，在其他条件相同的情况下，如果没有合成氮肥，世界上一半的人口将无法生存。但如果富裕国家都转向以素食为主的印度饮食，这个比例就会降低；如果全世界都像中国人一样饮食，这个比例就会升高，更不用说全民采用美国饮食了。[25]我们还可以通过减少食物浪费（正如我们之前看到的）和更有效地利用肥料来降低对氮肥的依赖。

I hasten to add that the 50 percent of humanity dependent on ammonia is not an immutable approximation. Given prevailing diets and farming practices, synthetic nitrogen feeds half of humanity—or, everything else being equal, half of the world’s population could not be sustained without synthetic nitrogenous fertilizers. But the share would be lower if the affluent world converted to the largely meatless Indian diet, and it would be higher if the entire world ate as well as the Chinese do today, to say nothing about the universal adoption of the American diet.[25] We could also reduce our dependence on nitrogenous fertilizers by cutting our food waste (as we saw earlier) and by using the fertilizers more efficiently.

全球约80%的氨产量用于农作物施肥；其余部分用于生产硝酸、炸药、火箭推进剂、染料、纤维以及窗户和地板清洁剂。[26]采取适当的预防措施并使用专用设备后，氨可以直接施用于田地；[27]但这种化合物主要用作生产固体和液体氮肥的必要原料。尿素是含氮量最高的固体肥料（46%），占据主导地位。[28]近年来，尿素约占全球农田氮肥施用量的55%，并在亚洲广泛用于支持中国和印度（世界上人口最多的两个国家）的水稻和小麦收成，并确保其他五个人口超过1亿的亚洲国家的丰收。[29]

About 80 percent of global ammonia production is used to fertilize crops; the rest is used to make nitric acid, explosives, rocket propellants, dyes, fibers, and window and floor cleaners.[26] With proper precautions and special equipment, ammonia can be applied directly to fields;[27] but the compound is mostly used as the indispensable feedstock for producing solid and liquid nitrogenous fertilizers. Urea, the solid fertilizer with the highest nitrogen content (46 percent), dominates.[28] Recently, it has accounted for about 55 percent of all nitrogen applied to the world’s fields, and it is widely used in Asia to support the rice and wheat harvests of China and India—the world’s two most populous nations—and to guarantee good yields in five other Asian countries with more than 100 million inhabitants.[29]

不太重要的氮肥包括硝酸铵、硫酸铵和硝酸铵钙，以及各种液态氮肥溶液。氮肥一旦施用于田间，几乎无法控制其因挥发造成的自然损失。（来自氨化合物）、淋溶（硝酸盐易溶于水）和反硝化作用（细菌驱动的硝酸盐在空气中转化为氮分子）。[30]

Less important nitrogenous fertilizers include ammonium nitrate, ammonium sulfate, and calcium ammonium nitrate, as well as various liquid solutions. Once the nitrogen fertilizers are applied to fields, it is almost impossible to control their natural losses due to volatilization (from ammonia compounds), leaching (nitrates are readily soluble in water), and denitrification (the bacteria-driven conversion of nitrates back to nitrogen molecules in the air).[30]

目前，解决田间氮素流失问题的有效直接方案只有两种：一是施用昂贵的缓释肥料；二是更实际的做法是转向精准农业，根据土壤分析结果按需施肥。[31]如前所述，间接措施——包括提高食品价格和减少肉类消费——可能有效，但并不受欢迎。因此，这些方案的任何切实可行的组合都不太可能从根本上改变全球氮肥的消耗量。目前，全球每年合成约1.5亿吨氨，其中约80%用作肥料。这些肥料中近60%施用于亚洲，约四分之一施用于欧洲和北美，不到5%施用于非洲。[32]大多数富裕国家当然可以而且应该减少其过高的施肥量（它们的人均粮食供应量已经过高），而中国和印度这两个肥料消耗大国有很多机会减少其过量的肥料施用。

There are now only two effective direct solutions to field losses of nitrogen: the spreading of expensive slow-release compounds; and, more practically, turning to precision farming and applying fertilizers only as needed based on analyses of the soil.[31] As already noted, indirect measures—including higher food prices and reduced meat consumption—could be effective but are not highly popular. As a result, it is unlikely that any realistically conceivable combination of these solutions can bring about a radical change to the global consumption of nitrogenous fertilizers. About 150 megatons of ammonia are now synthesized annually, with about 80 percent used as fertilizer. Nearly 60 percent of that fertilizer is applied in Asia, about a quarter in Europe and North America, and less than 5 percent in Africa.[32] Most rich countries certainly could, and should, pull back on their high application rates (their average per capita food supply is already too high), and China and India—two heavy users—have many opportunities to reduce their excessive fertilizer applications.

但非洲作为人口增长最快的洲，仍然缺乏这种营养物质，并且是重要的粮食进口地区。非洲提高粮食自给率的希望寄托于增加氮肥的使用：毕竟，非洲大陆近期的氨肥使用量还不到欧洲平均水平的三分之一。[33]提高氮肥供应的最佳（也是人们长期以来寻求的）解决方案是赋予非豆科植物固氮能力，但基因工程尚未实现这一目标；而另一种较为温和的选择——用固氮细菌接种种子——虽然是近期的一项创新，但其最终的商业化规模仍不明朗。

But Africa, the continent with the fastest-growing population, remains deprived of the nutrient and is a substantial food importer. Any hope for its greater food self-sufficiency rests on the increased use of nitrogen: after all, the continent’s recent usage of ammonia has been less than a third of the European mean.[33] The best (and long-sought) solution to boost nitrogen supply would be to endow non-leguminous plants with nitrogen-fixing capabilities, a promise genetic engineering is yet to deliver on, while a less radical option—inoculating seeds with a nitrogen-fixing bacterium—is a recent innovation whose eventual commercial extent is still unclear.

塑料：种类繁多、用途广泛、但也令人头疼

Plastics: diverse, useful, troublesome

塑料是一大类合成（或半合成）有机材料，它们的共同特性是易于成型（模塑）。塑料的合成始于单体，单体是简单的分子，可以……碳氢化合物通过连接形成长链或支链，从而构成聚合物。两种关键单体乙烯和丙烯是通过烃类原料的蒸汽裂解（加热至750–950°C）制得的，烃类也为后续合成反应提供能量。[34]塑料的可塑性使其可以通过浇铸、压制或挤出成型，其形状范围广泛，从薄膜到重型管道，从轻盈的瓶子到坚固耐用的大型垃圾容器，应有尽有。

Plastics are a large group of synthetic (or semisynthetic) organic materials whose common quality is that they are fit for forming (molding). Synthesis of plastics begins with monomers, simple molecules that can be bonded in long chains or branches to make polymers. The two key monomers, ethylene and propylene, are produced by the steam cracking (heating to 750–950°C) of hydrocarbon feedstocks, and hydrocarbons also energize subsequent syntheses.[34] The malleability of plastics makes it possible to form them by casting, pressing, or extruding, and they create shapes ranging from thin film to heavy-duty pipes and from feather-light bottles to massive and sturdy waste containers.

全球塑料产量一直以热塑性塑料为主——这类聚合物加热后易软化，冷却后又会变硬。低密度和高密度聚乙烯（PE）目前占全球塑料聚合物总量的20%以上，聚丙烯（PP）约占15%，聚氯乙烯（PVC）超过10%。[35]与之相反，热固性塑料（包括聚氨酯、聚酰亚胺、三聚氰胺和脲醛树脂）加热后不易软化。

Global output has been dominated by thermoplastics—polymers that soften readily when heated and harden again when cooled. Low- and high-density polyethylene (PE) now accounts for more than 20 percent of the world’s plastic polymers, polypropylene (PP) for about 15 percent, and polyvinyl chloride (PVC) for more than 10 percent.[35] In contrast, thermoset plastics (including polyurethanes, polyimides, melamine, and urea-formaldehyde) resist softening when heated.

一些热塑性塑料兼具低比重（轻质）和相当高的硬度（耐用性）。耐用铝的重量仅为碳钢的三分之一，而聚氯乙烯（PVC）的密度不到钢的20%，聚丙烯（PP）的密度不到钢的12%；结构钢的极限抗拉强度为400兆帕，而聚苯乙烯的极限抗拉强度为100兆帕，是木材或玻璃的两倍，仅比铝低10%。[36]

Some thermoplastics combine low specific gravity (light weight) with fairly high hardness (durability). Durable aluminum weighs only a third as much as carbon steel, but PVC density is less than 20 percent and PP less than 12 percent compared to steel; and while the ultimate tensile strength of structural steel is 400 megapascals, that of polystyrene is, at 100 megapascals, twice that of wood or glass and only 10 percent less than that of aluminum.[36]

热塑性塑料兼具轻质高强的优点，使其成为重型管道和法兰、防滑表面以及化学储罐等应用领域的首选材料。热塑性聚合物已广泛应用于汽车内外饰（PP保险杠、PVC仪表板和汽车零部件、聚碳酸酯前大灯透镜）；轻质耐高温或阻燃热塑性塑料（聚碳酸酯、PVC/丙烯酸酯混合物）在现代飞机内饰中占据主导地位；碳纤维增强塑料（复合材料）目前也用于制造飞机机身。[37]

This combination of low weight and high strength has made thermoplastics the preferred choice for such applications as heavy-duty pipes and flanges, anti-skid surfaces, and chemical tanks. Thermoplastic polymers have found widespread uses in car interiors and exteriors (PP bumpers, PVC dashboards and car parts, polycarbonate headlight lenses); light high-temperature or flame-retardant thermoplastics (polycarbonate, PVC/acrylic blends) dominate the interiors of modern aircraft; and carbon-fiber reinforced plastics (composite materials) are now used for building aircraft airframes.[37]

最早的塑料，尤其是由硝酸纤维素和樟脑制成的赛璐珞（后来成为电影工业的主要易燃材料，直到20世纪50年代才被取代），在19世纪最后三十年间少量生产。但第一种热固性塑料（模塑温度为150-160°C）是由在纽约工作的比利时化学家利奥·亨德里克·贝克兰于1907年制备的。[ 38]成立于1910年的通用胶木公司是第一家工业生产塑料制品的公司，这种塑料被模制成各种产品，从电绝缘体到黑色旋转拨号电话，应有尽有。二战期间，这种塑料还被用于制造轻型武器的部件。与此同时，玻璃纸是由雅克·布兰登伯格于1908年发明的。

The first plastics, most notably celluloid made from cellulose nitrate and camphor (later the highly flammable mainstay of the film industry, displaced only during the 1950s), were produced in small amounts during the last three decades of the 19th century, but the first thermoset material (molded at 150–160°C) was prepared in 1907 by Leo Hendrik Baekeland, a Belgian chemist working in New York.[38] His General Bakelite Company, founded in 1910, was the first industrial producer of a plastic that was molded into pieces ranging from electric insulators to black rotary dial telephones and, during the Second World War, used for parts in lightweight weapons. Meanwhile, cellophane was invented in 1908 by Jacques Brandenberger.

在两次世界大战之间的时期，聚氯乙烯（PVC）首次实现了大规模合成。PVC早在1838年就被发现，但此前从未在实验室外使用过。美国的杜邦公司、英国的帝国化学工业公司（ICI）和德国的法本公司资助并成功开展了致力于发现新型塑料材料的研究。[39]二战前，这些研究成果促成了醋酸纤维素（现用于吸水布和湿巾）、氯丁橡胶（合成橡胶）、聚酯（用于织物和室内装潢）、聚甲基丙烯酸甲酯（又称有机玻璃，由于新冠疫情期间隔板和防护罩的重新普及，其应用更加广泛）的商业化生产。尼龙自1938年开始生产（牙刷刷毛和丝袜是其最初的商业产品；如今，尼龙的应用范围从渔网到降落伞无所不包），正如前文所述，特氟龙（一种用途广泛的不粘涂层）也同样如此。苯乙烯的生产成本在 20 世纪 30 年代开始降低，现在这种材料主要以聚苯乙烯（PS）的形式用于包装材料和一次性杯盘中。

During the interwar years came the first large-scale syntheses of PVC, which was discovered as early as 1838 but never used outside a laboratory, and DuPont in the US, Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) in the UK, and IG Farben in Germany funded (very successfully) research dedicated to the discovery of new plastic materials.[39] Before the Second World War this resulted in the commercial production of cellulose acetate (now in absorbent cloths and wipes), neoprene (synthetic rubber), polyester (for fabrics and upholstery), polymethyl methacrylate (otherwise known as plexiglass, and now even more commonly used thanks to the COVID-induced resurgence of dividers and shields). Nylon has been produced since 1938 (toothbrush bristles and stockings were the first commercial products; it now goes into products ranging from fishing nets to parachutes) and—as already noted—so has Teflon, a ubiquitous non-stick coating. The affordable production of styrene also began during the 1930s, and the material is now mostly used as polystyrene, or PS, in packing materials and disposable cups and plates.

1937年，法本公司推出了聚氨酯（用于家具泡沫和绝缘材料）；帝国化学工业公司（ICI）利用高压合成聚乙烯（用于包装和绝缘材料），并于1933年开始生产甲基丙烯酸甲酯（用于粘合剂、涂料和油漆）。聚对苯二甲酸乙二醇酯（PET）——自20世纪70年代以来，以废弃饮料瓶的形式成为全球的祸害——于1941年获得专利，并自20世纪50年代初开始大规模生产（臭名昭著的PET瓶于1973年获得专利）。[40]二战后最著名的新增产品包括聚碳酸酯（用于光学镜片、窗户和硬质盖板）、聚酰亚胺（用于医用导管）、液晶聚合物（主要用于电子产品），以及杜邦公司著名的商标产品，例如Tyvek®（1955年）、Lycra®（1959年）和Kevlar®（1971年）。[41]到20世纪末，全球市场上已有50种不同的塑料，这种新的多样性——以及对最常用塑料日益增长的需求——所用化合物（PE、PP、PVC 和 PET）导致需求呈指数级增长。

IG Farben introduced polyurethanes in 1937 (furniture foams, insulation); ICI used very high pressure to synthesize polyethylene (used in packaging and insulation) and began producing methyl methacrylate (for adhesives, coatings, and paints) in 1933. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET)—since the 1970s the scourge of the planet in the form of discarded drink bottles—was patented in 1941 and mass-produced since the early 1950s (the infernal PET bottle was patented in 1973).[40] The best-known post–Second World War additions include polycarbonates (for optical lenses, windows, rigid covers), polyimide (for medical tubing), liquid crystal polymers (above all for electronics), and such famous DuPont trademarks as Tyvek® (1955), Lycra® (1959), and Kevlar® (1971).[41] By the end of the 20th century, 50 different kinds of plastics were on the global market, and this new diversity—together with rising demand for the most commonly used compounds (PE, PP, PVC, and PET)—led to exponential growth in demand.

全球塑料产量从1925年的约2万吨增长到1950年的200万吨，到2000年达到1.5亿吨，到2019年达到约3.7亿吨。[42]要体会塑料材料在我们日常生活中的无处不在，最好的方法就是留意我们每天有多少次用手触摸塑料、用眼睛观察塑料、用身体倚靠塑料、用脚踩在塑料上：你可能会惊讶于这种接触的频率之高！就在我敲下这些文字的时候：我右手掌下的戴尔笔记本电脑键盘和无线鼠标都是用丙烯腈-丁二烯-苯乙烯共聚物（ABS）制成的；我坐在一个聚酯纤维面料的转椅上；椅子的尼龙轮子放在一块覆盖着聚酯纤维地毯的聚碳酸酯地毯保护垫上……

Global production rose from only about 20,000 tons in 1925 to 2 million tons by 1950, 150 million tons by the year 2000, and about 370 million tons by 2019.[42] The best way to appreciate the ubiquity of plastic materials in our daily lives is to note how many times a day our hands touch, our eyes see, our bodies rest on, and our feet tread on a plastic: you might be astonished at the frequency of such encounters! As I am typing this: the keys of my Dell laptop and a wireless mouse under my right palm are made of acrylonitrile butadiene styrene, I sit on a swivel chair upholstered in a polyester fabric, and its nylon wheels rest on a polycarbonate carpet protection mat that covers a polyester carpet . . .

塑料行业最初以供应小型工业零件（1916 年劳斯莱斯汽车的变速杆旋钮是第一个应用案例）和各种家用物品起家，如今已极大地扩展了这两个最初的商业领域（最显著的是消费电子产品，每年新增数十亿件依赖塑料的产品），并增加了大规模应用，从汽车车身和飞机的完整内饰到大直径管道，不一而足。

An industry that started by supplying small industrial parts (a gear-lever knob in the 1916 Rolls-Royce was the first application) and various household items has vastly expanded those two original commercial niches (most prominently with consumer electronics adding billions of new plastic-dependent items every year) and has added mass-scale applications ranging from car bodies and complete interiors of airplanes to large-diameter pipes.

但塑料在医疗保健领域，尤其是在传染病的医院治疗中，发挥着不可或缺的作用。现代生活从产房开始，到重症监护室结束，都离不开塑料制品。[43]而那些此前对塑料在现代医疗保健中的作用一无所知的人，则因新冠疫情而得到了深刻的教训。这场疫情以各种极端的方式让我们认识到这一点：北美和欧洲的医生和护士个人防护装备（PPE）——包括一次性手套、口罩、防护面罩、帽子、防护服和鞋套——严重短缺；各国政府竞相从中国空运数量有限（且价格高昂）的物资。而西方个人防护装备生产商为了削减成本，已将大部分生产线转移到中国，造成了危险却完全可以避免的物资短缺。[44]

But plastics have found their most indispensable roles in health care in general and in the hospital treatment of infectious diseases in particular. Modern life now begins (in maternity wards) and ends (in intensive care units) surrounded by plastic items.[43] And those people who had no prior understanding of plastics’ role in modern health care got their lesson thanks to COVID-19. The pandemic has taught us this in often drastic ways, as doctors and nurses in North America and Europe ran out of personal protective equipment (PPE)—disposable gloves, masks, shields, hats, gowns, and booties—and as governments outbid each other in order to airlift limited (and highly overpriced) supplies from China, to which the Western producers of PPE, obsessed with cutting costs, had relocated most of their production lines, creating dangerous yet entirely avoidable supply shortages.[44]

医院里的塑料制品主要由各种PVC制成：软管（用于喂食病人、输送氧气和监测血压）、导管、静脉输液容器等。血袋、无菌包装、各种托盘和盆、便盆和床栏、保温毯以及数不胜数的实验室器皿。如今，超过四分之一的医疗保健产品的主要成分都是聚氯乙烯（PVC）。在现代家庭中，PVC 也存在于墙体和屋顶防水层、窗框、百叶窗、软管、电缆绝缘层、电子元件、种类繁多的办公用品和玩具中——甚至还存在于用于购买上述所有物品的信用卡中。[45]

Plastic items in hospitals are made above all from different kinds of PVC: flexible tubes (used for feeding patients, delivering oxygen, and monitoring blood pressure), catheters, intravenous containers, blood bags, sterile packaging, assorted trays and basins, bedpans and bed rails, thermal blankets, and countless pieces of labware. PVC is now the primary component in more than a quarter of all health-care products, and in modern homes it is present in wall and roof membranes, window frames, blinds, hoses, cable insulation, electronic components, a still-growing array of office supplies, and toys—and as credit cards used to purchase all of the above.[45]

近年来，人们对陆地塑料污染问题日益关注，对海洋、沿海水域和海滩的塑料污染问题则更为严重。我将在环境章节中详细讨论这个问题，但这种不负责任的塑料倾倒行为并不能成为反对合理使用这些种类繁多且往往不可或缺的合成材料的理由。此外，就微纤维而言，许多人错误地认为海洋中微纤维主要来源于合成纺织品的磨损。这些聚合物目前占全球纤维产量的三分之二，但一项海水样本研究表明，海洋纤维主要（>90%）来源于天然物质。[46]

Recent years have seen rising concerns about plastic pollution on land and even more so in the ocean, coastal waters, and on beaches. I will return to this in the environmental chapter, but this irresponsible dumping of plastics is not an argument against the proper use of these diverse and often truly indispensable synthetic materials. Moreover, as far as microfibers go, it is wrong to assume, as so many do, that most of their presence in ocean water derives from the wear and tear of synthetic textiles. Those polymers now account for two-thirds of global fiber output, but a study of seawater samples showed that oceanic fibers are mainly (>90 percent) of natural origin.[46]

钢铁：无处不在且可回收利用

Steel: ubiquitous and recyclable

钢（用复数形式更为准确，因为种类超过3500种）是以铁（Fe）为主的合金。[47]生铁或铸铁，即高炉炼制的热金属，通常含有95%至97%的铁、1.8%至4%的碳和0.5%至3%的硅，以及微量的其他元素。[48]由于其高碳含量，生铁质地脆，延展性（拉伸能力）低，抗拉强度（抵抗拉力断裂的能力）也逊于青铜或黄铜。工业革命前的钢铁主要在亚洲和欧洲以各种手工方法生产——也就是说，生产过程总是费时费力且成本高昂——因此从未普及。[49]

Steels (the plural is more accurate as there are more than 3,500 varieties) are alloys dominated by iron (Fe).[47] Pig or cast iron, the hot metal produced by blast furnaces, is typically 95–97 percent iron, 1.8–4 percent carbon, and 0.5–3 percent silicon, with mere traces of a few other elements.[48] Its high carbon content makes it brittle, it has low ductility (the ability to stretch), and its tensile strength (resistance to breaking under tension) is inferior to that of bronze or brass. Preindustrial steel was made in Asia and in Europe by a variety of artisanal methods—that is, always laboriously and expensively—and hence it was never available for common use.[49]

现代钢材是通过降低铸铁的碳含量（碳含量降至0.08%至2.1%（重量比））制成的。钢的物理性能远胜于最坚硬的石头，也胜过其他两种最常见的金属。花岗岩的抗压强度（承受使材料缩短的载荷的能力）与钢相似，但其抗拉强度更高。强度比钢材低一个数量级：花岗岩柱的承载能力与钢材相当，但钢梁的承载能力是钢材的15-30倍。[50]钢材的典型抗拉强度约为铝的7倍，铜的近4倍；其硬度分别是铝的4倍和铜的8倍；而且钢材耐热——铝的熔点为660°C，铜为1085°C，而钢的熔点为1425°C。

Modern steels are made from cast iron by reducing its high carbon content to 0.08–2.1 percent by weight. Steel’s physical properties handily beat those of the hardest stones, as well as those of the other two most common metals. Granite has a similar compressive strength (capacity to withstand loads that shorten the material) but its tensile strength is an order of magnitude lower: granite columns bear their load as well as steel, but steel beams can bear loads 15–30 times higher.[50] Steel’s typical tensile strength is about seven times that of aluminum and nearly four times that of copper; its hardness is, respectively, four and eight times higher; and it is heat resistant—aluminum melts at 660°C, copper at 1,085°C, steel only at 1,425°C.

钢材主要分为四大类。[51]碳钢（市面上90%的钢材含碳量为0.3%至0.95%）应用广泛，从桥梁到冰箱，从齿轮到剪刀，无处不在。合金钢则添加了不同比例的一种或多种元素（最常见的是锰、镍、硅和铬，但也包括铝、钼、钛和钒），以改善其物理性能（硬度、强度、延展性）。不锈钢（含铬量为10%至20%）于1912年首次用于厨房用具，如今已广泛应用于外科器械、发动机、机械零件和建筑领域。[52]工具钢的抗拉强度比最好的结构钢高2至4倍，用于切割钢材和其他金属，制造模具（用于冲压或挤压其他金属或塑料），也用于手工切割和锤击。除某些不锈钢品种外，所有钢材都具有磁性，因此适合用于制造电机。

Steels come in four major categories.[51] Carbon steels (90 percent of all steels on the market are 0.3–0.95 percent carbon) are everywhere, from bridges to fridges and from gears to shears. Alloy steels include varying shares of one or more elements (most commonly manganese, nickel, silicon, and chromium, but also aluminum, molybdenum, titanium, and vanadium), added in order to improve their physical properties (hardness, strength, ductility). Stainless steel (10–20 percent chromium) was made for the first time only in 1912 for kitchenware, and is now widely used for surgical instruments, engines, machine parts, and in construction.[52] Tool steels have a tensile strength 2–4 times higher than the best construction steels, and they are used for cutting steel and other metals for dies (for stamping or extrusion of other metals or plastics), as well as for manual cutting and hammering. And all steels (except for some stainless varieties) are magnetic and hence suitable for making electric machinery.

钢铁决定了现代文明的面貌，并支撑着其最基本的功能。它是应用最广泛的金属，构成了当今世界无数可见和不可见的关键部件。此外，我们使用的几乎所有其他金属和非金属产品都是用钢铁制成的工具和机器进行开采、加工、成型、精加工和运输的，而当今任何一种大众交通工具都离不开钢铁。从室内到室外，从小型物品（餐具、刀具、锅碗瓢盆、厨房用具、园艺工具）到大型物品（家用电器、割草机、自行车、汽车），钢铁无处不在。

Steel determines the look of modern civilization and enables its most fundamental functions. This is the most widely used metal and it forms countless visible and invisible critical components of today’s world. Moreover, nearly all other metallic and non-metallic products we use have been extracted, processed, shaped, finished, and distributed with tools and machines made of steel, and no mode of today’s mass transportation could function without steel. Naked steel is ubiquitous inside and outside of our homes, in items small (cutlery, knives, cooking pots, pans, kitchen gadgets, garden tools) and large (appliances, lawnmowers, bicycles, cars).

在大型城市建筑拔地而起之前，可以看到巨大的钢桩打桩机将钢材或钢筋混凝土打入地下，作为地基；随后，工地会被高耸的钢结构起重机占据数月之久。1954年，纽约的索科尼-美孚大厦成为第一座完全采用不锈钢外立面的摩天大楼，而且……最近，迪拜高达 828 米的哈利法塔采用了纹理不锈钢拱肩板和垂直管状钢销。[53]钢材既是许多优雅的悬臂桥和悬索桥的关键结构构件，也是其设计特色：[54]旧金山金门大桥的钢梁经常被重新涂成橙色；[55]日本明石海峡大桥拥有世界上最长的中央跨度，近 2 公里，其钢塔支撑着直径 1.12 米的编织钢索。[56]

Before large city buildings go up, you can see massive steel pile-driving machines ramming in steel or steel-reinforced concrete for the foundations, and then the site is dominated for months by tall steel construction cranes. In 1954, New York’s Socony-Mobil Building was the first skyscraper entirely clad in stainless steel, and more recently Dubai’s 828-meter-tall Burj Khalifa uses textured stainless-steel spandrel panels and vertical tubular steel pins.[53] Steel is both the critical structural component and the design feature of many elegant cantilevered and suspension bridges:[54] in San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge it is constantly repainted orange;[55] Japan’s Akashi Kaikyō Bridge has the world’s longest central span, at nearly 2 kilometers, and its steel towers support woven steel cables that are 1.12 meters in diameter.[56]

城市街道两旁整齐排列着由热浸镀锌和粉末涂层钢材制成的防锈路灯杆；轧制钢材用于制造路边交通标志和高架指示牌；波纹钢板则用于制造防撞护栏。钢塔支撑着粗壮的钢丝绳，将数百万滑雪者从山上运送下来，也用缆车将游客送上巍峨的山峰。无线电和电视塔（拉线桅杆）打破了多项人造建筑的高度纪录，现代景观中随处可见高压输电塔。近年来，又新增了两项引人注目的建筑：令人眼花缭乱的高耸拉线塔（用于传输移动电话信号）和成群的大型风力涡轮机塔，这些风力涡轮机塔既有陆上也有海上；而海洋中最庞大的钢结构则是巨大的石油和天然气生产平台。[57]

City streets are lined by regularly spaced lighting poles made from hot-dip galvanized and powder-coated steel for rust resistance; rolled steel makes roadside traffic signs and structures for overhead signage; and corrugated steel is used for crash barriers. Steel towers support thick steel wires to lift downhill skiers by the millions and to carry visitors in cable cars to tall peaks. Radio and TV towers (guyed masts) broke many height records for man-made structures, and modern landscapes contain seemingly endless repetitions of high-voltage electricity transmission towers. Two recent, prominent additions are dizzyingly tall guyed towers (to carry mobile telephone signals) and groups of large wind turbine towers, both onshore and offshore; and the most massive steel assemblies in the ocean are huge oil and gas production platforms.[57]

按重量计算，钢铁几乎总是交通运输设备中占比最大的部分。喷气式客机是一个主要的例外（铝合金和复合纤维占据主导地位），钢铁约占飞机重量的10%，主要用于发动机和起落架。[58]一辆普通汽车大约含有900公斤钢铁。[59]每年生产近1亿辆汽车，这意味着大约需要9000万吨钢铁——其中约60%是高强度钢，使汽车比传统钢铁轻26%至40%。[60]虽然现代高速列车（铝制车身，塑料内饰）的钢铁含量仅占约15%（车轮、车轴、轴承和电机），但其运行需要使用比普通钢轨更重的专用轨道。[61]

By weight, steel is nearly always the largest part of transportation equipment. Jetliners are a major exception (aluminum alloys and composite fibers dominate) and steel is about 10 percent of the plane’s weight, in engines and the landing gear.[58] The average car contains about 900 kilograms of steel.[59] With nearly 100 million motor vehicles produced per year, this translates to about 90 million tons of the metal—about 60 percent of it being high-strength steel that makes vehicles 26–40 percent lighter than conventional steel.[60] Although modern high-speed trains (aluminum bodies, plastic interiors) are only about 15 percent steel (wheels, axles, bearings, and motors), their operation requires dedicated tracks using heavier-than-normal steel rails.[61]

石油和液化气运输船以及运输矿石、谷物或水泥的散货船的船体，都是通过将大型高强度钢板弯曲成所需形状并焊接在一起制成的。战后航运业最伟大的变革莫过于集装箱船的投入使用（详见第四章）。集装箱船使用尺寸标准化的钢制箱体运输货物。[62]这些钢制箱体高约2.5米，宽约2.5米（长度略有不同），堆放在船体内部和甲板上方。你身上穿的每一件衣服，很可能都是从亚洲某家工厂出发，装在钢制集装箱里运到最终销售点的。

Ship hulls of oil and liquefied-gas tankers and of bulk carriers transporting ores, grains, or cement are made by bending large plates of high-tensile steel into desired shapes and welding them together. But the greatest revolution in postwar shipping has been the deployment of container ships (for more detail, see chapter 4). They transport cargo in steel crates of standardized dimensions.[62] These steel boxes are about 2.5 meters high and wide (length varies) and are stacked inside the hulls and high above the deck. Chances are that everything you wear was carried to its final point of sale in a steel container that started its journey in a factory in Asia.

那么，所有这些工具和机器是如何制造出来的呢？它们大多由其他机器和组件制造而成，这些机器和组件主要由钢材制成，能够进行铸造、锻造、轧制、减材加工（车削、铣削、挖空和钻孔）、弯曲、焊接、磨削和切割等工序。切割等工序之所以能够实现，要归功于性能卓越的工具钢，它们能够像切黄油一样轻松地切割碳钢。而制造机器的机器大多由电力驱动，电力的生产（以及由此产生的整个电子、计算机和电信领域）都离不开钢铁：高耸的锅炉里塞满了钢管，里面充满了加压水；核反应堆被包裹在厚厚的压力容器中；膨胀的蒸汽驱动着巨大的涡轮机旋转，而涡轮机的长轴则是由粗糙的、巨大的钢锻件加工而成。

And how were all these tools and machines made? Mostly by other machines and assemblies made largely of steel and which do casting, forging, rolling, subtractive machining (turning, milling, hollowing, and drilling), bending, welding, sharpening, and cutting, the latter operations being possible thanks to amazing tool steels that cut carbon steels as easily as a knife goes through soft butter. And the machines that make machines are mostly powered by electricity, whose generation (and hence also the entire universe of electronics, computing, and telecommunication) is impossible without steel: tall boilers crammed with steel tubes and filled with pressurized water; nuclear reactors enclosed in thick pressure vessels; expanding steam rotating large turbines whose long shafts are machined from rough, massive steel forgings.

埋藏在地下的钢铁包括深矿井中的固定和移动支撑杆，以及原油和天然气井中数百万公里的勘探管、套管和生产管道。石油和天然气行业也依赖于埋藏在近地表（1-2米深）的钢铁，用于集输、输送和分配管道。干线管道的直径超过1米，而天然气分配管道的直径可能只有5厘米。[63]原油炼油厂本质上就是钢铁森林，拥有高耸的蒸馏塔、催化裂化装置、庞大的管道系统和储罐。最后，我必须指出钢铁如何在医院拯救生命（从离心机和诊断设备到不锈钢手术刀、手术钩和牵开器），以及它如何夺走生命：军队和舰队及其种类繁多的武器装备，只不过是巨大的钢铁库，专门用于毁灭。[64]

Steel that is out of sight underground includes fixed and moving props in deep mines, and millions of kilometers of exploratory, casing, and production pipes in crude oil and natural gas wells. The oil and gas industry also depends on steel buried close to the surface (1–2 meters deep) in gathering, transmission, and distribution pipelines. Trunk lines use pipes with diameters of more than 1 meter, while distribution gas lines may be just 5 centimeters across.[63] Crude oil refineries are essentially forests of steel, with tall distillation columns, catalytic crackers, extensive piping, and storage vessels. Finally, I must note how steel saves lives in hospitals (from centrifuges and diagnostic machines to stainless-steel scalpels, surgical hooks, and retractors), and how it also kills: armies and fleets with their vast arrays of weapons are nothing but enormous repositories of steel dedicated to destruction.[64]

我们能否确保所需的大量钢铁供应？钢铁的全球产量究竟有多重要？我们是否有足够的……我们能否储备足够的铁矿石，以满足未来几代人的钢铁生产需求？我们能否生产足够的钢铁，以建设现代化基础设施，并提高低收入国家的生活水平？这些国家的人均钢铁消费量甚至低于一个世纪前富裕经济体的水平。钢铁生产对环境友好吗？还是会造成严重的环境破坏？我们能否在不使用任何化石燃料的情况下生产钢铁？

Can we secure the required massive supply of steel and how consequential is the metal’s global production? Do we have adequate supplies of iron ore to keep making steel for many generations to come? Can we produce enough of it in order to build modern infrastructures and raise the standards of living in low-income countries, where average per capita steel consumption is even lower than it was in the affluent economies a century ago? Is steelmaking environmentally friendly or is it exceptionally damaging? Can we produce the metal without using any fossil fuels?

第二个问题的答案无疑是肯定的。铁是地球上质量占比最高的元素，因为它很重（几乎是水的八倍），而且构成了地核。[65]铁在地壳中含量也很丰富：只有三种元素（氧、硅和铝）的含量比铁高；铁的含量接近6%，排名第四。[66]目前，铁矿石的年产量约为25亿吨，主要产地为澳大利亚、巴西和中国；全球铁资源储量超过8000亿吨，其中铁含量接近2500亿吨。这意味着铁的资源/产量比（R/P）超过300年，远远超出任何可想象的规划周期（原油的资源/产量比仅为50年）。[67]

The answer to the second question is unequivocally positive. Iron is the Earth’s dominant element by mass because it is heavy (nearly eight times as heavy as water) and because it forms the planet’s core.[65] But it is also abundant in the Earth’s crust: only three elements (oxygen, silicon, and aluminum) are more common; iron, with nearly 6 percent, ranks fourth.[66] Annual production of iron ore—led by Australia, Brazil, and China—is now about 2.5 billion tons; world resources are in excess of 800 billion tons, containing nearly 250 billion tons of the metal. This is a resource/production (R/P) ratio of more than 300 years, far beyond any conceivable planning horizons (the R/P ratio for crude oil is just 50 years).[67]

此外，钢铁很容易回收利用，只需在电弧炉（EAF）中熔化即可。电弧炉是一个巨大的圆柱形耐热容器，由厚重的钢板（内衬镁砖）制成，顶部有一个可拆卸的圆顶状水冷盖，三个巨大的碳电极就插入其中。将废钢装入炉内后，电极被放入炉内，电流通过电极形成电弧，电弧的高温（1800°C）足以熔化炉内金属。[68]然而，电弧炉的耗电量巨大：即使是高效的现代电弧炉，每天的耗电量也相当于一个拥有约15万人口的美国城市。[69]

Moreover, steel is readily recycled by melting it in an electric arc furnace (EAF)—a massive cylindrical heat-resistant container made of heavy steel plates (lined with magnesium bricks), with a removable dome-like water-cooled lid through which three massive carbon electrodes are inserted. After loading the steel scrap, the electrodes are lowered into it, and electric current passing through them forms an arc whose high temperature (1,800°C) easily melts the charged metal.[68] However, their electricity demand is enormous: even a highly efficient modern EAF needs as much electricity every day as an American city of about 150,000 people.[69]

车辆回收前，需要排空所有液体，拆除内饰，并移除电池、伺服电机、轮胎、收音机和发动机，以及塑料、橡胶、玻璃和铝制部件。之后，汽车压碎机将拆解后的车身压扁，为后续的粉碎作业做准备。迄今为止，最具挑战性的回收作业是拆解大型远洋船舶，这项工作主要在巴基斯坦（卡拉奇西北部的加达尼）、印度（古吉拉特邦的阿朗）和孟加拉国（吉大港附近）的海滩上进行。拆解后的船体由厚重的材料制成。钢板必须用气体和等离子切割炬切割——这是一项危险且污染环境的工作，而且经常由没有适当防护装备的工人进行。[70]

Vehicle recycling is preceded by draining all fluids, ripping out upholstery, and removing batteries, servomotors, tires, radios, and working engines, as well as plastic, rubber, glass, and aluminum components. Car crushers then flatten the stripped bodies preparatory to shredding. By far the most challenging recycling operation is the dismantling of large ocean-going vessels, done mostly on beaches in Pakistan (Gadani, northwest of Karachi), India (Alang in Gujarat), and Bangladesh (near Chittagong). Stripped hulls made of heavy steel plates must be cut by gas and plasma torches—dangerous and polluting work done too often by men working without proper protective gear.[70]

富裕经济体现在几乎回收了所有汽车废料，结构钢梁和钢板的再利用率也同样很高（超过90%），家用电器的回收率也仅略低一些。美国最近回收了超过65%的混凝土钢筋，这一比例与饮料和食品钢罐的回收率相近。[71]废钢已成为世界上最有价值的出口商品之一，因为拥有悠久钢铁生产历史且积累了大量废钢的国家将其出售给不断扩张的生产商。欧盟是最大的出口国，其次是日本、俄罗斯和加拿大；中国、印度和土耳其是最大的买家。[72]再生钢占钢铁年总产量的近30%，各国的占比差异很大，一些小型钢铁生产商的占比高达100%，美国接近70%，欧盟约为40%，而中国则不到12%。[73]

Affluent economies now recycle nearly all of their automotive scrap, have a similarly high rate (>90 percent) for reusing structural steel beams and plates, and only a slightly lower rate for recycling household appliances, and the US has recently recycled more than 65 percent of reinforcement bars in concrete, a rate similar to the recycling of beverage and food steel cans.[71] Steel scrap has become one of the world’s most valuable export commodities, as countries with a long history of steel production and with plenty of accumulated scrap sell the material to expanding producers. The EU is the largest exporter, followed by Japan, Russia, and Canada; and China, India, and Turkey are the top buyers.[72] Recycled steel accounts for almost 30 percent of the metal’s total annual output, with national shares ranging from 100 percent for several small steel producers to almost 70 percent in the US, about 40 percent in the EU, and to less than 12 percent in China.[73]

这意味着初级炼钢仍然占据主导地位，其每年生产的铁水量是回收量的两倍多——2019年接近13亿吨。炼钢过程始于高炉（内衬耐热材料的高耸钢铁结构），高炉通过冶炼铁矿石、焦炭和石灰石来生产液态铁（生铁或铸铁）。[74]第二步——降低生铁的高碳含量并生产钢——在转炉（基本氧气转炉；该形容词指的是所产生炉渣的化学性质）中进行。该工艺发明于20世纪40年代，并在20世纪50年代中期后迅速实现商业化。[75]如今的转炉是大型梨形容器，顶部敞开，用于装入多达300吨的铁水，并从顶部和底部吹入氧气进行吹炼。该反应可在约30分钟内将金属的碳含量降低至0.04%左右。高炉和碱性氧气转炉的组合是现代一体化炼钢的基础。最后步骤包括将热钢输送至连铸机，生产钢坯、钢锭（方形或矩形）和钢带，最终加工成成品钢材。

This means that primary steelmaking still dominates, producing more than twice as much hot metal every year as is recycled—almost 1.3 billion tons in 2019. The process starts with blast furnaces (tall iron and steel structures lined with heat-resistant materials) that produce liquid (cast or pig) iron by smelting iron ore, coke, and limestone.[74] The second step—reducing cast iron’s high carbon content and producing steel—takes place in a BOF (basic oxygen furnace; the adjective refers to the chemical properties of the produced slag). The process was invented during the 1940s and was rapidly commercialized after the mid-1950s.[75] Today’s BOFs are large, pear-shaped vessels with an open top used to charge up to 300 tons of hot iron, which gets blasted with oxygen blown in from both top and bottom. The reaction reduces the metal’s carbon content (to as little as 0.04 percent) in about 30 minutes. The combination of a blast furnace and a basic oxygen furnace is the basis of modern integrated steelmaking. Final steps include the transfer of hot steel to continuous casting machines to produce steel slabs, billets (square or rectangular shapes), and strips that are eventually converted into final steel products.

炼铁是高耗能行业，高炉炼铁消耗了约75%的总能耗。目前最佳实践的成品钢能耗仅为每吨17-20吉焦耳；效率较低的工艺则需要25-30吉焦耳/吨。[76]显然，电弧炉炼钢的能耗远低于一体化炼钢的成本：目前最佳水平的能耗略高于2吉焦耳/吨。此外，还需加上轧钢的能耗（通常为1.5-2吉焦耳/吨），因此，全球一体化炼钢的总能耗约为25吉焦耳/吨，而再生钢的能耗约为5吉焦耳/吨。[77] 2019年全球钢铁生产的总能耗约为34艾焦耳，约占全球一次能源供应量的6%。

Ironmaking is highly energy-intensive, with about 75 percent of the total demand claimed by blast furnaces. Today’s best practices have a combined demand of just 17–20 gigajoules per ton of finished product; less efficient operations require 25–30 GJ/t.[76] Obviously, the energy cost of secondary steel made in EAFs is much lower than the cost of integrated production: today’s best performance is just above 2 GJ/t. To this must be added the energy costs of rolling the metal (mostly 1.5–2 GJ/t), and hence the representative global rates for the overall energy cost may be about 25 GJ/t for integrated steelmaking and 5 GJ/t for recycled steel.[77] The total energy requirement of global steel production in 2019 was about 34 exajoules, or about 6 percent of the world’s primary energy supply.

鉴于钢铁行业对焦煤和天然气的依赖，炼钢也是人为温室气体排放的主要来源之一。世界钢铁协会的数据显示，全球平均每吨钢铁排放500公斤碳，而近年来，初级炼钢每年排放约9亿吨碳，占全球化石燃料燃烧直接排放量的7%至9%。[78]但钢铁并非唯一造成二氧化碳排放的重要材料：水泥的能源消耗远低于钢铁，但由于其全球产量几乎是钢铁的三倍，因此水泥生产造成的碳排放量也占相当比例（约8%）。

Given the industry’s dependence on coking coal and natural gas, steelmaking has been also a major contributor to the anthropogenic generation of greenhouse gases. The World Steel Association puts the average global rate at 500 kilograms of carbon per ton, with recent primary steelmaking emitting about 900 megatons of carbon a year, or 7–9 percent of direct emissions from the global combustion of fossil fuels.[78] But steel is not the only major material responsible for a significant share of CO2 emissions: cement is much less energy-intensive, but because its global output is nearly three times that of steel, its production is responsible for a very similar share (about 8 percent) of emitted carbon.

混凝土：一个由水泥创造的世界

Concrete: a world created by cement

水泥是混凝土不可或缺的组成部分，它是通过将磨碎的石灰石（钙的来源）和粘土、页岩或废料（硅、铝和铁的来源）在大型窑炉（长100-220米的倾斜金属圆筒）中加热（至少1450°C）而制成的。[79]这种高温烧结会产生熟料（熔融的石灰石和铝硅酸盐），然后将其研磨成细粉状水泥。

Cement is the indispensable component of concrete, and it is produced by heating (to at least 1,450°C) ground limestone (a source of calcium) and clay, shale, or waste materials (sources of silicon, aluminum, and iron) in large kilns—long (100–220 meters) inclined metal cylinders.[79] This high-temperature sintering produces clinker (fused limestone and aluminosilicates) that is ground to yield fine, powdery cement.

混凝土主要由骨料（65%～85%）和水（15%～20%）组成。[80]使用较细的骨料，例如沙子，可以提高混凝土的强度。混凝土与使用不同粒径砾石的粗骨料混凝土类似，但需要更多的水。混合物由水泥粘合而成——水泥通常占混凝土最终质量的10%至15%——水泥与水的反应首先使混合物凝固，然后使其硬化。

Concrete consists largely (65–85 percent) of aggregates and also water (15–20 percent).[80] Finer aggregates such as sand result in stronger concrete, but need more water in the mix than do coarser aggregates that use different sizes of gravel. The mixture is held together by cement—typically 10–15 percent of concrete’s final mass—whose reaction with water first sets the mixture and then hardens it.

如今，混凝土已成为现代文明中应用最广泛的材料，它坚硬而沉重，能够经受数十年的严苛使用，尤其是在钢筋加固的情况下。普通混凝土的抗压性能相当不错（现代最好的混凝土强度是两代以前的五倍），但抗拉强度却很低。[81]结构钢的抗拉强度比普通混凝土高出100倍，人们已经使用各种类型的加固材料（钢丝网、钢筋、玻璃纤维或钢纤维、聚丙烯）来缩小这一巨大差距。

The result is now the most massively deployed material of modern civilization, hard and heavy and able to withstand decades of punishing use, particularly when it is reinforced with steel. Plain concrete is fairly good in compression (and the best modern varieties are five times stronger than those of two generations ago)—but weak in tension.[81] Structural steel has tension strength up to 100 times higher, and different types of reinforcing (steel mesh, steel bars, glass or steel fibers, PP) have been used to narrow this huge gap.

自2007年以来，人类大部分时间都生活在以混凝土为主要建材的城市中。当然，城市建筑中也使用了许多其他材料：摩天大楼的钢结构骨架外覆玻璃或金属；北美郊区的独立式住宅则由木材（木龙骨、胶合板、刨花板）和石膏板（通常外覆砖石）构成；如今，工程木材也被用于建造多层公寓。[82]但摩天大楼和高层公寓楼都建在混凝土桩基上，混凝土不仅用于地基和地下室，还用于许多墙壁和天花板，并且在所有城市基础设施中都无处不在——从地下工程网络（大型管道、电缆沟、下水道、地铁基础、隧道）到地上交通基础设施（人行道、道路、桥梁、码头、机场跑道）。从圣保罗和香港（拥有多层公寓楼）到洛杉矶和北京（拥有四通八达的高速公路网络），现代城市都是混凝土的化身。

Since 2007, most of humanity has lived in cities made possible by concrete. Of course, there are plenty of other materials in urban buildings: skyscrapers have steel skeletons covered by glass or metal; detached houses in North American suburbs are made of wood (studs, plywood, particle board) and gypsum drywall (and are often sheathed in brick or stone); and engineered lumber is now used to build apartments many stories high.[82] But skyscrapers and tall apartment buildings stand on concrete piles, concrete goes not only into foundations and basements but also into many walls and ceilings, and it is ubiquitous in all urban infrastructures—from buried engineering networks (large pipes, cable channels, sewers, subway foundations, tunnels) to aboveground transportation infrastructure (sidewalks, roads, bridges, shipping piers, airport runways). Modern cities—from São Paulo and Hong Kong (with their multistoried apartment towers) to Los Angeles and Beijing (with their extensive networks of freeways)—are embodiments of concrete.

罗马水泥是由石膏、生石灰和火山砂混合而成，事实证明，它是一种优良且耐用的材料，适用于建造大型建筑，包括巨大的拱顶。万神殿历经近两千年仍保存完好（建于公元126年），其跨度仍然超过任何其他非钢筋混凝土建筑。[83]但现代水泥的制备方法直到1824年才由英国砖瓦匠约瑟夫·阿斯普丁获得专利。他的水硬性砂浆是通过在高温下烧制石灰石和粘土制成的：石灰、二氧化硅和这些材料中存在的氧化铝会玻璃化或转化为玻璃状物质，研磨后即可制成波特兰水泥。[84]阿斯普丁之所以选择这个名称（至今仍被广泛使用），是因为这种玻璃状熟料硬化后，与水反应，其颜色与英吉利海峡波特兰岛的石灰石相似。

Roman cement was a mixture of gypsum, quicklime, and volcanic sand, and it proved to be an excellent and durable material for large structures, including expansive vaults. The Pantheon, intact after nearly two millennia (it was completed in 126 ce) still spans a greater distance than any other structure made of non-reinforced concrete.[83] But the preparation of modern cement was patented only in 1824 by Joseph Aspdin, an English bricklayer. His hydraulic mortar was made by firing limestone and clay at high temperatures: lime, silica, and alumina present in these materials are vitrified or transformed into a glass-like substance, whose grinding produced Portland cement.[84] Aspdin chose that name (still widely used today) because once hardened, and after reacting with water, the glassy clinker had a color similar to limestone from the Isle of Portland in the English Channel.

如前所述，这种新材料抗压性能优异，如今最好的混凝土可以承受超过100兆帕的压力，这大约相当于一头非洲公象的重量平衡在一枚硬币上。[85]但抗拉性能则截然不同：仅2至5兆帕的拉力（甚至小于撕裂人体皮肤所需的拉力）就能使混凝土断裂。正因如此，混凝土在建筑领域的大规模商业应用，是在钢筋技术的逐步进步使其适用于承受高拉力的结构部件之后才实现的。

As already noted, the new material was excellent in compression, and today’s best concretes can withstand pressure of more than 100 megapascals, which is about the weight of an African bull elephant balanced on a coin.[85] Tension is a different matter: a pulling force of just 2 to 5 megapascals (less than it takes to tear human skin) can break concrete apart. That is why the large-scale commercial adoption of concrete in construction took place only after gradual advances in steel reinforcement made it suitable for structural parts subject to high tension.

19世纪60年代和70年代，法国的弗朗索瓦·科涅和约瑟夫·莫尼耶申请了第一批钢筋专利（莫尼耶是一位园丁，他开始使用铁丝网加固他的花盆），但真正的突破出现在1884年，由欧内斯特·兰索姆发明了钢筋。[86]现代水泥回转窑的早期设计出现在19世纪90年代，这种窑炉可以将矿物在高达1500°C的温度下烧制，使得在大型项目中使用价格适中的混凝土成为可能。1903年，位于辛辛那提的16层高的英格尔斯大厦成为世界上第一座钢筋混凝土摩天大楼。[87]仅仅三年后，托马斯·爱迪生就确信混凝土应该取代木材用于建造美国独立式住宅，并开始在新泽西州设计和现场浇筑混凝土房屋； 1911 年，他试图通过提供廉价的混凝土家具（包括整套卧室家具）来重振失败的项目，甚至用混凝土制作了留声机，这是他最喜欢的发明之一。[88]

During the 1860s and 1870s, the first reinforcing patents were filed by François Coignet and Joseph Monier in France (Monier, a gardener, began to use iron mesh to reinforce his planters), but the real breakthrough came in 1884 with Ernest Ransome’s reinforcing steel bars.[86] The earliest designs of modern cement rotary kilns, where the minerals are vitrified at temperatures of up to 1,500°C, appeared during the 1890s and made it possible to use affordable concrete in large projects. The sixteen-story Ingalls Building in Cincinnati became the world’s first reinforced concrete skyscraper in 1903.[87] Just three years later, Thomas Edison became convinced that concrete should replace wood in the building of American detached houses, and began to design and cast in place concrete homes in New Jersey; in 1911 he tried to revive the failed project by also offering cheap concrete furniture, including entire bedroom sets, and even made a phonograph, one of his favorite inventions, out of concrete.[88]

与此同时，与爱迪生的失败形成鲜明对比的是，瑞士工程师罗伯特·迈拉尔开创了一种至今仍然盛行的混凝土建筑潮流：钢筋混凝土桥梁，其开端是1901年建成的相对较短的祖奥兹桥和1906年建成的塔瓦纳萨桥。他最著名的设计是横跨阿尔卑斯山峡谷的萨尔吉纳托贝尔拱桥，这座气势恢宏的拱桥于1930年竣工，如今已成为国际历史土木工程地标。[89]早期的混凝土设计也受到建筑师奥古斯特·佩雷的青睐。在法国（优雅的公寓和香榭丽舍剧院），以及在美国，弗兰克·劳埃德·赖特的作品都广为人知。赖特在两次世界大战期间最著名的混凝土建筑设计是东京帝国饭店（在1923年地震夷平东京并损坏这座新建筑之前竣工）和宾夕法尼亚州的流水别墅（于1939年竣工）。纽约古根海姆博物馆是他最后一件著名的混凝土建筑设计，于1959年竣工。[90]

At the same time, in contrast to Edison’s failure, Robert Maillart, a Swiss engineer, pioneered a concrete construction trend that is still going strong: reinforced concrete bridges, starting with the relatively short Zuoz in 1901 and Tavanasa in 1906. His most famous design, the bold Salginatobel arch above an Alpine ravine, was completed in 1930 and is now an International Historic Civil Engineering Landmark.[89] Early concrete designs were also favored by architects Auguste Perret in France (elegant apartments and the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées) and Frank Lloyd Wright in the US. Wright’s most famous interwar concrete designs were Tokyo’s Imperial Hotel, finished just before the 1923 earthquake leveled the city and damaged the new structure, and Fallingwater in Pennsylvania, completed in 1939. The Guggenheim Museum in New York was his last famous concrete design, completed in 1959.[90]

钢筋的抗拉强度通过在浇筑混凝土前（预应力，使用端部锚栓张紧钢筋，待混凝土与钢筋粘结后释放）或浇筑后（后张拉，将钢筋束固定在保护套管内）张紧的模板中得到进一步提高。第一个大型预应力建筑是欧仁·弗雷西内设计的布雷斯特附近的普卢加斯泰尔桥，于1930年竣工。[91]约恩·乌松设计的悉尼歌剧院（建于1959年至1973年）以其大胆的白色帆状外观，或许是世界上最著名的预应力混凝土结构。[92]如今，预应力技术已十分普遍，最长的钢筋混凝土桥梁不再跨越河流或峡谷，而是用于高速列车的铁路高架桥。该世界纪录保持者是中国的丹阳昆山大桥（2010 年建成），全长 164.8 公里，是京沪高速铁路的一部分。[93]

The tensile strength of reinforcing steel was further improved by pouring concrete into forms whose wires or bars were tensioned just before pouring the concrete (pre-stressing, with end anchors that are used to tension the steel and are released once the concrete bonds with the metal) or after it (post-stressing, with steel tendons locked in place inside protective sleeves). The first major pre-stressed design, Eugène Freyssinet’s Plougastel Bridge near Brest, was finished in 1930.[91] With its bold, white, sail-like design, Jørn Utzon’s Sydney Opera House (built between 1959 and 1973) is perhaps the world’s most famous pre-stressed concrete strucuture.[92] Pre-stressing is now common, and the longest reinforced concrete bridges are not crossing rivers or ravines but rather railroad viaducts for high-speed trains. The record goes to the 164.8-kilometer Danyang–Kunshan Grand Bridge in China (completed in 2010), part of the Beijing–Shanghai high-speed railway.[93]

如今，从港口码头到现代隧道掘进机安装的节段环（例如英吉利海峡和阿尔卑斯山下的隧道），每一座大型现代建筑和每一条交通基础设施都离不开钢筋混凝土。美国州际公路系统的标准结构是在两倍厚的天然骨料（石块、砾石、沙子）层上铺设一层约28厘米厚的非钢筋混凝土——整个州际公路系统大约使用了5000万吨水泥、15亿吨骨料，而钢材（用于结构支撑和涵管）仅约600万吨。[94]机场跑道（最长可达3.5公里）采用钢筋混凝土基础，着陆区最深（达1.5米），以承受每年数十万次飞机（例如空客A380）起降的反复冲击。例如，加拿大最长的跑道（4.27公里）在卡尔加里）需要超过 85,000 立方米的混凝土和 16,000 吨钢筋。[95]

Reinforced concrete is now inside every large modern building and every transportation infrastructure, from port piers to segmental rings installed by modern tunnel-boring machines (under the Channel and the Alps). The standard configuration of the US Interstate Highway System is a layer of about 28 centimeters of non-reinforced concrete on top of a twice-as-thick layer of natural aggregates (stones, gravel, sand)—and the entire Interstate system contains about 50 million tons of cement, 1.5 billion metric tons of aggregates, and only about 6 million tons of steel (for structural support and culvert pipes).[94] Airport runways (up to 3.5 kilometers long) have reinforced concrete foundations, deepest (up to 1.5 meters) in the touchdown zone to handle the repeated pounding of hundreds of thousands of landings every year by airplanes weighing up to about 380 tons (the Airbus 380). For example, Canada’s longest runway (4.27 kilometers, in Calgary) required more than 85,000 cubic meters of concrete and 16,000 tons of reinforcing steel.[95]

但迄今为止，用钢筋混凝土建造的最庞大的结构无疑是世界上最大的水坝。这些巨型结构的时代始于20世纪30年代，当时科罗拉多河上的胡佛水坝和哥伦比亚河上的格兰德库利水坝相继建成。位于拉斯维加斯东南部峡谷中的胡佛水坝高达340万立方米，需要约340万立方米的混凝土、2万吨钢筋、两倍于此的钢板和钢管，以及8000吨结构钢。[96] 20世纪下半叶，数百座这样的巨型结构拔地而起。世界上最大的水坝——位于中国长江上的三峡大坝（自2011年开始发电）——使用了近2800万立方米的混凝土和25.65万吨钢材。[97]

But by far the most massive structures built of reinforced concrete are the world’s largest dams. The era of these megastructures began during the 1930s with the construction of the Hoover Dam on the Colorado River and the Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River. The vertiginous Hoover Dam, located in a gorge southeast of Las Vegas, required about 3.4 million cubic meters of concrete and 20,000 tons of reinforcing steel, twice as much plate and pipe steel, and 8,000 tons of structural steel.[96] Hundreds of these massive structures were built during the second half of the 20th century, and the world’s largest dam—China’s Sanxia (Three Gorges) on the Yangzi, generating electricity since 2011—has its almost 28 million cubic meters of concrete reinforced with 256,500 tons of steel.[97]

1900年至1928年间，美国水泥年消费量增长了十倍，达到3000万吨。战后建设热潮——包括州际公路系统的建设和机场的扩建——到世纪末使水泥消费量增长了两倍。2005年，水泥消费量达到峰值，约为1.28亿吨，而近期的消费量约为每年1亿吨。[98]这与世界第一大水泥消费国——中国的年需求量相比，简直微不足道。1980年，中国开始现代化进程，当时的水泥产量不足8000万吨。1985年，中国超越美国成为世界最大的水泥生产国，2019年，其水泥产量约为22亿吨，占全球总产量的一半以上。[99]

Annual American cement consumption rose tenfold between 1900 and 1928, when it reached 30 million tons, and the postwar construction boom—including the construction of the Interstate Highway System and the expansion of the country’s airports—tripled by the century’s end. The peak was reached at about 128 million tons in 2005, and recent rates are around 100 million tons a year.[98] This is now a tiny fraction of the annual demand in the world’s number-one cement consumer, China. In 1980, at the outset of its modernization drive, it produced less than 80 million tons of cement. In 1985, it surpassed the US to become the world’s largest producer, and in 2019 its output of about 2.2 billion tons was just over half of the global total.[99]

或许，这一崛起最令人震惊的结果是，短短两年间——2018年和2019年——中国的水泥产量（约44亿吨）几乎与美国整个20世纪的水泥产量（45.6亿吨）相当。毫不奇怪，中国如今拥有世界上最庞大的高速公路、高铁和机场系统，以及数量最多的巨型水电站和新兴的数百万人口城市。另一个令人瞠目结舌的数据是，世界如今一年的水泥消耗量就超过了20世纪上半叶的总和。而且（既幸运又不幸），这些庞大的现代混凝土建筑的寿命远不及万神殿的穹顶。

Perhaps the most stunning outcome of this rise is that in just two years—2018 and 2019—China produced nearly as much cement (about 4.4 billion tons) as did the United States during the entire 20th century (4.56 billion tons). Not surprisingly, the country now has the world’s most extensive systems of freeways, rapid trains, and airports, as well as the largest number of giant hydro stations and new multimillion-population cities. Yet another astounding statistic is that the world now consumes in one year more cement than it did during the entire first half of the 20th century. And (both fortunately and unfortunately) these enormous masses of modern concrete will not last as long as the Pantheon’s coffered dome.

普通建筑混凝土并非高耐久性材料，易受多种环境因素侵蚀。[100]暴露的表面会受到潮气、冻害、细菌和藻类滋生（尤其是在热带地区）、酸沉降和振动的侵蚀。埋于地下的混凝土结构会受到导致裂缝的压力以及上方渗出的活性化合物造成的损害。混凝土的高碱性（新浇筑的混凝土pH值约为12.5）能有效防止钢筋腐蚀，但裂缝和剥落会使金属暴露于腐蚀性破坏之下。氯化物会侵蚀浸泡在海水中的混凝土以及冬季使用盐除冰的道路上的混凝土。

Ordinary construction concrete is not a highly durable material and it is subject to many environmental assaults.[100] Exposed surfaces are attacked by moisture, freezing, bacterial and algal growth (especially in the tropics), acid deposition, and vibration. Buried concrete structures suffer from crack-inducing pressures, and from damage caused by reactive compounds seeping from above. Concrete’s high alkalinity (freshly poured material has a pH of about 12.5) is an effective guard against the corrosion of the reinforcing steel, but cracks and exfoliation expose the metal to corrosive disintegration. Chlorides attack concrete submerged in seawater and concrete on winter roads where salt is used for de-icing.

从1990年到2020年，现代世界的大规模混凝土化建设已累计使用了近7000亿吨坚硬但会缓慢风化的材料。混凝土结构的耐久性差异很大：虽然无法给出平均使用寿命，但许多结构在短短二三十年后就会严重劣化，而另一些结构则能保持60-100年的良好状态。这意味着在21世纪，我们将面临前所未有的混凝土劣化、更新和拆除压力（显然，这个问题在中国尤为突出），因为许多结构必须被拆除——以便进行替换或销毁——或者被废弃。混凝土结构可以缓慢拆除，钢筋可以分离出来，这两种材料都可以回收利用：虽然成本不低，但完全可行。经过破碎和筛分后，骨料可以掺入新的混凝土中，钢筋也可以回收利用。[101]即使在今天，到处都需要更换混凝土和建造新的混凝土。

Between 1990 and 2020, the mass-scale concretization of the modern world has emplaced nearly 700 billion tons of hard but slowly crumbling material. The durability of concrete structures varies widely: while it is impossible to offer an average longevity figure, many will deteriorate badly after just two or three decades while others will do well for 60–100 years. This means that during the 21st century we will face unprecedented burdens of concrete deterioration, renewal, and removal (with, obviously, a particularly acute problem in China), as structures will have to be torn down—in order to be replaced or destroyed—or abandoned. Concrete structures can be slowly demolished, reinforcing steel can be separated, and both materials can be recycled: not cheap, but perfectly possible. After crushing and sieving, the aggregate can be incorporated in new concrete, and reinforcing steel can be recycled.[101] Even now, replacement concrete and new concrete are needed everywhere.

在人口增长率低的富裕国家，首要需求是修复老化的基础设施。美国最新的基础设施评估报告显示，所有以混凝土为主的领域都只获得了差或非常差的评价，其中水坝、道路和航空的评级为D，整体平均评级仅为D+。[102]这一评估结果让我们得以窥见中国到2050年可能面临的规模和资金挑战。相比之下，最贫困的国家更需要基本的基础设施，非洲和亚洲许多家庭最基本的需求是用水泥地面取代泥土地面，以改善整体卫生状况，并将寄生虫病的发生率降低近80%。[103]

In affluent countries with low population growth, the main need is to fix decaying infrastructures. The latest report card for the US awards nothing but poor to very poor grades to all sectors where concrete dominates, with dams, roads, and aviation getting Ds and the overall average grade just D+.[102] This appraisal gives an inkling of what China might face (mass- and money-wise) by 2050. In contrast, the poorest countries need essential infrastructures and the most basic need in many homes in Africa and Asia is to replace mud floors with concrete floors in order to improve overall hygiene and to reduce the incidence of parasitic diseases by nearly 80 percent.[103]

随着人口老龄化、城市化进程、经济全球化以及区域性衰退，世界各地将有更多混凝土建筑被废弃。底特律汽车工厂的混凝土废墟、欧洲老工业区废弃的企业，以及苏联中央计划者在俄罗斯平原和西伯利亚建造的那些如今已废弃的工厂和纪念碑，仅仅是这一趋势的开端。[104]其他常见且引人注目的混凝土遗迹还包括厚墙防御工事，例如诺曼底和马奇诺防线上的掩体，以及曾经存放核导弹、如今空置在美国大平原上的巨型混凝土筒仓。

With aging populations, migration to cities, economic globalization, and widespread regional declines, more concrete will simply be abandoned worldwide. Concrete ruins of car factories in Detroit, abandoned enterprises in Europe’s old industrial regions, and all those now derelict plants and monuments built by Soviet central planners on the Russian plain and in Siberia are only the first waves of this trend.[104] Other common and prominent concrete relics are thick-walled defensive bunkers such as those of Normandy and the Maginot Line, and massive concrete silos that formerly housed nuclear missiles and now sit empty on America’s Great Plains.

材料展望：新旧投入

Material outlook: old and new inputs

在21世纪上半叶，随着全球人口增长放缓，许多富裕国家的人口数量停滞甚至下降，各国经济体应该能够满足对钢铁、水泥、氨和塑料的需求，尤其是在回收利用力度加大的情况下。但到2050年，所有这些行业不太可能完全摆脱对化石燃料的依赖，并停止成为全球二氧化碳排放的重要来源。对于当今低收入的现代化国家而言，这种情况尤其难以实现，因为它们巨大的基础设施和消费需求将需要大规模增加所有基础材料的需求。

During the first half of the 21st century—with slower global population growth and with stagnant or even declining counts in many affluent countries—economies should have no problems meeting the demand for steel, cement, ammonia, and plastics, especially with intensified recycling. But it is unlikely that by 2050 all of these industries will eliminate their dependence on fossil fuels and cease to be significant contributors to global CO2 emissions. This is especially unlikely in today’s low-income modernizing countries, whose enormous infrastructural and consumer needs will require large-scale increases of all basic materials.

在这些国家复制中国1990年后的经验，将使钢铁产量增长15倍，水泥产量增长10倍以上，氨合成量增长一倍以上，塑料合成量增长30倍以上。[105]显然，即使其他现代化国家只达到中国近期材料进步的一半甚至四分之一，这些国家目前的用量也将成倍增长。对化石碳的需求一直是——而且在未来几十年仍将如此——我们为依赖钢铁、水泥、氨和塑料所带来的诸多好处所付出的代价。随着我们不断扩大可再生能源的转化，我们将需要更多数量的旧材料以及前所未有的新材料。以前只需要少量材料，现在却需要大量的材料。[106]

Replicating the post-1990 Chinese experience in those countries would amount to a 15-fold increase of steel output, a more than 10-fold boost for cement production, a more than doubling of ammonia synthesis, and a more than 30-fold increase of plastic syntheses.[105] Obviously, even if other modernizing countries accomplish only half or even just a quarter of China’s recent material advances, these countries would still see multiplications of their current uses. Requirements for fossil carbon have been—and for decades will continue to be—the price we pay for the multitude of benefits arising from our reliance on steel, cement, ammonia, and plastics. And as we continue to expand renewable energy conversions, we will require larger masses of old materials as well as unprecedented quantities of materials that were previously needed in only modest amounts.[106]

两个显著的​​例子说明了这种日益加剧的物质依赖性。没有什么比大型风力涡轮机更能代表“绿色”发电了——但这些由钢铁、水泥和塑料组成的庞然大物，同时也是化石燃料的化身。[107]它们的地基是钢筋混凝土，塔筒、机舱和转子都是钢材（每兆瓦装机容量需要近200吨钢材），而巨大的叶片则是由高能耗且难以回收的塑料树脂制成（中型涡轮机大约需要15吨）。所有这些巨型部件都必须用超大型卡车运送到安装地点，并由大型钢制起重机吊装，涡轮机齿轮箱也需要反复加注润滑油。将这些需求乘以数百万台涡轮机的数量（才能完全取代化石燃料发电），便足以说明任何关于绿色经济即将实现去物质化的说法都是多么具有误导性。

Two prominent examples illustrate this unfolding material dependence. No structures are more obvious symbols of “green” electricity generation than large wind turbines—but these enormous accumulations of steel, cement, and plastics are also embodiments of fossil fuels.[107] Their foundations are reinforced concrete, their towers, nacelles, and rotors are steel (altogether nearly 200 tons of it for every megawatt of installed generating capacity), and their massive blades are energy-intensive—and difficult to recycle—plastic resins (about 15 tons of them for a midsize turbine). All of these giant parts must be brought to the installation sites by outsized trucks and erected by large steel cranes, and turbine gearboxes must be repeatedly lubricated with oil. Multiplying these requirements by the millions of turbines that would be needed to eliminate electricity generated from fossil fuels shows how misleading any talks are about the coming dematerialization of green economies.

电动汽车或许是新型且巨大的材料依赖性的最佳例证。一块典型的锂电池重约450公斤，其中包含约11公斤锂、近14公斤钴、27公斤镍、超过40公斤铜和50公斤石墨，以及约181公斤钢、铝和塑料。为一辆电动汽车提供这些材料需要加工约40吨矿石，考虑到矿石中许多元素的浓度较低，这意味着需要开采和加工约225吨原材料。[108]再举个例子，我们需要将这个数字乘以近1亿辆，这相当于全球每年需要被电动汽车取代的内燃机汽车的产量。

Electric cars provide perhaps the best example of new, and enormous, material dependencies. A typical lithium car battery weighing about 450 kilograms contains about 11 kilograms of lithium, nearly 14 kilograms of cobalt, 27 kilograms of nickel, more than 40 kilograms of copper, and 50 kilograms of graphite—as well as about 181 kilograms of steel, aluminum, and plastics. Supplying these materials for a single vehicle requires processing about 40 tons of ores, and given the low concentration of many elements in their ores it necessitates extracting and processing about 225 tons of raw materials.[108] Again, we would have to multiply this by close to 100 million units, which is the annual worldwide production of internal-combustion vehicles that would have to be replaced by electric drive.

电动汽车未来普及率的不确定性很大，但基于两种情景（假设到2050年全球汽车保有量中25%或50%为电动汽车）的详细材料需求评估发现：从2020年到2050年，锂的需求量将增长18-20倍，钴的需求量将增长17-19倍，镍的需求量将增长28-31倍，而大多数其他材料的需求量从2020年开始将增长15-20倍。[109]显然，这将需要……只有大幅扩张锂、钴（其中很大一部分来自刚果危险的人工挖掘深井，且普遍存在童工现象）和镍的开采和加工，以及广泛寻找新的资源，才能实现这一目标。而这一切，又离不开化石燃料和电力的大量额外转化。预测未来电动汽车保有量稳步增长是一回事，而在全球范围内大规模创造这些新的材料供应则是另一回事。

Uncertainties about the future rates of electric vehicle adoption are large, but a detailed assessment of material needs, based on two scenarios (assuming that 25 percent or 50 percent of the global fleet in 2050 would be electric vehicles), found the following: from 2020 to 2050 demand for lithium would grow by factors of 18–20, for cobalt by 17–19, for nickel by 28–31, and factors of 15–20 would apply for most other materials from 2020.[109] Obviously, this would require not only a drastic expansion of lithium, cobalt (a large share of it now coming from Congo’s perilously hand-dug deep shafts and from widespread child labor), and nickel extraction and processing, but also an extensive search for new resources. And these, in turn, could not take place without large additional conversions of fossil fuels and electricity. Generating smoothly rising forecasts of future electric vehicle ownership is one thing; creating these new material supplies on a mass global scale is quite another.

现代经济始终与大规模的物质流动息息相关，无论是为不断增长的全球人口提供食物的氨基肥料；制造新型工具、机器、建筑和基础设施所需的塑料、钢铁和水泥；还是生产太阳能电池、风力涡轮机、电动汽车和蓄电池所需的新型原材料。除非用于提取和加工这些材料的所有能源都来自可再生能源，否则现代文明仍将从根本上依赖于生产这些不可或缺的材料所使用的化石燃料。人工智能、应用程序和电子信息都无法改变这一点。

Modern economies will always be tied to massive material flows, whether those of ammonia-based fertilizers to feed the still-growing global population; plastics, steel, and cement needed for new tools, machines, structures, and infrastructures; or new inputs required to produce solar cells, wind turbines, electric cars, and storage batteries. And until all energies used to extract and process these materials come from renewable conversions, modern civilization will remain fundamentally dependent on the fossil fuels used in the production of these indispensable materials. No AI, no apps, and no electronic messages will change that.

4. 理解全球化

4. Understanding Globalization

引擎、微芯片及其他

Engines, Microchips, and Beyond

全球化以无数日常方式展现出来。满载着成千上万个相互连接的钢制集装箱的货轮，将电子产品、厨房用具、袜子、裤子、园艺工具和体育器材从亚洲运往欧洲和北美的购物中心，也运往非洲和拉丁美洲的廉价服装和厨具摊贩手中。巨型油轮将原油从沙特阿拉伯运往印度和日本的炼油厂，将液化天然气从德克萨斯州运往法国和韩国的储气罐。满载铁矿石的大型散货船从巴西驶往中国，然后空船返回母港（油轮也是如此）。苹果公司在美国设计的iPhone手机，由一家台湾公司（鸿海精密，以富士康的名义在中国广东省深圳市）的工厂组装，零部件来自十几个国家，然后通过精心策划的工程和营销整合流程，在全球范围内分销。[1]

Globalization manifests itself in countless quotidian ways. Ships loaded with many thousands of interlocking steel containers are bringing electronic and kitchen gadgets, socks and pants, garden tools and sports equipment from Asia to the shopping centers of Europe and North America, as well as to hawkers of cheap clothes and kitchenware in Africa and Latin America. Giant tankers move crude oil from Saudi Arabia to refineries in India and Japan, and liquefied natural gas from Texas to storage tanks in France and South Korea. Large bulk carriers full of iron ore leave Brazil for China and return empty (as do the oil tankers) to their home ports. Apple’s American-designed iPhones are assembled in a Taiwanese-owned factory (Hon Hai Precision, trading as Foxconn) in Shenzhen, in China’s Guangdong province, from parts coming from more than a dozen countries, and the phones are then distributed globally in a highly choreographed feat of integrated engineering and marketing.[1]

国际移民包括来自旁遮普邦或黎巴嫩的家庭乘坐定期航班抵达多伦多和悉尼；移民冒着生命危险乘坐橡皮艇试图抵达兰佩杜萨岛或马耳他；以及年轻人前往伦敦、巴黎或爱荷华州和堪萨斯州的小型学院接受高等教育。[2]休闲旅游已达到如此规模，以至于在许多情况下，疫情前的“过度旅游”一词都只是对当时情况的轻描淡写。例如，罗马的圣彼得大教堂挤满了手持自拍杆的游客，他们参加的是欧洲短途旅行团；又如，亚洲的海滩因环境恶化而不得不关闭。[3]新冠疫情的爆发导致了新的严重过度旅游危机，2020年初春，数百名老年人被困在日本或马达加斯加海岸附近的游轮上——然而，在年底之前，即使新一波感染仍在上升。世界各地的大型公司纷纷推出 2021 年的新型巨型邮轮航线（这就是现代人的不安分！）。

International migrations include families from Punjab or Lebanon arriving in Toronto and Sydney on scheduled jet flights; migrants risking their lives in rubber dinghies as they try to reach Lampedusa or Malta; and young adults seeking higher education abroad in London, Paris, or in small colleges in Iowa and Kansas.[2] Travel for leisure has reached such levels that in many cases the pre-pandemic label of “overtourism” was but a mild description of what was taking place in Rome’s San Pietro, where the basilica was jammed with selfie stick–wielding tourists on quick package European tours, or on Asian beaches that became so degraded they had to be closed to visitors.[3] The COVID-19 pandemic’s onset led to new acute overtourism crises, as hundreds of elderly people were shut in on cruise ships off the shores of Japan or Madagascar in the early spring of 2020—and yet before the end of the year, even as new waves of infection were rising fast around the world, major companies advertised new megaship cruises for 2021 (such is modern restlessness!).

有关资金流动的统计数据大大低估了实际的（包括大规模非法）资金流动。全球商品贸易额目前接近每年20万亿美元，全球商业服务贸易额接近每年6万亿美元。[4] 2000年至2019年间，全球外国直接投资翻了一番，目前接近每年1.5万亿美元，而到2020年，全球货币交易总额接近每天7万亿美元。[5]描述全球信息流动的数字比这些资金转移高出几个数量级——不仅以TB或PB为单位，而且以EB（10¹⁸ ）和Yotta（10²⁴）字节为单位。[6]

Statistics concerning money movements greatly underestimate the real (including massive illegal) flows. The global merchandise trade is now close to $20 trillion a year, and the annual value of world trade in commercial services is close to $6 trillion.[4] Global foreign direct investment doubled between 2000 and 2019 and now approaches $1.5 trillion a year, while by 2020 global currency trading totaled nearly $7 trillion per day.[5] And numbers describing global information flows are many orders of magnitude higher than these money transfers—not just in terabytes or petabytes but in exa (1018) and yotta (1024) bytes of data.[6]

显然，要真正理解现代世界的运作方式，就必须了解这一多方面进程的演变、范围和后果。这一进程（根据我认为或许最简洁的定义）包含“世界经济、文化和人口日益增长的相互依存，这种相互依存是由跨境商品和服务贸易、技术以及投资、人员和信息的流动所促成的”。[7]与普遍的看法相反，这一进程并非新生事物；将工作岗位转移到劳动力成本低的国家（劳动力套利）只是其众多必要驱动因素之一；而且，其未来的扩张和强化并非不可避免。或许关于全球化的最大误解在于，它是一种由经济和社会演进预先决定的历史必然性。事实并非如此——全球化并非如一位美国前总统所言，“如同风或水等自然力量的经济等价物”；它只是人类构建的另一个概念，现在越来越多的人认为，在某些方面，它已经走得太远，需要进行调整。[8]

Obviously, understanding how the modern world really works cannot be done without appreciating the evolution, the extent, and the consequences of this multifaceted process which entails (according to what I think is perhaps the best concise definition) “the growing interdependence of the world’s economies, cultures, and populations, brought about by cross-border trade in goods and services, technology, and flows of investment, people, and information.”[7] Contrary to widely held beliefs, the process is not new; moving jobs to countries with low labor costs (labor arbitrage) is just one of its several requisite drivers; and there is nothing inevitable about its future expansion and intensification. Perhaps the greatest misconception about globalization is that it is a historical inevitability preordained by economic and social evolution. Not so—globalization is not, as a former US president claimed, “the economic equivalent of a force of nature, like wind or water”; it is just another human construct, and there is now a growing consensus that, in some ways, it has already gone too far and needs to be readjusted.[8]

本章我将阐明，全球化是一个有着相当悠久历史的过程（尽管过去商品、投资和人口流动的增长并未被纳入“全球化”这一概念），而近期人们对这一现象的关注度激增，并非源于其新颖性，而是源于其规模的扩大。谷歌的Ngram Viewer图表能够很好地展现人们对任何重大发展事件的长期关注趋势。全球化图表由以下部分组成：在 20 世纪 80 年代中期之前，人们的兴趣几乎为零，然后在接下来的二十年里急剧上升——在 1987 年至 2006 年期间，参与频率增长了 40 倍，达到顶峰——随后到 2018 年下降了 33%。

In this chapter I will show that globalization is a process with considerable history (although, in the past, the rising flows of goods, investment, and people were not subsumed under the label), and the recent attention to the phenomenon escalated due to its extent, not because of its novelty. Google’s Ngram Viewer charts provide excellent illustrations of long-term trends of attention paid to any notable developments. The chart for globalization consists of a near-zero flat line until the mid-1980s, then a steep rise of interest during the next two decades—a 40-fold rise of frequency between 1987 and 2006, when interest peaked—followed by a 33 percent decline by 2018.

如果低廉的劳动力成本是企业在海外设立新工厂的唯一原因——正如许多人似乎错误地认为的那样——那么撒哈拉以南非洲显然是最理想的选择，而印度几乎总是比中国更受欢迎。但在21世纪第二个十年，中国平均每年吸引约2300亿美元的外国直接投资，而印度不到500亿美元，整个撒哈拉以南非洲（不包括南非）也只有大约400亿美元。[9]中国还具备其他诸多吸引因素——最重要的是，中央集权的一党制政府能够保障政治稳定和良好的投资环境；庞大且高度同质化的高素质人口；以及巨大的国内市场——这些因素使其成为比尼日利亚、孟加拉国甚至印度更受欢迎的选择，最终导致了世界最大的共产主义国家与几乎所有世界领先的资本主义企业之间形成了一种惊人的默契。[10]

If low labor costs were the sole reason for locating new factories abroad—as many people seem to erroneously believe—then sub-Saharan Africa would be the most obvious choice, and India would almost always be preferable to China. But during the second decade of the 21st century, China averaged about $230 billion of foreign direct investment a year, compared to less than $50 billion for India and just around $40 billion for all of sub-Saharan Africa (excluding South Africa).[9] China provided a combination of other attractors—above all, centralized one-party government that could guarantee political stability and acceptable investment conditions; a large, highly homogeneous and literate population; and an enormous domestic market—that made it the preferred choice over Nigeria, Bangladesh, and even India, resulting in a remarkable collusion between the world’s largest communist state and a nearly complete lineup of the world’s leading capitalist enterprises.[10]

全球化一直被人们赞誉为给各国带来的优势、益处、创造性破坏、现代化和进步。中国无疑是全球化的最大受益者，因为中国重新融入全球经济，使得1980年至2015年间生活在极端贫困中的人口减少了94%。[11]但这些成就和赞誉也伴随着不同程度的反对，甚至对这一进程的彻底否定。不满和愤怒源于高薪工作岗位流失到海外（2000年后，美国经济的多个部门的流失尤为显著），源于劳动力套利导致的竞相压低薪酬，以及日益加剧的不平等和新型贫困。[12]

Globalization has been linked, approvingly, with the advantages, benefits, creative destruction, modernity, and progress it has brought to entire nations. China has been by far its greatest beneficiary, as the country’s reintegration into the global economy helped to reduce the number of people living in extreme poverty by 94 percent between 1980 and 2015.[11] But these gains and praises coexist with various degrees of disapproval or even outright rejection of the process, with the discontent and anger that have resulted from the loss of well-paying jobs to offshoring (with post-2000 losses especially prominent in several sectors of the US economy), from the race to the bottom as labor arbitrage drives remunerations ever lower, and from growing inequality and new kinds of immiseration.[12]

尽管在这些反应和分析中有很多值得赞同和反对的地方，但本章既不会重复过去两代经济学出版物中充斥的常见论述，也不会就这一现象的利弊展开辩论。我的目标是解释技术因素——如上所述——如何影响经济。所有这些，包括新型原动机（发动机、涡轮机、电动机）和新型通信及信息手段（存储、传输和检索），都使得一波又一波的全球化成为可能。然而，这些技术进步又如何取决于当时的政治和社会条件呢？因此，全球化进程的持续和进一步加强并非必然，而1913年后长达数十年的全球化显著倒退，以及近期出现的逆转和对现有供应链安全的担忧，都清楚地表明了这一点。

While there is much with which to agree, and disagree, in these reactions and analyses, this chapter will be neither a reiteration of often-told narratives that have crowded economic publications of the past two generations, nor a polemic about the desirability of the phenomenon. My goal is to explain how technical factors—above all, new prime movers (engines, turbines, motors) and new means of communication and information (storage, transmission, and retrieval)—made successive waves of globalization possible, and then to point out how these technical advances have been contingent on the prevailing political and social conditions. As a result, there is nothing inevitable about the continuation and further intensification of the process, and the significant, decades-long, post-1913 retreat from globalization, as well as recent reversals and concerns about the security of existing supply chains, serve as obvious reminders of this reality.

全球化的遥远起源

Globalization’s distant origins

从最根本的物理层面来看，全球化就是物质的流动——原材料、食品、成品和人口的流动——以及信息（警告、指导、新闻、数据、理念）和投资在各大洲内部及之间的传递，而这一切都得益于各种技术手段，使得大规模、经济可靠地进行此类转移成为可能。不可避免地，这些转移需要能量转换。虽然物质的流动和信息的传递可以通过人力和畜力来实现（例如搬运货物、骑马传递信息），但这些有生命力的动力、耐力和作用范围都非常有限——当然，它们也无法跨越海洋。

In its most fundamental physical way, globalization is, and will remain, simply the movement of mass—of raw materials, foodstuffs, finished products, and people—and the transmission of information (warnings, guidance, news, data, ideas) and investment within and among the continents, enabled by techniques that make such transfers possible on large scales and in affordable and reliable ways. Inevitably, these transfers entail energy conversions, and while moving mass and transmitting information can be done by deploying human and animal muscles (carrying loads, sending messengers on horseback), these animate prime movers have very limited power, endurance, and range—and, of course, they are incapable of bridging the oceans.

帆船的历史可以追溯到五千多年前的埃及，它是最早实现这种联系的非生物能量转换器。但只有蒸汽机，以及更先进的导航技术，才带来了大规模、低成本且可靠的能量交换。而只有随着1900年后内燃机（在陆地、海洋和空中）的普及，以及1955年后固态（半导体）电子技术的应用，这一进程才达到了前所未有的高度。但这些创新只是加速了全球化进程，而非其起源。全球化进程（与1985年后的显著发展不同）并非新现象，本章将追溯其发展的时间节点。以及它过去浪潮的范围，以及它们最终影响范围和强度的极限。

Sails, going back to the Egypt of more than 5,000 years ago, were the first inanimate energy converters to make such links possible, but only steam engines, aided by better means of navigation, brought the large-scale, low-cost, and reliable interchange—and only with the post-1900 diffusion of internal combustion engines (on land, on the ocean, and in the air) and the post-1955 adoption of solid-state (semiconductor) electronics has this process increased to unprecedented levels. But these innovations intensified globalization; they didn’t launch it. The process (unlike its post-1985 prominence) is not a new phenomenon, and in this chapter I will trace both the timing and the extent of its past waves—and the limits of their eventual reach and intensity.

这个过程始于很久以前，但其最初几轮的规模和范围都存在局限性。6000多年前，旧世界部分地区沿着史前路线进行黑曜石贸易，这并非如近期某些人所声称的那样是全球化的例证[13] ——但在欧洲人“发现”美洲之前，许多联系都相当紧密，而且是真正的跨洲联系。船只定期从罗马埃及的红海港口贝雷尼克驶往印度，就像从巴士拉驶往印度一样：卡西乌斯·狄奥在公元116年记载，图拉真皇帝在短暂占领美索不达米亚期间，站在波斯湾岸边，望着一艘驶往印度的船只，心中感叹自己多么希望像亚历山大一样年轻，因为亚历山大曾率领军队远征那片遥远的土地。[14]中国的丝绸经由帕提亚帝国一路运往罗马——来自埃及的粮食和极其沉重的古代方尖碑，以及来自毛里塔尼亚廷吉塔纳（摩洛哥北部）的野生动物，也同样如此。[15]

The process began a long time ago, but its first rounds were inherently limited. Trading obsidian along prehistoric routes in parts of the Old World more than 6,000 years ago is not, as has recently been claimed, an example of globalization[13]—but many ties before the European “discovery” of America were relatively intensive and truly intercontinental. Ships sailed regularly from Berenike, the Red Sea port in Roman Egypt, to India, as they did from Basra: Cassius Dio wrote in 116 ce how the emperor Trajan, during his temporary occupation of Mesopotamia, stood at the Persian Gulf’s shore watching a ship leaving for India and wishing that he were as young as Alexander, who had led his armies to that faraway country.[14] Chinese silk made it, via the Parthian Empire, all the way to Rome—as did regular shipments of grain and extraordinarily heavy loads of ancient obelisks from Egypt, and wild animals from Mauretania Tingitana (northern Morocco).[15]

但欧洲、亚洲和非洲部分地区的零星联系，与真正的全球性联系相去甚远。只有新大陆的发现（始于1492年）和首次环球航行（1519年）才开始符合这一定义，而仅仅一个世纪后，商业交流就将欧洲国家与亚洲内陆、印度和远东地区，以及非洲沿海地区和美洲大陆联系起来——只有澳大利亚仍然被排除在外。这些早期联系中，有些既持久又具有变革性。总部位于伦敦的东印度公司（1600年至1874年间运营）贸易范围广泛，主要往返于印度次大陆，商品种类繁多，从纺织品、金属到香料和鸦片，应有尽有。荷兰东印度公司（Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie）主要从东南亚进口香料、纺织品、宝石和咖啡；荷兰对日本的贸易垄断持续了两个世纪（1641 年至 1858 年），直到 1945 年才结束对东印度群岛的统治。[16]

But the scattered linking of parts of Europe, Asia, and Africa is a far cry from a truly global reach. Only the inclusion of the New World (starting in 1492) and the first circumnavigation of the Earth (1519) began to satisfy this definition, and a mere century later commercial exchanges tied European states with the interior of Asia, India, and the Far East, as well as with coastal regions of Africa and with both Americas—and only Australia was still left aside. Some of these early links were as enduring as they were transformative. The East India Company, headquartered in London and operating between 1600 and 1874, traded a wide range of items—largely to and from the Indian subcontinent—ranging from textiles and metals to spices and opium. The Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie (Dutch East India Company) imported spices, textiles, gems, and coffee mostly from Southeast Asia; it kept its uninterrupted monopoly on trade with Japan for two centuries (between 1641 and 1858), and the Dutch domination of the East Indies ended only in 1945.[16]

与此同时，技术能力也明确限制了早期交流的频率和强度，在这里我将使用它们的关键指标——个人的最大功率和速度。交通方式，以及越来越快、越来越可靠的远距离通信能力——以此来追溯全球化的四个不同时代。

At the same time, technical capabilities put clear limits on the frequency and intensity of these early exchanges, and here I will use their key markers—the maximum power and speed of individual modes of transport, and the ability to communicate over long distances ever more quickly and reliably—to trace the four distinct eras of globalization.

全球化的萌芽最终通过帆船将世界各地连接起来，虽然彼此间的交流并不十分频繁。蒸汽机的出现使这些联系更加普遍、更加紧密，也更加可预测，而电报则提供了第一种真正意义上的全球性（近乎即时）通信方式。第一批柴油发动机、航空和无线电的结合，提升并加速了全球化进程。大型柴油发动机（用于航运）、涡轮机（用于航空）、集装箱（实现多式联运）以及微芯片（凭借信息处理的数量和速度，实现了前所未有的控制）将全球化推向了巅峰。

Incipient globalization eventually connected the world with far-flung but not very intensive exchanges enabled by sail ships. Steam engines made these linkages more common, more intensive, and much more predictable, while telegraph provided the first truly global means of (near-instant) communication. The combination of the first diesel engines, flight, and radio elevated and accelerated these enablers of globalization. And large diesels (in shipping), turbines (in flight), containers (enabling intermodal transport), and microchips (allowing unprecedented controls thanks to the volume and speed of information-handling) brought globalization to its highest stage.

风驱动的全球化

Wind-driven globalization

从一开始，仅依赖人力驱动的全球化的局限性就显而易见。人力和畜力是陆地上唯一的动力来源，这限制了搬运工（最多40-50公斤）或畜力商队（马或骆驼，每匹牲畜可负重100-150公斤）所能携带的货物重量，也限制了他们每日的行进速度。[17]丝绸之路上的商队（从黑海沿岸的塔奈斯经萨莱到北京）需要一年时间才能完成，这意味着平均日行速度约为25公里。进行长途航行的木制帆船数量寥寥，而且运载量小、航速慢、缺乏精确的导航设备，常常无法完成航程。

Starting at the beginning, the limits of globalization dependent solely on animate power are easily stated. Human and animal muscles were the only prime movers on land, restricting the weight of goods that could be carried by porters (maxima of 40–50 kilograms) or by animal caravans (horses or camels, loads of 100–150 kilograms per animal) and limiting their daily progress.[17] Caravans on the Silk Road (from Tanais on the Black Sea via Sarai to Beijing) took a year, implying an average speed of about 25 kilometers per day. Wooden sail ships undertaking long-distance voyages were far from numerous, and they had small capacities, traveled slowly, lacked accurate means of navigation, and frequently failed to complete their journeys.

荷兰航运至亚洲的详细记录证实了这些限制。[18]记录显示，17世纪前往巴达维亚（今雅加达）的平均航程为238天（8个月），从巴达维亚到长崎港的荷兰小据点出岛则需一个月。18世纪的平均航速略有下降，航程耗时245天。考虑到阿姆斯特丹和巴达维亚之间的距离为15,000海里（27,780公里），这意味着平均航速为每小时4.7公里。相当于走得相当慢！这种糟糕的平均速度是由于顺风航行（风从船后方吹来）时速度还算不错，以及在赤道无风带航行时船只无法航行，或者长时间强劲的盛行风需要费力地转向——或者干脆放弃并等待风向改变。

Detailed records of Dutch shipping to Asia document these limits.[18] They show that the average duration of a voyage to Batavia (present-day Jakarta) was 238 days (eight months) during the 17th century, and another month from Batavia to Dejima, the small Dutch outpost in the Nagasaki harbor. And average speeds during the 18th century were slightly slower, with journeys taking 245 days. Given the distance of 15,000 nautical miles (27,780 kilometers) between Amsterdam and Batavia, this implies an average speed of 4.7 kilometers per hour, the equivalent of rather slow walking! That poor average is a result of some half-decent speeds when running before the wind (the wind coming from directly behind the vessel), and other days when ships were becalmed by the equatorial doldrums or when long spells of strong prevailing winds required laborious tacking—or giving up and waiting for the wind to shift.

17至18世纪，荷兰人仅为亚洲贸易建造了1450艘新船（平均每年7艘），每艘船的载吨位仅为700至1000吨。这样的载吨位足以运输香料、茶叶和瓷器等高价值货物并从中获利，但对于大宗商品贸易而言则完全不经济（日本珍贵的铜矿是主要例外）。前往巴达维亚的航次受限于船只数量和航行风险，而前往日本的航次则被德川幕府限制在每年2至7艘，并且在1790年代每年仅允许一艘船抵达。由于荷兰东印度公司保留了详细的记录，我们也知道有多少人登上了从荷兰开往东印度群岛的 4700 多艘船只：1595 年至 1795 年间，近 100 万人完成了这段旅程，但平均每年只有 5000 人，其中约 15% 的人在到达锡兰或巴达维亚之前就去世了。[19]

During the 17th and 18th centuries the Dutch built only 1,450 new ships for Asian trade (averaging seven a year) with capacities of just 700–1,000 tons.
