The list can be easily extended by adding worries about mad cow disease (bovine spongiform encephalopathy), Salmonella or Escherichia coli, exposure to hospital microbes (nosocomial infections), non-ionizing radiation from mobile phones, cybersecurity and data theft, artificial intelligence designs or genetically engineered organisms getting out of control, the accidental launch of nuclear missiles, and a stray, unobserved asteroid hitting the planet. With such a recital we might easily conclude that we are now exposed to more risks than ever—or, in contrast, that the incessant (and exaggerated) reporting of such events or their possibilities has simply made us more aware of their existence and that proper risk perception would provide some calming perspectives. And that is exactly what I will do in this chapter. Yes, the world is full of constant or episodic risks, but it is also replete with wrong perceptions and irrational risk appraisals. There are many reasons for these misperceptions and miscalculations, and practitioners of risk analysis have published revealing findings regarding their origins, prevalence, and endurance.[8]

但在我深入分析、量化和比较人为风险和自然风险之前，让我们先从基础知识入手。为了延年益寿，我们应该吃什么？鉴于现代饮食理论及其反驳层出不穷，这个问题似乎难以回答，或者至少非常棘手。我该如何权衡从完全肉食到纯粹素食的各种饮食方式的优缺点呢？前者被宣传为所谓的旧石器时代饮食，其中超过三分之一的食物能量来自肉类蛋白；后者则不仅要求完全不摄入任何动物性物质，甚至连皮鞋、针织羊毛衫和丝绸衬衫都不穿。前者迎合了我们遥远进化根源的某种刻板印象；后者则提供了保护饱受摧残的生物圈的最可靠途径，因为不起眼的植物不像破坏性的家畜那样会对环境造成破坏，它们对环境的压力微乎其微。[9]

But before I get to the analyses, quantifications, and comparison of man-made and natural risks, let’s start with the basics. What should we eat to promote a long life? Given the veritable minefield of modern dietary claims and counterclaims, this might seem to be an impossible, or at least very difficult, question to answer. How will I weigh the respective merits and demerits of diets ranging from unchecked carnivory to the purest veganism? The first one, promoted as the supposed Paleolithic diet, supplies more than a third of all food energy from meat protein; the other extends beyond never swallowing even a microgram of animal matter to never wearing leather shoes, knitted woolen sweaters, or silk blouses. The first appeals to a caricature of some of our distant evolutionary roots; the second offers the surest path to the preservation of the long-suffering biosphere because humble plants, unlike destructive domesticated animals, exert only the gentlest pressure on the environment.[9]

我寻找风险最低的饮食方案（即预期寿命超过80岁的饮食方案）的方法，不仅会忽略媒体宣传的各种可疑饮食说法，而且，或许更令人惊讶的是，还会忽略大量发表在科学期刊上的论文。特别是那些通过追踪不同规模和年龄群体，研究饮食、疾病和长寿之间联系，且主要依赖参与者对过去饮食的回忆的论文。我也会忽略此类研究的荟萃分析。仅仅列出 1950 年以后的这些出版物——从对冠心病、饱和脂肪和胆固醇的研究，到对吃肉和喝牛奶的风险的研究——就足以写成一本小册子。这些研究中相当一部分致力于揭露人类记忆的不可靠性（你上周吃了什么？我敢打赌你记不起来，或者至少记不清），以及详细阐述其他方法论或分析上的缺陷，以至于该领域充斥着对无效结论的指责。[10]

My approach to finding the least risky diets (those associated with life expectations above 80 years) will ignore not only all of the dubious dietary claims promoted by the media, but also, perhaps more surprisingly, scores of publications in scientific journals. In particular, those that have examined the links between diets, diseases, and longevity by following groups of various sizes and ages for shorter or longer periods of time while relying overwhelmingly on the participants’ recollections of all the food they have eaten in the past. I will also disregard metastudies of such projects. Merely listing these post-1950 publications—from the examination of coronary heart disease and saturated fat and cholesterol, to the risks of eating meat and drinking milk—would fill a small book, and a busy segment of these inquiries has been devoted to exposing the fallibility of human memory (what did you eat last week? I bet you can’t remember, or at least not accurately), as well as detailing other methodological or analytical shortcomings, such that this field is rife with accusations of invalid conclusions.[10]

难怪大多数人觉得我们应该吃什么这个问题很棘手。这是一个难题。这些研究及其荟萃分析屡次未能得出明确一致的结论，新的研究常常推翻之前的发现。[11]是否有更好的方法来解决这些持续数代且仍在不断演变的饮食难题？其实很简单。我们可以研究哪些人群寿命最长，以及他们的饮食结构。

No wonder most people find the question of what we should eat a difficult one. These studies, and their metastudies, have repeatedly failed to produce consistent clear-cut outcomes, with new research often upending previous findings.[11] Is there a better way out of these generations-long, and still unfolding, dietary conundrums? Indeed, it is quite simple. We can look at which populations live the longest and what their diets are.

像在京都一样吃——或者像在巴塞罗那一样吃

Eating as in Kyoto—or as in Barcelona

在全球200多个国家和地区中，日本自20世纪80年代初以来一直保持着最高的平均寿命，当时其出生时男女平均预期寿命超过77岁。[12]此后，日本的预期寿命持续增长，到2020年，其出生时男女平均预期寿命约为84.6岁。在所有社会中，女性的预期寿命都高于男性，到2020年，日本女性的平均预期寿命约为87.7岁，高于排名第二的西班牙的86.2岁。平均寿命是遗传、生活方式和营养等复杂且相互作用的因素共同作用的结果。试图确定饮食在多大程度上决定了平均寿命是不可能的，但如果一个国家的饮食存在独特的特征，那么显然值得对其进行更深入的研究。

Among the world’s more than 200 nations and territories, Japan has had the highest average longevity since the early 1980s, when its combined (male and female) life expectancy at birth surpassed 77 years.[12] Further gains followed, and by 2020 Japan’s combined life expectancy at birth was about 84.6 years. Women live longer in all societies, and by 2020 their life expectancy in Japan was about 87.7 years, ahead of 86.2 years in second-place Spain. Average longevity is an outcome of complex and interacting genetic, lifestyle, and nutritional factors. Trying to find out to what extent it is determined by diet alone is impossible, but if there are unique features to a nation’s diet, they clearly deserve a closer examination.

日本的饮食习惯究竟有何特别之处，能够直接解释其对日本国民长寿的贡献？其实，日本大量食用的传统食材与邻近亚洲国家大量食用或饮用的食材并无本质区别。中国人和日本人食用的是同一种稻米（日本稻，Oryza sativa japonica ）的不同品种，但营养价值却相差无几。中国人传统上用硫酸钙（shigāo ）凝固豆腐（dòufu ），而日本人则用硫酸镁（nigari ）凝固豆腐（tōfu），但两者的豆类原料都富含蛋白质。此外，与未发酵的日本绿茶（ocha）不同，中国绿茶（lǘchá）是经过部分发酵的。这些差异并非体现在营养价值上，而仅仅是外观、颜色和口感上的不同。

Is there anything truly special about Japan’s food consumption that would provide a ready explanation of that diet’s contribution to the nation’s record longevity? All of its traditional ingredients consumed in substantial quantities differ only subtly from those eaten or drunk in abundance in neighboring Asian nations. The Chinese and Japanese consume different, but nutritionally equivalent, varieties of the same subspecies of rice (Oryza sativa japonica). The Chinese have traditionally coagulated their bean curd (dòufu) with calcium sulfate (shígāo), while the Japanese bean curd (tōfu) is gelled with magnesium sulfate (nigari), but the ground legume grain is identically rich in protein. And unlike unfermented Japanese green tea (ocha), Chinese green tea (lǘchá) is partially fermented. These are not differences in nutritional quality, merely matters of appearance, color, and taste.

过去150年间，日本人的饮食习惯发生了巨大的变化。大多数人食用的传统饮食……1900年以前，日本的粮食供应不足以支撑人口增长，导致男女身材普遍矮小；二战前缓慢的改善在1945年战败后，随着粮食短缺的缓解而加速。[13]牛奶最初被引入学校午餐以预防营养不良，此后牛奶消费量开始上升，白米也变得供应充足。随着日本建立起当时世界上最大的捕鱼（和捕鲸）船队，海产品供应迅速增长。肉类成为日本常见菜肴的一部分，许多烘焙食品在这个传统上不爱烘焙的文化中也广受欢迎。收入的提高和口味的融合导致平均胆固醇水平、血压和体重增加——然而，心脏病发病率并未飙升，预期寿命反而延长。[14]

The Japanese diet has undergone an enormous transformation during the past 150 years. The traditional diet, consumed by most of the nation before 1900, was insufficient to support the population’s growth potential and it resulted in short statures among both women and men; slow pre–Second World War improvements accelerated after the country overcame food shortages following its defeat in 1945.[13] The consumption of milk, first introduced at school lunches to prevent malnutrition, began to rise, and white rice became abundant. Seafood supply expanded rapidly as the country built the world’s largest fishing (and whaling) fleet. Meat became a part of common Japanese dishes, and many baked goods emerged as favorites in this traditionally non-baking culture. Higher incomes and hybridization of tastes brought increases in mean blood cholesterol levels, blood pressure, and body weight—and yet heart disease did not soar and longevity increased.[14]

最新公布的调查显示，日本和美国在每日总食物能量摄入量方面出人意料地接近。2015-2016年，美国男性每日食物能量摄入量仅比日本男性高出11%，而美国女性也仅比日本男性高出不到4%。两国在总碳水化合物（日本领先不到10%）和蛋白质（美国领先不到14%）摄入量方面差异不大，而且两国的蛋白质摄入量都远高于最低推荐摄入量。但在平均脂肪摄入量方面，两国存在显著差距，美国男性比日本男性多摄入约45%，女性多摄入约30%。而最大的差距体现在糖的摄入量上：美国成年人的糖摄入量比日本成年人高出约70%。如果按年均差异重新计算，美国人近年来每年平均比日本成年人多摄入约8公斤脂肪和16公斤糖。[15]

The latest published surveys show Japan and the US to be surprisingly close in total food energy consumed per day. In 2015–2016, US males consumed only 11 percent more, and US women not even 4 percent more food energy per day than their Japanese counterparts did in 2017. The two countries diverged moderately in total carbohydrate (Japan was ahead by less than 10 percent) and protein (with Americans less than 14 percent ahead) consumption, and both nations were well above the needed protein minima. But there is a major gap in terms of average fat intake, with American males consuming about 45 percent more and women 30 percent more than the Japanese. And the greatest disparity is in sugar intake: among US adults it is about 70 percent higher. When recalculated in terms of average annual differences, Americans have recently consumed about 8 kilograms more fat and 16 kilograms more sugar every year than the average adult in Japan.[15]

食材的广泛供应，以及互联网上烹饪指南和食谱的便捷获取，意味着您也可以最大限度地降低过早死亡的风险，开始享用日式料理——无论是日本传统料理和食，还是其对外国菜肴的改良（例如，维也纳炸肉排变成了预切好的炸猪排；咖喱饭变成了黏稠的咖喱饭）。[16]但在您开始早餐吃味噌汤（味噌汤），午餐吃简单的冷饭团（用海苔包裹的饭团）之前，享用寿喜烧（肉和蔬菜炖菜）时，或许应该听听其他人的意见：欧洲最佳的饮食和长寿模式会怎么做？

The widespread availability of ingredients, and easy access to cooking instructions and recipes on the internet, means that you too can minimize your risk of premature mortality and start eating à la japonaise—be it the country’s traditional cuisine, washoku, or its adaptations of foreign meals (Wienerschnitzel appearing as pre-sliced tonkatsu; curry and rice transformed into gooey kare raisu).[16] But before you start breakfasting on miso soup (miso shiru), lunching on plain cold onigiri (rice balls wrapped in nori, dried seaweed), and dining on sukiyaki (meat and vegetable stew) a second opinion might be in order: what would the best European model of diet and longevity do?

西班牙女性的预期寿命位居世界第二，该国传统上奉行所谓的地中海饮食，大量摄入蔬菜、水果和全谷物，并辅以豆类、坚果、种子和橄榄油。但随着西班牙平均收入的增长，他们的饮食习惯迅速发生了令人惊讶的巨大改变。[17]直到20世纪50年代末，佛朗哥统治下贫困的西班牙仍然保持着非常节俭的饮食习惯。典型的饮食以淀粉类食物为主（人均年谷物和土豆消费量约为250公斤）和蔬菜；肉类供应量（胴体重量）低于人均20公斤，实际消费量不足12公斤（其中三分之一是羊肉和山羊肉）；橄榄油是最重要的植物油（每年约10升）。与其他食品相比，只有糖的消耗量（1960 年约为 16 公斤）较高。

The Spanish women are the runners-up in the world’s record life expectancy, and the country traditionally followed the so-called Mediterranean diet, with high intakes of vegetables, fruits, and whole grains complemented by beans, nuts, seeds, and olive oil. But as the average incomes in Spain rose, they rapidly changed those habits to a surprisingly high degree.[17] Until the late 1950s, Franco’s impoverished Spain continued to eat very frugally. Typical diets were dominated by starches (annual consumption of cereals and potatoes added up to about 250 kilograms per capita) and vegetables; meat supply (carcass weight) remained below 20 kilograms per capita and actual consumption was less than 12 kilograms (of which a third was mutton and goat meat); aceite de oliva was the most important plant oil (about 10 liters a year); and only sugar consumption (about 16 kilograms in 1960) was high in relation to other foodstuffs.

西班牙于1986年加入欧盟后，饮食结构的变化加速发展。到2000年，西班牙成为欧洲肉食消费量最高的国家（人均肉类消费量增长超过五倍，达到每年110公斤以上）。此后，人均肉类消费量（胴体重量）略有下降，到2020年降至约100公斤，但这仍然是日本人均消费量的两倍！此外，西班牙人还食用乳制品和奶酪，以及种类繁多、数量庞大的火腿（用盐腌制并长时间风干而成），因此，西班牙人均动物脂肪消费量是日本人的四倍也就不足为奇了。[18]西班牙人现在的植物油消费量几乎是日本人的两倍，但他们的橄榄油消费量比1960年下降了约25%。

Dietary changes accelerated after Spain joined the EU in 1986, and by the year 2000 it became Europe’s leading carnivorous nation (after more than quintupling the average per capita supply to just above 110 kilograms per year). A subsequent slight decline cut the rate (carcass weight) to about 100 kilograms per capita in 2020, but that is still twice the Japanese mean! And with dairy products and cheeses added to fresh meat and the enormous quantity and variety of jamones (hams cured by salting and prolonged drying), it is hardly surprising that the Spanish supply of animal fat is four times the Japanese rate.[18] Spaniards now consume almost twice the volume of plant oils as the Japanese—but their consumption of olive oil is about 25 percent lower than in 1960.

收入的提高加剧了人们对甜食的传统偏好，而碳酸饮料的普及则进一步强化了这一趋势：自1960年以来，西班牙人均糖消费量翻了一番，目前比日本高出约40%。与此同时，西班牙人均葡萄酒消费量持续下降，从1960年的约45升降至2020年的仅11升，啤酒则成为该国消费量最大的酒精饮料。西班牙如今的现状令人担忧。的饮食方式与日本的饮食方式大相径庭——而且，作为欧洲大陆最大的肉食国家，这种饮食方式与节俭、近乎素食且能延长寿命的传奇地中海饮食方式截然不同。

Higher incomes have only increased the traditional predilection for sugary creations, and the adoption of pop drinks did the rest: since 1960, per capita consumption of sugar has doubled and it is now about 40 percent above the Japanese level. At the same time, Spanish wine-drinking has been relentlessly declining, from about 45 liters per capita in 1960 to just 11 liters by 2020, and beer has become by far the country’s most-consumed alcoholic drink. The way Spain now eats is substantially different from the way Japan feeds itself—and, most definitely (being the continent’s top carnivore), this diet hardly resembles the frugal, near-vegetarian, and life-lengthening legendary Mediterranean diet.

尽管西班牙人的饮食中肉类、脂肪和糖分含量较高（而且他们也迅速放弃了饮用那些被认为有益心脏的葡萄酒），但西班牙的心血管疾病死亡率却持续下降，预期寿命却在不断提高。自1960年以来，西班牙的心血管疾病死亡率下降速度一直高于富裕经济体的平均水平，到2011年，其死亡率比这些国家的平均水平低约三分之一；自1960年以来，西班牙男女的预期寿命总和增加了13年以上，从70岁提高到2020年的83岁以上。[19]这仅比日本少一年：为了多活一年（而且这一年很可能是在身体或精神衰退中度过的，或者两者兼而有之），用豆腐代替一半的肉类摄入量是否值得呢？

But despite a more meaty, fatty, and sugary diet (and also rapidly abandoning drinking its supposedly heart-protecting wines), Spain’s cardiovascular mortality has kept on declining and life expectancy has been rising. Since 1960, Spain’s CVD mortality has been falling at a faster pace than the average of affluent economies, and by 2011 it was about a third lower than their mean; and since 1960, Spain has added more than 13 years to its combined (male and female) longevity prospect, raising it from 70 to more than 83 years by 2020.[19] This is just one year less than in Japan: is one additional year of life (and there are high chances that it might be spent in physical or mental decrepitude, or a combination of both) worth replacing half of the meat you eat with tofu?

想想你可能会错过什么：薄如蝉翼的伊比利亚火腿片；香喷喷的烤乳猪（即便不如马约尔广场南边不远的Sobrino de Botín餐厅那么出名，这家餐厅已经烤乳猪近300年了）；还有炖得恰到好处的加利西亚章鱼，用土豆、橄榄油和辣椒粉炖煮而成。这些都是关乎人生的抉择——但结论其实相当明确。如果我们把长寿（以及健康积极的生活方式）仅仅取决于日常饮食——饮食固然重要，但它只是更大图景中的一个因素，这个图景还包括遗传基因和周围环境——那么日式饮食略胜一筹，但瓦伦西亚人的饮食习惯也能带来同样美味的体验。

Think of what you might be missing: those paper-thin slices of jamón ibérico; that well-roasted pig (even if not done as famously as at Sobrino de Botín, a short walk south of the Plaza Mayor, where they have been preparing it for nearly 300 years); that well-cooked polpo gallego, octopus stewed with potatoes, olive oil, and paprika. These are, truly, existential decisions to make—but the conclusion is reasonably clear. If we were to stake longevity (accompanied by healthy and active life) solely on the prevailing diet—which, however important, is but one element of a bigger picture that includes your inherited genes and surrounding environment—then Japanese eating has a slight edge, but an only slightly inferior outcome can be had by eating as they do in Valencia.

这是一个影响深远但相对简单的风险评估：基于令人信服的数据做出一个选择，就能应对未来几十年。其他风险评估则总是更加复杂，因为衡量标准可能不像寿命那么简单。特定活动的风险会随着时间而变化（如今在美国开车总体上比半个世纪前安全得多，但驾驶50年后，你的驾驶技能可能会退化，当你再次开车时，你对自己和他人的风险会更大）。如果你想知道洲际旅行是否安全，假设你不常乘坐飞机，但飞行比滑雪（你可能已经滑雪多年）风险更大，那么你需要一个相当精确的比较标准。那么，如何比较不同国家的风险呢？比如，在美国开车、在阿尔卑斯山徒步旅行时被闪电击中以及在日本地震中丧生？事实上，我们可以对所有这些风险进行一些非常精确的比较评估。

This is a vastly consequential but relatively simple risk assessment: one choice, based on convincing data, can suffice for decades to come. Other risk assessments are invariably trickier, where metrics might not be as simple as years lived. The risks of specific activities change over time (driving in the US is now generally much safer than half a century ago, but after 50 years of driving your skills might have deteriorated and you pose a greater risk to yourself and others when you get behind the wheel). And if you want to know if intercontinental flying (which you might do infrequently) is riskier than downhill skiing (which you may have done for many years), you must have a rather accurate comparative yardstick. And how does one compare the risks experienced in different nations—say, driving in the US, being struck by lightning while hiking in the Alps and getting killed by an earthquake in Japan? As it turns out, we can do some remarkably accurate, comparative evaluations of all of these risks.

风险认知和承受能力

Risk perceptions and tolerances

在1969年开创性的风险分析中，时任加州大学洛杉矶分校工程与应用科学学院院长的昌西·斯塔尔强调了自愿活动和非自愿活动在风险承受能力方面的巨大差异。[20]当人们认为自己能够掌控局面时（这种认知或许并不正确，但它基于过往经验，因此也基于他们相信自己能够评估可能的结果），他们会参与一些活动——例如徒手攀岩、跳伞、斗牛——这些活动造成的严重伤亡风险可能比在西方大城市遭遇恐怖袭击等可怕的非自愿风险高出千倍。而且大多数人每天反复进行一些会暂时大幅增加自身风险的活动，这并没有什么问题：数亿人每天开车（而且很多人显然喜欢这样做），更多的吸烟者能够容忍更高的风险[21] ——在富裕国家，几十年的教育已经减少了吸烟者的数量，但全世界仍然有超过10亿吸烟者。

In his pioneering 1969 analysis of risks, Chauncey Starr—at that time the dean of the School of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of California in Los Angeles—stressed the major difference in risk tolerance between voluntary and involuntary activities.[20] When people think that they are in control (a perception that may be incorrect but that is based on previous experiences and hence on the belief that they can assess the likely outcome), they engage in activities—climbing vertical rock faces without ropes, skydiving, bullfighting—whose risks of serious injury or fatality may be a thousand-fold higher than the risk associated with such dreaded involuntary exposure as a terrorist attack in a large Western city. And most people have no problem engaging daily and repeatedly in activities that temporarily increase their risk by significant margins: hundreds of millions of people drive every day (and many apparently like to do so), and an even higher risk is tolerated by an even larger number of smokers[21]—in affluent countries, decades of education has reduced their ranks, but worldwide there are still more than 1 billion of them.

在某些情况下，人们对自愿承担的风险和试图避免错误认知的非自愿接触风险之间的这种差异变得非常奇怪，因为人们拒绝让孩子接种疫苗（自愿让他们接触多种可预防疾病的风险），因为他们认为政府保护儿童的要求（一种非自愿的强制措施）风险过高——而且他们这样做是基于屡次被证伪的“证据”。（最显著的例子是将疫苗接种与自闭症发病率升高联系起来）或谣言中的种种危险（植入微芯片！）。[22]而SARS-CoV-2疫情将这些非理性的恐惧推向了新的高度。人类结束疫情的最佳希望是大规模接种疫苗，但在第一批疫苗获准分发之前很久，很大一部分民众就告诉民意调查员他们不会接种疫苗。[23]

In some cases this disparity between tolerating voluntary risks and trying to avoid wrongly perceived risks of involuntary exposures becomes truly bizarre, as people refuse to have their children inoculated (voluntarily exposing them to multiple risks of preventable diseases) because they consider government requirements to protect their children (an involuntary imposition) as unacceptably risky—and have been doing so on the basis of repeatedly discredited “evidence” (most notably linking vaccination to a higher incidence of autism) or rumored perils (the implanting of microchips!).[22] And the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic elevated these irrational fears to a new level. Humanity’s best hope to end the pandemic was mass-scale vaccination, but long before the first vaccines were approved for distribution, large shares of the population were telling pollsters that they would not get inoculated.[23]

人们对核电普遍存在的恐惧是风险认知偏差的又一个绝佳例证。许多人吸烟、开车、暴饮暴食，却对住在核电站附近心存疑虑。民意调查显示，尽管核电避免了大量因燃烧化石燃料而导致的空气污染相关死亡（到2020年，全球近五分之三的电力来自化石燃料，而核裂变发电仅占10%），但人们对这种发电方式仍然存在根深蒂固的不信任。即使将两次重大事故（1985年的切尔诺贝利和2011年的福岛）所有潜在死亡人数的最佳估计值都考虑在内，核电和化石燃料发电的总体风险对比也并未发生逆转。[24]

Widespread fear of nuclear electricity generation is yet another excellent example of risk misperception. Many people smoke and drive and eat excessively but have reservations about living next to a nuclear power plant, and polling has shown lasting and pervasive distrust of this form of electricity generation despite the fact that it has prevented a large number of air pollution–related deaths that would have been associated with burning fossil fuels (by 2020, nearly three-fifths of the world’s electricity came from fossil fuels, and just 10 percent from nuclear fission). And the comparison between overall risks of nuclear and fossil-fueled electricity generation does not flip even when the best estimates of all latent fatalities from the two major accidents (Chornobyl in 1985 and Fukushima in 2011) are included.[24]

或许，法国和德国在核相关风险认知上的对比最为鲜明。自20世纪80年代以来，法国超过70%的电力来自核裂变，近60座反应堆遍布全国各地，利用塞纳河、莱茵河、加龙河和卢瓦尔河等法国河流的水进行冷却。[25]然而，法国人口的预期寿命（在欧盟内仅次于西班牙）最好地证明了这些核电站并未造成明显的健康问题或过早死亡——但在莱茵河对岸，不仅德国绿党认为核能是一种必须尽快消除的邪恶发明，而且社会上还有相当一部分人持这种观点。[26]

Perhaps the most stunning contrast of nuclear-related risk perceptions is seen when comparing France and Germany. France has been deriving more than 70 percent of its electricity from nuclear fission since the 1980s and nearly 60 reactors dot the country’s landscape, cooled by water from many French rivers, including the Seine, Rhine, Garonne, and Loire.[25] Yet the longevity of the French population (second only to Spain within the EU) is the best testimony to the fact that these nuclear power plants have not been a discernible source of ill health or premature deaths—but across the Rhine it is not only the German Greens who believe that nuclear power is an infernal invention that must be eliminated as fast as possible, but much larger portions of society too.[26]

因此，许多研究者认为，并不存在等待衡量的“客观风险”，因为我们对风险的感知本质上是主观的，取决于我们对特定危险（熟悉的风险与新风险）的理解以及文化环境。[ 27]心理测量学研究表明，特定风险具有其独特的、高度相关的特征模式：非自愿风险通常与对新型、不可控和未知风险的恐惧相关；自愿风险则更容易被认为是可控的且为科学所知的。核电被普遍认为是不安全的，而X射线则被认为是风险可以接受的。

This is why many researchers have argued that there is no “objective risk” waiting to be measured because our risk perceptions are inherently subjective, dependent on our understanding of specific dangers (familiar vs. new risks) and on cultural circumstances.[27] Their psychometric studies showed that specific hazards have their unique patterns of highly correlated qualities: involuntary risks are often associated with the dread of new, uncontrollable, and unknown hazards; voluntary hazards are more likely to be perceived as controllable and known to science. Nuclear electricity generation is widely perceived as unsafe, x-rays as tolerably risky.

恐惧感在风险感知中扮演着举足轻重的角色。恐怖袭击或许是这种差异化容忍度的最佳例证，因为恐惧会占据主导地位，驱散基于确凿证据的理性评估。由于恐怖袭击的时间、地点和规模都难以预测，因此在心理测量学的恐惧量表上名列前茅。而这种恐惧也被全天候新闻频道上的专家们利用，他们炮制了大量夸张的伪分析：在过去的二十年里，他们臆测了各种各样的恐怖袭击，从在曼哈顿中城引爆手提箱大小的核弹，到毒害为大城市供水的蓄水池，再到喷洒致命的基因改造病毒，无所不包。

Feelings of dread play an outsized role in risk perception. Terrorist attacks are perhaps the best example of this differentiated tolerance, as fear takes over and drives out rational assessment readily made on the basis of incontrovertible evidence. Because of their unpredictable timing, location, and scale, terrorist attacks rank high on the psychometric scale of dread, and these fears have been intensively exploited by vastly exaggerated pseudo-analyses offered by talking heads on 24/7 news channels: during the past two decades they have speculated on everything from suitcase-sized nuclear bombs detonated in mid-Manhattan to the poisoning of reservoirs used to supply drinking water to large cities and the spraying of deadly engineered viruses.

与此类可怕的袭击相比，驾驶带来的风险大多是自愿的、高度重复的，而且非常常见；意外死亡事件绝大多数（超过 90% 的案例）每次致命碰撞仅造成一人死亡。因此，社会容忍了每年超过 120 万人的全球死亡人数，但如果死亡人数是工业厂房或大城市及其附近建筑物（桥梁、建筑物）的反复事故，即使此类灾难的年度死亡总人数“仅仅”只有几十万人，社会也绝不会容忍这种情况。[28]

Compared to such dreaded attacks, driving presents largely voluntary, highly recurrent, and very familiar risks, and accidental deaths involve overwhelmingly (more than 90 percent of cases) only one person per fatal collision. As a result, societies tolerate the global toll exceeding 1.2 million deaths a year, something they would never assent to if it were to take the form of recurrent accidents in industrial plants or collapsed structures (bridges, buildings) in or near large cities, even if the combined annual death toll of such disasters was an order of magnitude smaller—“just” in the hundreds of thousands of fatalities.[28]

个人对风险承受能力的巨大差异，最能体现在许多人自愿且反复地参与一些活动上，而这些活动在其他人看来不仅风险过高，甚至明显属于寻死之举。定点跳伞（固定目标跳伞）就是一个绝佳的例子，因为打开降落伞哪怕稍有延迟都可能致命——自由落体会在几秒钟内达到致命速度。[29]此外，还有一些人出于宿命论的信念而对风险承受能力持合理态度：疾病或事故是命中注定且不可避免的，因此无需冒险。有意识地通过适当的个人行动来改善自身健康或预防意外事故。[30]

Large differences in individual tolerance of risk are best illustrated by the fact that many individuals engage—voluntarily and repeatedly—in activities that others might consider not just too risky but belonging all too clearly to the category of death wish. Base (fixed object) jumping is an excellent example of such an activity, as the slightest delay in opening the parachute may cost a life—a free-falling body reaches fatal velocity in a matter of seconds.[29] And then there is risk tolerance justified by fatalistic beliefs: diseases or accidents are predestined and inevitable, and hence it makes no sense to try enhancing one’s health or preventing mishaps by appropriate personal action.[30]

宿命论者往往会低估风险，以避免分析风险并得出实际结论所需的努力，也因为他们觉得自己完全无力应对风险。[31]交通宿命论已被深入研究。抱有宿命论的驾驶员会低估危险的驾驶情况，不太可能采取防御性驾驶措施（例如避免分心、保持安全车距、不超速），也不太可能给孩子系安全带或报告交通事故。令人担忧的是，一些国家的研究发现，出租车司机中普遍存在交通宿命论，而小巴司机中更是普遍存在。[32]

Fatalistic people also underestimate risks in order to avoid the effort required to analyze them and draw practical conclusions, and because they feel totally unable to cope with them.[31] Traffic fatalism has been particularly well studied. Fatalistic drivers underestimate dangerous driving situations, are less likely to practice defensive driving (no distractions, keeping safe trailing distance, no speeding), and are less likely to restrain their children with seat belts or to report involvement in road accidents. Worryingly, studies in some countries found traffic fatalism prevalent among taxi drivers, and pervasive among minibus drivers.[32]

我们几乎无法将定点跳伞者变成规避风险行为的典范，也无法说服众多出租车司机相信他们的事故并非命中注定。但我们可以运用目前对风险的最佳理解——包括日常生活中的风险以及那些极其罕见但可能致命的风险——来量化其后果，从而比较它们的影响。这并非易事，因为我们需要处理如此多种多样的事件和过程。此外，没有完美的衡量标准，也无法找到一个通用的衡量标准，来比较数十亿人每天面临的普遍风险与那些百年、千年甚至万年才发生一次，却会造成全球灾难性后果的极其罕见的事件。无论如何，这正是我将要尝试做的。

There is little we can do to convert base jumpers into paragons of risk-averse behavior or to convince many taxi drivers that their accidents are not predetermined. But we can use the best available understanding of risks, both of those in everyday life and those that are exceedingly uncommon but potentially deadly, to quantify their consequences and hence to compare their impacts. This is not an easy task, because we have to deal with such a variety of events and processes. Moreover, there is no perfect metric to do so, and there can be no universal yardstick to compare the ubiquitous risks faced daily by billions of individuals with the extraordinarily rare events that may take place just once in a hundred, a thousand, or even ten thousand years, but with catastrophic global consequences. In any case, that is what I will try to do.

量化日常生活中的风险

Quantifying the risks of everyday life

对老年人来说，危险甚至在醒来之前就开始了：心脏病发作（急性心肌梗塞）在昼夜交替的过渡时期更为常见，也更为严重。[33]老年人起床后最常见的受伤方式之一就是跌倒。在美国，每年发生数百万起意外跌倒事故，造成瘀伤或骨折，并导致超过36,000人死亡，其中70岁以上的老年人比例过高，而且往往……并非上下楼梯时发生，而是在失去平衡或被地毯边缘绊倒时发生。[34]而一旦进入厨房，就会面临与食物相关的风险，例如未煮熟的鸡蛋中的沙门氏菌，以及茶叶中的农药残留（虽然含量极低，但对于饮用非有机茶的人来说，却是每天都会接触到的）。[35]

For older people the danger starts even before waking up: heart attacks (acute myocardial infarctions) are more common, and more severe, during the dark-to-light transition period.[33] When they get up, one of the most common ways older people injure themselves is to fall. In the US, millions of accidental falls take place every year, leaving bruises or broken bones—and more than 36,000 deaths, disproportionately among those more than 70 years old, and often occurring not when walking up or down stairs but when simply losing balance or tripping over a carpet edge.[34] And once you make it to your kitchen there are food-associated risks, from Salmonella in improperly cooked eggs to pesticide residue in tea (this is a minuscule but, for drinkers of non-organic tea, everyday exposure).[35]

清晨驾车可能行驶在结冰的路面上，或者吸毒后驾驶的司机可能闯红灯。你办公室的墙壁可能仍然隐藏着老旧的石棉隔热材料，而故障的空调可能会传播军团菌。你的同事可能会让你感染季节性流感，或者（就像2020-2021年、2009年、1968年和1957年发生的那样）感染一种新的流行病毒。你可能会对误混入无坚果巧克力棒中的坚果产生严重的过敏反应。如果德克萨斯州或俄克拉荷马州正值龙卷风季节，你下班回家后可能会发现你的家变成了一堆瓦砾；如果你住在巴尔的摩，你不可能对这座城市的凶杀率漠不关心，因为巴尔的摩的凶杀率比以帮派闻名的洛杉矶高出一个数量级。[36]而且，由于几乎没有仿制药是在美国本土生产的（它们大多来自中国和印度），你的药店可能不会给你配药，因为一批受污染的药品已被召回。[37]

A morning drive may be on an icy road or a drugged-up driver could go through a red light. Your office walls may still hide old asbestos insulation, and faulty air conditioning may spread Legionella bacteria. Your coworkers may infect you with seasonal flu or (as happened in 2020–2021, 2009, 1968, and 1957) with a new pandemic virus. You may have a severe allergic reaction to a nut accidentally admixed into a nut-free chocolate bar. If it is tornado season in Texas or Oklahoma you might return from work to see your home turned into a pile of rubble, and if you live in Baltimore you cannot remain unconcerned about the city’s homicide rate that is an order of magnitude higher than in Los Angeles, the city famous for its gangs.[36] And as hardly any generic drugs are made domestically (they come mostly from China and India), your drugstore may not fill your prescription because a contaminated batch was pulled from distribution.[37]

详细的年龄和性别特定死亡率数据显示，随着人们年龄的增长，罹患致命疾病的原因（以及由此产生的担忧）也会发生变化。最新统计数据显示，在英格兰和威尔士的男性中，心脏病在50岁出头到70岁末期是主要死因；而对于女性来说，乳腺癌在30岁中期成为最令人恐惧的疾病，并一直持续到60岁中期；之后，肺癌成为女性最大的单一死因；而痴呆症和阿尔茨海默病最近取代缺血性心脏病，成为80岁以上男女的主要死因。[38]

And detailed data on age- and sex-specific death rates show how the reasons for (and hence the concerns about) getting mortally sick change as people grow older. The latest statistics show that among males in England and Wales heart disease dominates from the early 50s to the late 70s, and for women breast cancer becomes the most dreaded disease by their mid-30s and it remains so until their mid-60s; afterwards, lung cancer is the single largest cause of death among females, and dementia and Alzheimer’s disease have recently displaced ischemic heart disease as the leading cause of death for both sexes over 80 years of age.[38]

量化常见风险似乎是一项艰巨的任务。如何比较因异常严重的季节性流感疫情而死亡的风险与偶尔周末划皮艇或驾驶雪地摩托导致致命伤害的风险？或者，如何比较频繁跨太平洋飞行的风险与经常食用可能反复被大肠杆菌污染的加州产生菜的风险？我们又该如何表达致命风险？按标准数量计算……受影响人群的人数（1000人；100万人）是多少？每单位有害物质、每单位暴露时间还是每单位环境浓度？

Quantifying common risks seems to be a daunting enterprise. How does one compare the risks of dying due to an unusually severe seasonal influenza epidemic to the risk of a mortal injury resulting from occasional weekend kayaking or snowmobiling; or the risk of frequent transpacific flying to the risk of habitual eating of California-grown lettuce that might be repeatedly contaminated with Escherichia coli? And how do we express fatal risks? Per standard number of people (1,000; 1 million) in an affected population? Per unit of hazardous substance, per unit of time exposure, or per unit of ambient concentration?

显然，要找到一个能够涵盖死亡、受伤或经济损失（这些损失的总额在不同社会之间可能相差几个数量级）以及慢性疼痛（众所周知，慢性疼痛难以量化）的统一指标是不可能的。但是，死亡的终结性提供了一个普遍的、最终的、无可争议的量化指标，可用于风险比较评估。进行一些有启发性的比较的最简单、最直接的方法是使用一个标准分母，并比较每10万人的年度死亡原因频率。使用美国统计数据（最新公布的详细分类数据为2017年）时，会得出一些令人惊讶的结果。[39]

A uniform metric able to subsume fatalities and injuries or economic losses (whose totals could differ by orders of magnitude among different societies) and chronic pain (something that remains notoriously unquantifiable) is clearly an impossible objective. But the finality of dying provides a universal, ultimate, and incontestably quantifiable numerator that can be used for comparative risk assessment. The simplest and most obvious way to make some revealing comparisons is to use a standard denominator and to compare annual frequencies of causes of death per 100,000 people. When using the US statistics (the latest published detailed breakdown is for 2017) this leads to some surprising outcomes.[39]

凶杀案造成的死亡人数几乎与白血病相当（6人对7.2人），这既体现了白血病治疗的进步，也反映了美国社会令人震惊的暴力。意外跌倒造成的死亡人数几乎与可怕的胰腺癌相当，后者确诊后的生存期很短（11.2人对13.5人）。交通事故造成的死亡人数是糖尿病的两倍（而且死者往往更年轻）（52.2人对25.7人），意外中毒和有害物质造成的死亡人数也高于乳腺癌（19.9人对13.1人）。但这些比较都使用了相同的分母（10万人），而没有考虑特定死因的暴露时间长短。凶杀案可能发生在公共场所和私人场所，也可能发生在白天或晚上的任何时间，因此，人们一年365天、一天24小时都面临着这种风险——但机动车事故（包括导致行人死亡的事故）只会在有人驾驶时发生，而大多数美国人每天开车的时间只有大约一个小时。

Homicides take almost as many lives as leukemia (6 vs. 7.2), a dual testament to the advances in treating that malignancy and to the extraordinary violence of American society. Accidental falls kill almost as many people as the dreaded pancreatic cancer with its short post-diagnosis survival (11.2 vs. 13.5). Motor vehicle accidents take twice as many lives (and, moreover, much younger ones) than does diabetes (52.2 vs. 25.7), and accidental poisoning and noxious substances exact a higher death toll than does breast cancer (19.9 vs. 13.1). But these comparisons use the same denominator (100,000 people) without taking into account the duration of exposure to a given cause of death. Homicides can, and do, take place in public and private and at any time of day or night, and the exposure to this risk is thus 24 hours a day, 365 days a year—but motor vehicle accidents (including those that kill pedestrians) can happen only when somebody is driving, and most Americans spend only about an hour behind the wheel every day.

因此，更具洞察力的衡量标准是，以人们受特定风险影响的时间作为共同分母，并以每人每小时暴露死亡人数进行比较——也就是说，以个人自愿或非自愿地暴露于特定风险的时间作为衡量标准。这种方法由昌西·斯塔尔于1969年提出，用于评估社会效益和风险。技术风险，我仍然认为它比另一个通用指标——微死亡率——更可取。[40]这些单位定义了微概率，即每次特定暴露导致死亡的百万分之一的概率，并以每年、每天、每次手术、每次航班或每段行程距离来表示——而这些不统一的分母使得进行全面的比较变得困难。

A more insightful metric then is to use the time during which people are affected by a given risk as the common denominator, and do the comparisons in terms of fatalities per person per hour of exposure—that is, the time when an individual is subject, involuntarily or voluntarily, to a specific risk. This approach was introduced in 1969 by Chauncey Starr in his evaluation of social benefits and technological risks and I still find it preferable to another general metric—that of micromorts.[40] These units define a micro probability, a one-in-a-million chance of death per specific exposure, and express it per year, per day, per surgery, per flight, or per distance traveled—and these non-uniform denominators do not make for easy across-the-board comparisons.

全球范围内对总死亡率（每千人）的监测十分完善，既包括总体人口死亡率，也包括按性别和特定年龄组划分的死亡率。[41]总死亡率很大程度上取决于人口的平均年龄。2019年，全球平均死亡率为7.6‰，而肯尼亚的死亡率（尽管营养和医疗保健水平较低）不到德国的一半（5.4‰对11.3‰），这是因为肯尼亚的中位年龄仅为20岁，不到德国47岁的一半。特定疾病导致的死亡数据也通常可得——在美国，心血管疾病占总死亡人数的四分之一（2.5/1,000），癌症占五分之一（2/1,000）——因伤害（跌倒导致的死亡人数约为1.4，交通事故导致的死亡人数约为1.1），与动物接触导致的死亡人数约为0.7，意外中毒导致的死亡人数仅为0.03）和自然灾害导致的死亡数据也同样可得。[42]

Overall death rates (per 1,000 people) are well monitored worldwide, both for populations at large and for each sex by specific age group.[41] Overall mortality depends heavily on the population’s average age. In 2019 the global mean was 7.6/1,000, while Kenya’s mortality (despite a lower standard of nutrition and health care) was less than half of the German rate (5.4 vs. 11.3) because Kenya’s median age of just 20 years is less than half of Germany’s 47 years. Data on deaths due to specific diseases are also commonly available—with cardiovascular diseases accounting for a quarter of the total in the US (2.5/1,000) and cancers for a fifth (2/1,000)—as is the information on deaths due to injuries (ranging from about 1.4 for falls and 1.1 for transport accidents, to 0.7 for encounters with animals and just 0.03 for accidental poisonings) and natural disasters.[42]

全年（闰年修正后为8766小时）是计算总体死亡率、慢性病死亡率以及地震或火山爆发等随时可能发生的自然灾害死亡率的分母。但要计算诸如驾车或飞行等常见活动的风险，我们首先需要确定从事这些活动的特定人群总数，然后估算其年平均暴露时间。同样的道理也适用于量化飓风或龙卷风造成的死亡风险：这些气旋并非全年每天都会出现，也不会影响到整个大国。

The entire year (8,766 hours when corrected for leap years) is the denominator for overall mortality, for chronic diseases, and for natural disasters such as earthquakes or volcanic eruptions that can strike anytime. But in order to calculate risks for such common activities as driving or flying, we have to ascertain first the totals of specific populations engaged in these activities and then to estimate the average hours of annual exposure. The same sequence applies to quantifying the risks of dying in a hurricane or a tornado: these cyclones are not around every day of the year and do not affect the entirety of large countries.

计算基线，即总体人群或按性别和年龄划分的平均总体死亡风险，很容易。2019年，富裕（发达）国家的总体死亡率（粗死亡率）集中在10/1000左右，实际死亡率从北美的8.7到日本的10.7，再到欧洲的11.1不等。每年10/1000的死亡率（假设1000人面临死亡风险的时间为8766 × 1000小时）按比例换算为每人每小时0.000001或1 × 10⁻⁶。心血管疾病疾病是所有富裕国家的主要死因，约占总死亡人数的四分之一（3 × 10⁻⁷ ）。季节性流感的风险比疾病低一个数量级（通常约为 2 × 10⁻⁸ ，最高可达 3 × 10⁻⁸ ），即使在暴力事件频发的美国，近期因疾病导致的死亡风险也仅为每小时7 × 10⁻⁹ ，是跌倒致死风险（1.4 × 10⁻⁸）的一半。但是，如前所述，后一种意外死亡的发生率存在显著差异，85 岁以上人群的风险为 3 × 10⁻⁷，而25至 34 岁人群的风险仅为 9 × 10⁻¹⁰ 。 [ 43]

Calculating the baseline, the average population-wide or sex- and age-specific risk of overall mortality, is easy. In 2019, overall mortality (crude death rate) of well-off (developed) countries clustered at around 10/1,000, with actual rates ranging from 8.7 for North America to 10.7 in Japan and 11.1 for Europe. That annual mortality of 10/1,000 (with 1,000 people subject to dying for 8,766 × 1,000 hours) prorates to 0.000001 or 1 × 10-6 per person per hour of exposure. Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of mortality in all affluent countries and they account for nearly a quarter of that total (3 × 10-7). Seasonal influenza carries a risk an order of magnitude lower (usually about 2 × 10-8 and up to 3 × 10-8), and even in the violence-prone United States the risk of homicide has recently been just 7 × 10-9 per hour of exposure, half the risk of death attributable to falls (1.4 × 10-8). But, as already noted, the frequency of the latter kind of accidental death is highly skewed, with people over 85 years of age having a risk of 3 × 10-7 compared to just 9 × 10-10 for people 25–34 years old.[43]

为了反驳关于总体死亡率的结论，在富裕国家，自然死亡的总体风险相当于每小时每百万人中有一人死亡；每小时约有三百万人中有一人死于心脏病，约七千万人中有一人死于意外跌倒。这样的概率足够低，不会让任何富裕国家的普通公民感到担忧。性别和年龄相关的具体数字必然有所不同。加拿大男女的总体死亡率为千分之七，但年轻男性（20-24岁）的死亡率仅为千分之八，而我这个年龄段（75-79岁）的男性死亡率则高达千分之三十五，因此我这个年龄段的男性每小时的死亡风险为每人4×10⁻⁶ ，是人口平均水平的四倍。[44]

To reverse the conclusion about general mortality, in affluent countries the overall risk of natural demise amounts to 1 person among 1 million dying every hour; every hour, 1 person among about 3 million dies of heart disease and 1 among roughly 70 million dies of an accidental fall. Such odds are sufficiently low not to preoccupy an average citizen of any affluent country. Sex- and age-specific numbers are, inevitably, different. While Canada’s overall mortality for both sexes is 7.7/1,000, for young (20–24 years) males it is only 0.8/1,000 but for men of my age (75–79 years) it is 35/1,000, and my group’s risk is then 4 × 10-6 per person per every hour of being alive, four times the rate for the population average.[44]

在量化志愿活动的风险之前，我应该先阐明住院治疗的风险。由于多种原因（在许多国家，越来越多的人因选择性美容手术而住院），住院治疗不可避免，而高患者周转率也增加了医疗事故发生的可能性。1999年，首项关于可预防医疗事故的研究发现，美国每年发生44,000至98,000起此类事故。[45]这是一个令人不安的高数字——2016年的一项新研究将这一数字提高到2013年的251,454例（死亡人数可能高达400,000人），使其成为当年美国第三大死因，仅次于心脏病（611,000人）和癌症（585,000人），高于慢性呼吸系统疾病（149,000人）。[46]这些结果在大众媒体上广泛报道，表明该国每年所有医院死亡病例中有 35% 至 58% 是由于医疗事故造成的。

Before I turn to quantifying the risks of voluntary activities, I should clarify the dangers associated with hospital stays. They are unavoidable because of many conditions (and in many countries also increasingly for elective cosmetic surgeries), and high patient throughputs make it more likely that medical errors will happen. In 1999, the first study of preventable medical errors found that anywhere between 44,000 and 98,000 of them are made in the US every year.[45] That was an uncomfortably high total—and in 2016 a new study raised it to 251,454 cases in 2013 (and possibly to as many as 400,000 deaths), making it the third-highest cause of US mortality in that year, behind heart disease (611,000) and cancers (585,000) and ahead of chronic respiratory disease (149,000).[46] These results, widely reported in the mass media, implied that every year 35–58 percent of all hospital deaths in the country were due to medical error.

这样看来，这些说法的不合理之处就显而易见了：粗心大意的错误固然会发生，令人遗憾的疏忽也难免。这种情况确实会发生，但如果它们占到所有医院死亡人数的三分之一到五分之三以上，那就足以证明现代医学极其无能，甚至可以说是犯罪。幸运的是，这些高死亡率并非源于粗心大意，而是数据处理错误。[47]最新一项关于医疗不良反应相关死亡率（AEMT）的研究澄清了事实：该研究发现，1990年至2016年间，此类死亡人数为123,063人（主要由手术和围手术期错误导致），下降了21.4%，降至每10万人中1.15例AEMT死亡。[48]

When put in this way, the implausibility of those claims become easily evident: careless errors surely take place, regrettable omissions do happen, but that they could add up to anywhere between just over a third and nearly three-fifths of all hospital deaths would brand modern medicine as an extraordinarily inept, if not outright criminal, endeavor. Fortunately, these high mortalities did not result from carelessness but from data-handling errors.[47] The latest study of mortality associated with adverse effects of medical treatment (AEMT) sets the record straight: it found 123,063 such deaths between 1990 and 2016 (mostly due to surgical and perioperative errors), a decline of 21.4 percent to 1.15 AEMT deaths per 100,000 people.[48]

男性和女性的死亡率相似，但各州之间存在显著差异，加利福尼亚州的死亡率低至每10万人0.84例急诊医疗事故死亡。绝对值计算，平均每年约有4750人死亡，不到2016年公布的最低估计值的2%。[49]换算成相对风险指标，这意味着每小时暴露于急诊医疗事故的死亡人数约为1.2 × 10⁻⁶ ，也就是说，本书的任何一位老年男性读者（其总体死亡风险在3 × 10⁻⁶至5 × 10⁻⁶之间）在普通美国医院住院的几天内，因急诊医疗事故死亡的风险最多只会增加20%至30%——我认为，这是一个非常令人鼓舞的风险发现！

Men and women had similar rates, but states differed significantly, with California as low as 0.84 AEMT deaths per 100,000. In absolute terms this averages to about 4,750 deaths a year, less than 2 percent of the lowest estimate published in 2016.[49] Translated into a comparative risk metric, this results in about 1.2 × 10-6 fatalities per hour of exposure, which means that any elderly male reader of this book (whose general mortality risk is between 3 × 10-6 and 5 × 10-6) will increase his risk of demise due to AEMT by no more than about 20–30 percent during the few days of an average stay in an American hospital—and that, I would argue, is a very encouraging risk finding!

自愿风险和非自愿风险

Voluntary and involuntary risks

我们自愿参与各种风险程度不一的活动，究竟会将这些基本风险，或与诸如紧急手术或因医疗评估而需短期住院等不可避免的事件相关的风险，增加到什么程度？我们又该对地震、洪水等自然灾害造成的不可避免的非自愿风险担忧到什么程度？

How much do we increase these baseline risks, or risks associated with such unavoidable events as emergency operations or short hospital stays required for medical evaluations, by voluntary exposures through participating in a wide variety of more or less risky endeavors? And how much should we worry about unavoidable involuntary risk resulting from natural hazards ranging from earthquakes to floods?

如前所述，这些分类对于风险评估很有用，但自愿暴露和非自愿暴露之间的区别并非总是显而易见的。有些活动显然属于自愿行为（而且风险相当高甚至非常高），例如吸烟或参与极限运动；而有些非自愿风险则显然无法避免，无论是在个人层面（包括被陨石击中的极低风险）。而且是集体性的，甚至是全球性的经历（地球与小行星相撞就是最典型的例子）。

As already noted, these are useful categories for risk assessment, but the distinction between voluntary and involuntary exposures is not always obvious. There are clear-cut voluntary (and fairly to very risky) activities such as smoking or engaging in extreme sports; and obviously unavoidable involuntary risks both at an individual level (including the exceedingly low danger of being hit by a meteorite) and as collective, indeed a planet-wide, experiences (the Earth colliding with an asteroid being the foremost example).

但许多风险因素难以如此轻易地界定，因为自愿风险和非自愿风险之间并没有明确的界限：对于一个在郊区建造了梦想家园的家庭来说，开车上班或许是他们的选择；但对于北美数百万公共交通系统出了名的糟糕的人来说，开车上班却是迫不得已的必需。如果一个年轻人想留在纽芬兰，除了当渔民或在大型石油生产平台上工作之外，他几乎没有其他选择，而这两种职业的风险都远高于搬到多伦多，学习编程，然后在远离北大西洋岩石的玻璃办公室里编写应用程序。

But many risky exposures cannot be so easily assigned, because there is no clear dichotomy between voluntary and involuntary risks: driving to work may be a matter of choice for a family that built a dream exurban house, but it is a matter of unavoidable necessity for millions of people in North America with its notoriously poor mass transit systems. And if a young man wants to stay in Newfoundland, there are not that many choices beyond becoming a fisherman or a worker on a massive oil-producing platform, both being far more risky occupations than moving to Toronto, learning how to code, and writing apps in a glassed office far away from the rock jutting into the North Atlantic.

考虑到这些复杂因素，我首先要解释驾车和飞行相关的风险。这两项活动在全球范围内涉及数亿车辆驾驶员和乘客，近年来每天还有超过1000万付费乘客乘坐飞机。对于这两项活动，我们首先必须准确统计死亡人数，然后做出必要的假设，以确定受影响人群及其暴露于特定风险的总时间。

Keeping these complications in mind, I will first explain the risks associated with driving and flying, activities that globally involve hundreds of millions of vehicle drivers and passengers and recently more than 10 million paying fliers every day. For both activities, we must start by accurately counting the number of deaths and then deploying necessary assumptions in order to define affected populations and their aggregate time of exposure to a given risk.

对于驾驶而言，显然是指坐在驾驶座上（或作为乘客）的时间。在美国，我们统计了所有机动车辆和乘用车每年的行驶里程（最近的总里程约为每年5.2万亿公里），而交通事故死亡人数在多年下降后略有上升，达到每年约4万人。[50]为了估算驾驶时间，我们需要用行驶里程除以平均速度——显然，这个数字只能是一个勉强说得通的近似值，而非精确值。城际速度波动较小，但城市速度在高峰时段往往会下降多达40%。假设平均综合速度为65公里/小时（约40英里/小时），那么美国每年的驾驶时间约为800亿小时，而每年4万人死亡，这意味着每小时的死亡人数恰好为5 × 10⁻⁷（0.0000005）。即使将交通事故死亡人数也包括被车辆撞死的行人和路人，或者采用其他合理的平均速度（例如 50 或 70 公里/小时），也不会改变以下事实：开车比坐飞机危险一个数量级，开车时，一个人死亡的平均几率比待在家里或照料花园（只要不涉及爬高梯子或使用大型电锯）时高出约 50%。

For driving it is obviously time spent behind the wheel (or as a passenger). For the US we have totals of distances traveled every year by all motor vehicles and by passenger cars (a recent grand total has been about 5.2 trillion kilometers annually) and, after declining for many years, traffic fatalities have gone up slightly to about 40,000 a year.[50] In order to estimate the time spent driving, we have to divide the distance driven by average speed—and, obviously, this number can be only a defensible approximation, not an accurate rate. Intercity speeds show less variation, but urban speeds tend to drop by as much as 40 percent during recurrent rush hours. Assuming an average combined speed of 65 km/hour (about 40 mph) gives us annually about 80 billion driving hours in the US, and with 40,000 fatalities this translates exactly to 5 × 10-7 (0.0000005) fatalities per hour of exposure. Neither the fact that traffic fatalities also include pedestrians and bystanders killed by vehicles nor the deployment of other plausible average speeds (say, 50 or 70 km/hour) would change the order of magnitude. Driving is an order of magnitude more dangerous than flying, and during the time a person is driving the average chance of dying goes up by about 50 percent compared to staying at home or tending a garden (as long as that does not include climbing a tall ladder or working with a large chainsaw).

对于我这个年龄段的男性来说，驾驶风险仅比总体死亡风险高出12%。美国的驾驶风险也因性别和人口群体而存在显著差异。亚裔美国女性一生中死于机动车事故的风险仅为0.34%（291人中1人），而美洲原住民男性则为1.75%（57人中1人），所有人群的风险为0.92%（109人中1人）。[51]当然，在其他一些国家，人们的驾驶里程远低于美国和加拿大，但事故率却高得多（巴西的事故率约为美国的两倍，撒哈拉以南非洲的事故率约为美国的三倍），因此风险要高出一个数量级。[52]

And for men of my age group the driving-risk bump is only 12 percent above the overall risk of dying. Driving risks in the US also show significant differences due to gender and population groups. The lifetime risk of dying in a motor vehicle accident is only 0.34 percent for Asian American females (1 out of 291) but 1.75 percent (1 of every 57) for Native American males, while the risk for all individuals is 0.92 percent (1 out of 109).[51] Of course, in other countries where people drive much less than Americans and Canadians but where the accident rates are much higher (they are about twice as common in Brazil, three times as much in sub-Saharan Africa), the risks are up to an order of magnitude greater.[52]

上世纪末，定期商业航班的风险已经非常低，而进入21世纪的头二十年，其安全性更是显著提高。尽管近期发生了一些令人不安的事故，例如2014年3月马来西亚航空370号航班在印度洋上空失踪（至今仍未解开谜团，而且很可能永远无法解释），以及随后2014年7月马来西亚航空17号航班在乌克兰东部被击落，还有两起波音737 MAX客机的坠毁事故——狮航610号航班于2018年10月29日在爪哇海坠毁，埃塞俄比亚航空302号航班于2019年3月10日在亚的斯亚贝巴附近坠毁。[53]

Scheduled commercial flights, already a very low-risk activity at the end of the last century, got appreciably safer during the first two decades of the 21st century. This conclusion stands despite some disturbing recent losses, including the still-unsolved (and likely never to be explained) disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight 370 somewhere over the Indian Ocean in March 2014, followed by the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight 17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014, and the two crashes of the new Boeing 737 MAX—Lion Air flight 610 in the Java Sea (October 29, 2018) and Ethiopian Airlines flight 302 near Addis Ababa (March 10, 2019).[53]

或许，比较航空业死亡人数最直观的方式是计算每1000亿客公里飞行里程的死亡率。2010年，这一比率为14.3，2017年降至历史最低点0.65，但2019年又上升至2.75。因此，2019年的飞行安全程度是2010年的五倍多，是20世纪50年代末喷气式客机时代初期的200倍多。[54]将这些死亡人数换算成每小时暴露风险来表示就相当简单了。2015年至2019年，意外死亡人数的平均总数为292人；平均飞行里程为68万亿客公里，乘客人数为42亿，这意味着平均每位乘客飞行约1900公里，暴露时间约为2.5小时。飞行时间总计约105亿乘客小时，其中292人死亡，这意味着每人每小时飞行死亡人数为2.8 × 10⁻⁸ ( 0.000000028)。这仅占飞行中总体死亡风险的约3%，而对于一位七旬男性来说，飞行中的死亡风险也仅增加1%。任何理智的常旅客（尤其是老年人）都应该更担心遇到意外延误、经历繁琐的安检、忍受长途飞行的枯燥乏味以及应对时差带来的种种不适。

Perhaps the most revealing way to compare the airline industry’s fatalities is per 100 billion passenger-kilometers flown. This rate was 14.3 in 2010, it reached a record low of 0.65 in 2017, but it increased to 2.75 in 2019. Flying in 2019 was thus more than five times safer than in 2010, and more than 200 times safer than at the beginning of the jetliner era in the late 1950s.[54] Expressing these fatalities in terms of risks per hour of exposure is fairly straightforward. The mean 2015–2019 total of accidental deaths was 292; the averages of 68 trillion passenger-kilometers flown and 4.2 billion passengers mean that average passengers flew about 1,900 kilometers and spent about 2.5 hours in flight; the total of about 10.5 billion passenger-hours spent aloft and 292 fatalities translates to 2.8 × 10-8 (0.000000028) fatalities per person per hour of flying. This is only about 3 percent of the general risk of mortality while aloft, and in the case of a septuagenarian male the risk while aloft rises by a mere 1 percent. Any rational frequent flyer (and even more so an elderly one) should worry more about encountering unforeseen delays, running the security theater gauntlet, enduring the tedium of long-distance flying, and coping with the debilitating effects of jetlag.

在自愿风险谱的另一端，是那些持续时间短但死亡概率极高的活动。其中风险最高的莫过于从悬崖、高塔、桥梁和建筑物上进行定点跳伞。一项针对这种“自找苦吃”的疯狂行为的最可靠研究，考察了挪威谢拉格山脉长达11年的跳伞活动，结果显示，每2317次跳伞中就有1次（共9次）导致死亡[55] ，平均暴露风险为4 × 10⁻² ( 0.04)。相比之下，过去高空跳伞的致命事故发生率约为每10万次跳伞一次，但最新的美国数据显示，每25万次跳伞就会发生1起死亡事故。典型的定点跳伞下降过程持续5分钟，其暴露风险约为5 × 10⁻⁵ ，虽然仍然比坐在椅子上5分钟高出50倍，但仅为定点跳伞风险的千分之一左右。[56]同样，只有极少数人真正了解这些具体数字，但几乎所有人（除了少数敢于冒险的人）都表现得好像他们已经内化了这些数字。

At the opposite end of the voluntary risk spectrum are activities whose brief duration carries a high probability of death. None is riskier than base jumping from cliffs, towers, bridges, and buildings. The most reliable study of this “asking for it” madness looked at an 11-year period of jumping from the Kjerag Massif in Norway, where 1 in every 2,317 jumps (9 in total) resulted in death,[55] with an average exposure risk of 4 × 10-2 (0.04). For comparison, in skydiving a fatal accident used to take place roughly once every 100,000 jumps but the latest US data show one fatality for every 250,000 jumps. With a typical descent lasting five minutes the exposure risk is only about 5 × 10-5, still 50 times higher than just sitting in a chair for those five minutes—but it is only about 1/1,000 of the risk associated with base jumping.[56] Again, only very few people are actually aware of these specific numbers, but nearly all people (save for the risk-tolerant few) behave as if they have internalized them.

2020年，美国约有2.3亿人持有驾照（驾驶时每人每小时的辐射暴露风险为5 × 10⁻⁷）；约有1200万人是高山滑雪者（下坡时为2 × 10⁻⁷ ）；美国跳伞协会约有3.5万名会员（空中飞行时为5 × 10⁻⁵ ）；美国滑翔伞协会约有3000名会员，他们的活动（飞行时间从20分钟到几小时不等）的死亡风险为10⁻⁴至10⁻³ ；虽然定点跳伞越来越受欢迎（尤其是在挪威和瑞士），但在美国，这项运动仍然仅限于数百名以男性为主的冒险者，他们在短暂的坠落过程中死亡的风险为4 × 10⁻²。[ 57]风险与参与活动的总体人数之间存在着明显的反比关系：很多人愿意冒着肩膀脱臼或脚踝扭伤的风险在压雪道上滑雪下坡；但很少有人愿意从悬崖上纵身跃入深渊。

In 2020 in the US, about 230 million people held a driver’s license (exposure risk behind the wheel is 5 × 10-7 per person per hour); about 12 million were downhill skiers (2 × 10-7 while descending); the United States Parachuting Association has about 35,000 members (5 × 10-5 while aloft); the US Hang Gliding & Paragliding Association has about 3,000 members and what they do (depending on the length of flights lasting anywhere between 20 minutes and a few hours) carries a fatality risk of 10-4 to 10-3; and although base jumping has been increasing in popularity (particularly in Norway and Switzerland), in the US it is still confined to a few hundred mostly male fate-tempters whose risk of dying is 4 × 10-2 during their brief falls.[57] The strong inverse relationship between the risk and overall participation in an activity is obvious: large numbers of people are willing to risk a dislocated shoulder or a sprained ankle while skiing downhill on a groomed run; very few are into launching themselves into the void from precipices.

最后，我们来看几个关于现代最令人恐惧的非自愿暴露风险——恐怖主义风险——的关键数据。1995年至2017年间，美国本土共有3516人死于恐怖袭击，其中2996人（占总数的85%）死于2001年9月11日。[58]因此，在这22年间，全美个人暴露风险平均为6 × 10⁻¹¹ ，而曼哈顿的暴露风险则高出两个数量级，这意味着仅仅活着就面临风险，风险增加了0.1%，这个数值太小，几乎无法被人真正理解和承受。在一些不太富裕的国家，近期恐怖袭击造成的伤亡要高得多：2017 年伊拉克（超过 4,300 人死亡）的风险上升到 1.3 × 10 -8，2018年阿富汗（7,379 人死亡）的风险上升到 2.3 × 10 -8，但即使是这样的比率也只使生存的基本风险增加几个百分点，而且仍然低于人们自愿承担的风险（尤其是在没有车道和临时交通规则的地方）。[59]

Finally, a few key numbers concerning one of the most dreaded modern involuntary exposures: the risk of terrorism. Between 1995 and 2017, 3,516 people died in terrorist attacks on US soil, with 2,996 fatalities (or 85 percent of that total) on September 11, 2001.[58] Countrywide individual exposure risk thus averaged 6 × 10-11 during those 22 years, and for Manhattan it was two orders of magnitude higher, increasing the risk of just being alive by one-tenth of a percent, a quantity that is too small to be meaningfully internalized. In less fortunate countries, the recent toll of terrorist attacks has been much higher: in Iraq in 2017 (with more than 4,300 deaths) the risk rose to 1.3 × 10-8, and in Afghanistan in 2018 (7,379 deaths) to 2.3 × 10-8, but even that rate raises the basic risk of being alive by just a few percent and it remains lower than the risk people voluntarily assume by driving (particularly in places with no lanes and ad hoc traffic rules).[59]

尽管这些比较是正确的，但也揭示了客观量化分析的固有局限性。大多数开车通勤的人只在特定时间开车，每天在路上的时间很少超过一小时或一个半小时，走的是熟悉的路线，而且（除非遇到恶劣天气或意外的交通堵塞）他们感觉一切都在掌控之中。相比之下，在恐怖袭击最猖獗的时期，喀布尔或巴格达的爆炸或枪击事件发生的时间和间隔都难以预测，袭击地点也遍布公共场所——从清真寺到市场——生活在城市里，根本无法完全避免此类威胁。因此，即使人们面临恐怖威胁的概率较低，也伴随着一种难以量化的恐惧感，这种恐惧感与担心早高峰通勤路上的路面湿滑截然不同。

But correct as they are, these comparisons also show the inherent limits of dispassionate quantification. Most people commuting to work by car drive only at specific times, spend rarely more than an hour or an hour and a half per day on the road, follow familiar routes, and (save for inclement weather or an unexpected traffic jam) feel pretty much in control. In contrast, during times of peak terror, bombings or shooting attacks in Kabul or Baghdad took place at unpredictable times and intervals, in many public places—from mosques to markets—and there is no reliable way to completely avoid such threats while living in a city. As a result, the lower exposure rates to terrorist threats carry an unquantifiable accompaniment of dread, qualitatively so different from being concerned about possibly slippery roads during a morning commute.

自然灾害：没有电视上看起来那么危险

Natural hazards: less risky than they look on TV

那么，反复发生的致命自然灾害与仅仅活着本身以及极限运动的风险相比，孰轻孰重？一些国家英国经常遭受一两种灾难性事件的侵袭（但频率不高），例如洪水和强风；而美国每年都要应对许多龙卷风和广泛的洪水，经常遭受飓风（自 2000 年以来，几乎每年都有两个飓风登陆）和暴雪的侵袭，其太平洋沿岸各州也始终面临发生大地震和海啸的风险。[60]

And how do recurrent deadly natural hazards compare with just being alive, and with the risks of extreme sports? Some countries are repeatedly (but not very frequently) subject to just one or two kinds of catastrophic events—flooding and extremely strong winds in the case of the UK—while the US has to cope every year with many tornadoes and extensive flooding, frequently with hurricanes (since the year 2000, nearly two hurricanes a year made a landfall) and heavy snowfalls, and its Pacific states are always at risk of experiencing a major earthquake and possible tsunami.[60]

龙卷风每年都会造成人员伤亡和房屋损毁，详细的历史统计数据使得准确计算暴露风险成为可能。1984 年至 2017 年间，在龙卷风发生频率最高的 21 个州（北达科他州、德克萨斯州、佐治亚州和密歇根州之间的区域，人口约 1.2 亿）共有 1994 人丧生，其中约 80% 的死亡发生在每年的 3 月至 8 月这六个月内。[61]

Tornadoes kill people and destroy homes every year, and detailed historical statistics make it possible to calculate accurate exposure risks. Between 1984 and 2017, 1,994 people were killed in the 21 states with the highest frequency of these destructive cyclones (the region between North Dakota, Texas, Georgia, and Michigan, with about 120 million people), and about 80 percent of those deaths took place in the six months of the year from March to August.[61]

这意味着每小时暴露于龙卷风的死亡人数约为 3 × 10⁻⁹ ( 0.000000003)，这一风险比仅仅存活的风险低三个数量级。美国龙卷风肆虐的州很少有居民了解这一死亡率，但他们和其他经常遭受自然灾害的地区居民一样，都意识到被龙卷风夺去生命的概率非常小，因此继续居住在这些地区的风险是可以接受的。广泛传播的强龙卷风造成的破坏画面，让生活在气候相对温和地区的人们不禁疑惑，为什么有人会说要在原地重建家园。但这样的决定既非不理智，也非鲁莽冒险，正因为如此，数百万人才能继续生活在从德克萨斯州延伸到南达科他州的“龙卷风走廊”上。

This translates to about 3 × 10-9 (0.000000003) fatalities per hour of exposure, a risk that is three orders of magnitude lower than just living. Very few inhabitants of America’s tornado-swept states are aware of this rate but they recognize—as do people in other areas subject to recurrent natural catastrophes—that the probability of being killed by a tornado is sufficiently small, and hence the risk of continued living in such regions remains acceptable. Widely broadcast images of destruction left by powerful tornadoes make viewers living in atmospherically less violent regions wonder why people say that they will rebuild on the same spot. But such decisions are neither irrational nor recklessly risky, and because of them millions of people continue to live in the Tornado Alley that extends from Texas to South Dakota.

值得注意的是，对世界各地其他常见自然灾害的暴露风险计算结果也趋于同一数量级（10⁻⁹ ），甚至更低。同样，这些较低的平均死亡率也解释了为什么各国都接受了地震这一始终存在的风险。1945年至2020年间，日本地震（地震可能影响这个岛国的每个地区）造成约33,000人死亡，其中超过一半的死亡是由2011年3月11日的东日本大地震和海啸造成的（15,899人死亡，2,529人失踪）。[62]但对于一个人口从1945年的7100万增长到2020年近1.27亿的国家来说，这意味着大约……每小时暴露造成的死亡人数为5 × 10 -10 (0.0000000005)，比该国的总体死亡率低四个数量级：显然，在 1 的基础上增加 0.0001 几乎不可能成为改变对生命风险总体评估的决定性因素。

Remarkably, calculations of exposure risks to other commonly encountered natural disasters around the world converge on the same order of magnitude (10-9) or yield even lower rates. Again, these low average fatality exposure rates help to explain why entire countries come to terms with the ever-present risks of earthquakes. Between 1945 and 2020, Japanese earthquakes (which can affect every part of the island nation) killed about 33,000 people, more than half as a result of the March 11, 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami (15,899 deaths and 2,529 missing).[62] But for a population that grew from 71 million in 1945 to nearly 127 million in 2020, that works out to about 5 × 10-10 (0.0000000005) fatalities per hour of exposure, four orders of magnitude lower than the country’s overall mortality rate: obviously adding 0.0001 to 1 can hardly be a decisive factor that changes the overall assessment of life’s risks.

世界大部分地区的洪水和地震造成的暴露风险大多在 1 × 10⁻¹⁰到5 × 10⁻¹⁰之间，而 1960 年后美国飓风（可能影响从德克萨斯州到缅因州沿海各州约 5000 万人，平均每年造成约 50 人死亡）的发生率约为 8 × 10⁻¹¹ 。 [ 63]这是一个非常低的发生率——与大多数人认为的极低自然风险（例如被闪电击中致死）非常相似，甚至可能更低。近年来，美国每年因雷击死亡的人数不到 30 人。假设雷击危险仅限于户外（平均每天 4 小时）以及 4 月至 9 月这六个月（约占所有雷击发生时间的 90%），则风险约为 1 × 10 -10；而将暴露时间延长至 10 个月，则风险降低至 7 × 10 -11 (0.00000000007)。[64]

Floods and earthquakes in most parts of the world carry exposure risks mostly on the order of between 1 × 10-10 and 5 × 10-10, and the post-1960 rate for American hurricanes (potentially affecting about 50 million people in the coastal states from Texas to Maine and killing, on average, about 50 people a year) has been about 8 × 10-11.[63] That is a remarkably low rate—either very similar to or perhaps even lower than what most people would consider an exceptionally low natural risk: being killed by lightning. In recent years, lightning has killed fewer than 30 people a year in the US, and when assuming that the danger applies only when outdoors (averaging four hours a day) and during the six months from April to September (when about 90 percent of all lightning occurs) the risk equals about 1 × 10-10, while extending the exposure period to 10 months lowers it to 7 × 10-11 (0.00000000007).[64]

美国飓风造成的死亡风险如今已与闪电相当，这表明卫星、提前发布的公共预警和疏散措施有效地降低了飓风造成的伤亡。与此同时，我们也应该感到担忧，因为全球自然灾害的年发生频率及其造成的经济损失都在不断增加。我们之所以能够如此确信，是因为全球最大的再保险公司（它们的盈亏取决于地震、飓风、洪水和火灾等不可预测的自然灾害的发生）几十年来一直在密切监测这些趋势。

The fact that US hurricanes now present a fatality risk no greater than lightning illustrates how their toll has been reduced by satellites, advanced public warnings, and evacuations. At the same time, there are reasons for concern, as both the annual worldwide frequency of natural disasters and their economic cost have been increasing. We can say this with a high degree of confidence because the world’s largest reinsurance companies (whose profits and losses depend on the unpredictable occurrences of earthquakes, hurricanes, floods, and fires) have been carefully monitoring their trends for decades.

保险是一种古老的实践，旨在为各种风险提供不同程度的补偿。人寿保险基于高度可预测的生存率，而针对不可预测的重大自然灾害的保险则迫使保险公司通过投保来分担此类灾害带来的风险。因此，全球最大的再保险公司（瑞士再保险公司、德国慕尼黑再保险公司和汉诺威再保险公司、法国SCOR公司、美国伯克希尔哈撒韦公司、英国劳合社）对自然灾害的研究最为深入，因为它们的生存依赖于做出正确的应对。呼吁：为了避免保险损失增加，他们不应该根据过时的数字来设定保险费，因为这些数字会低估未来的风险。

Insurance is an ancient practice of providing different degrees of compensation for a variety of risks. While life insurance is based on highly predictable survival rates, insuring against unpredictable major natural hazards forces insurance companies to share the risk associated with such disasters by securing their own insurance. As a result, the world’s largest reinsurance companies (Swiss Re, German Munich Re and Hannover Rueck, French SCOR, US Berkshire Hathaway, British Lloyd’s) are the most assiduous students of natural catastrophes because their very existence depends on making proper calls: in order to avoid rising insured losses, they should not set their insurance premiums on the basis of outdated numbers that would underestimate future risks.

慕尼黑再保险公司记录的所有自然灾害数量显示出预期的年度波动，但上升趋势十分明显：1950年至1980年间缓慢增长，1980年至2005年间年度发生频率翻了一番，2005年至2019年间增长约60%。[65]总体经济损失（反映重大灾害造成的特殊负担）的年度波动更大，上升趋势也更为显著。以2019年不变价格计算，1990年以前的最高纪录约为1000亿美元，而2011年创下历史新高，略高于3500亿美元，2017年几乎与之持平。保险损失大多占总损失的30%至50%，2017年的最高纪录接近1500亿美元。

Numbers of all natural catastrophes recorded by Munich Re show expected year-to-year fluctuations but the upward trend has been unmistakable: a slow increase between 1950 and 1980, a doubling of annual frequency between 1980 and 2005, and about a 60 percent rise between 2005 and 2019.[65] Overall economic losses (reflecting exceptional burdens stemming from major disasters) show even greater annual fluctuations and an even steeper rising trend. When measured in constant 2019 monies, the pre-1990 record was about $100 billion, while 2011 set an all-time record of just over $350 billion and that total was nearly matched in 2017. Insured losses ranged mostly between 30 and 50 percent of total losses, with the 2017 record reaching nearly $150 billion.

直到20世纪80年代，灾害损失的增加主要归因于风险敞口的扩大（人口和经济的增长导致），虽然这一趋势仍在继续——越来越多的人及其投保的财产居住在易灾地区——但近几十年来，自然灾害本身也发生了变化：大气变暖导致水蒸气含量增加（增加了极端降水的可能性）；一些地区长期干旱导致反复发生持续时间长、强度大的火灾。许多模型预测这些趋势将进一步加剧，但我们也知道，从设立禁区、恢复湿地到制定合理的建筑规范，许多有效措施可以用来减轻其影响。

Until the 1980s, the rising disaster toll was mainly attributable to greater exposure (resulting from growing populations and economies), and while this trend continues—there are more people with more insured property living in disaster-prone regions—recent decades have seen changes in natural hazards themselves: a warmer atmosphere holds more water vapor (increasing the chances of extreme precipitation); prolonged droughts in some regions cause recurrent fires of exceptional duration and intensity. Many models now forecast further intensification of these trends, but we also know that many effective measures—from setting up exclusion zones and restoring wetlands to enacting proper building codes—can be taken to reduce their impacts.

为了进一步降低自然灾害或人为灾害带来的风险，必须寻找真正极端的事件，例如陨石坠落或日益增多的轨道卫星碎片造成的死亡。美国国家研究委员会的一份报告估计，考虑到撞击地球的太空碎片数量，每年应该有91人死亡——这意味着全球77.5亿人口每小时暴露于太空碎片中约有1×10⁻¹²人死亡。但实际上，自1900年以来，没有记录在案的死亡事件，直到最近才出现第一起陨石致人死亡的书面证据。（并导致另一人瘫痪）的记录是在奥斯曼帝国国家档案馆总局的手稿中发现的：该事件发生在1888年8月22日，地点位于如今的伊拉克苏莱曼尼亚。[66]但即使每年有一人丧生，其死亡率也仅为10-14——比活着的概率小八个数量级（仅为1/1亿），因此显然无需担忧。[67]至于轨道上的太空垃圾，截至2019年，大约有34,000块大于10厘米的碎片，以及超过25倍大小的1-10厘米碎片。所有这些碎片在重返大气层时都会解体，但即使是小碎片，在日益拥挤的主轨道空间中也会带来碰撞风险。[68]

In order to get even lower risks from exposures to natural or man-made hazards, one must hunt for truly exceptional events such as people killed by a falling meteorite or by debris from an increasing number of orbiting satellites. A report by the US National Research Council estimated that, given the quantity of space debris hitting the Earth, there should be 91 deaths a year—and that would imply about 1 × 10-12 fatalities per hour of exposure for the global population of 7.75 billion. In reality, there have been no recorded deaths since 1900, and only recently the first written proof of a meteorite killing a man (and leaving another paralyzed) was discovered among the manuscripts in the General Directorate of State Archives of the Ottoman Empire: the event took place on August 22, 1888, in what is now Sulaymaniyah in Iraq.[66] But even if one person were killed every year, the rate would be merely 10-14—or eight orders of magnitude smaller (1/100,000,000 as large) than just being alive, so clearly not a reason to worry.[67] As for the orbiting space junk, by 2019 there were some 34,000 pieces larger than 10 centimeters and more than 25 times as many pieces measuring 1–10 centimeters. All of these pieces break up as they re-enter the atmosphere, but even small pieces present collision risks in increasingly congested prime-orbit space.[68]

终结我们的文明

Ending our civilization

当我们思考那些罕见但极其特殊、影响全球的风险时，尤其是当我们设想那些可能严重破坏甚至终结现代文明的灾难性事件时，我们的思维方式截然不同：这些真实存在（尽管发生概率很低）的风险属于一种完全不同的认知范畴。就像对待任何可能发生在遥远未来的事件一样，我们往往会低估它们的影响。而2020年的疫情再次表明，即使是那些几十年内才会再次发生的风险，我们也长期缺乏应对准备，而非几个世纪或几千年。

When we think about rare but truly extraordinary risks that have global effects, and even more so when we contemplate catastrophic events that could severely damage or even end modern civilization, we do so on an altogether different mental plane: those real (albeit very low) risks belong to a very different perception category. As with every event that might take place in a possibly quite distant future, we strongly discount their impact and, as demonstrated yet again by the 2020 pandemic, we are chronically unprepared to deal even with those risks whose recurrence is measured in decades, not in centuries or millennia.

真正具有全球影响的风险可分为两大类：一类是相对频繁发生的病毒性流行病，它们能在数月或数年内造成巨大损失；另一类是极其罕见但异常致命的自然灾害，它们可能在短短几天、几小时甚至几秒钟内发生，但其后果却可能持续数百年甚至数百万年，远远超出任何文明的视野。如果附近一颗超新星爆炸，并以致命剂量的宇宙射线辐射淹没地球，我们是否有足够的时间（从光到辐射到达地球的时间间隔）为全球大部分人口建造临时避难所？[69]但这真的值得担忧吗？

Risks with truly global impacts fall into two very different categories: relatively frequent viral pandemics that can exact a considerable toll in a matter of months or a few years; and exceedingly rare but uncommonly deadly natural catastrophes that could take place within spans as short as a few days, hours, or seconds but whose consequences might persist not only for centuries but for millions of years, far beyond any civilizational horizons. Should a nearby supernova explode and flood the Earth with lethal doses of radiation from cosmic rays, would we have enough time (between the arrival of light and radiation) to improvise shelters for most of the global population?[69] But should this be a worry at all?

能够破坏地球臭氧层的爆炸必须发生在距离地球不到50光年的范围内，但我们所有可能发生爆炸的“近邻”恒星都远比这远得多。虽然伽马射线暴每1500万年可能在1万光年内影响地球，但有记录以来最近的一次伽马射线暴距离地球也有13亿光年。[70]显然，这种风险很大程度上属于学术范畴——与其猜测它何时发生，鉴于此类事件的频繁性，我们更应该问：比如说，15万年或50万年后，地球上是否还存在文明？尽管地球与小行星碰撞的概率相对较高，但计算未来不可避免的地球与小行星碰撞的风险，同样充满了不确定性和假设，而这些假设的具体细节可能会产生巨大的影响。过去曾发生过与小行星或大型彗星的碰撞，将来也还会发生——但是我们应该认为重大碰撞每 10 万年发生一次，还是每 200 万年发生一次呢？[71]

A blast that would damage the Earth’s ozone layer must take place less than 50 light-years away, but all of our “nearby” stars that might possibly explode are much farther than this, and while a gamma-ray burst could affect Earth from as far as 10,000 light-years once every 15 million years, the closest such burst on record was 1.3 billion light-years away.[70] Clearly, this risk belongs to a largely academic category—rather than guessing when it might happen, we should, given the frequency of such events, better ask: will any terrestrial civilization be around in, say, 150,000 or half a million years? Although it is a comparatively more probable event, calculating the risk of an inevitable future collision of the Earth with an asteroid is another exercise in uncertainties and in assumptions whose particularities can make an enormous difference. Encounters with asteroids or large comets happened in the past and they will happen in the future—but do we assume that a major encounter takes place once every 100,000 years or once every 2 million years?[71]

从地质时间尺度来看，这些时间跨度相对较短，但对于计算每年的潜在风险（更不用说每小时的风险）而言，时间跨度又太长。此外，如果这样的天体撞击南极附近的太平洋，其造成的全球后果将与撞击西欧或中国东部截然不同。在前一种情况下，大部分破坏将来自巨大的海啸，但（取决于小行星的大小）可能只有少量尘埃进入大气层。在后两种情况下，撞击将瞬间摧毁大片人口密集区和工业活动区，并将大量的岩石粉末抛入大气层，造成全球范围内的显著降温。

These are relatively short spans on a geological timescale but are far too long to be used for any revealing calculations of the likely risks per year (to say nothing about per hour of exposure). Moreover, global consequences would be very different if such an object struck the Pacific Ocean near Antarctica than if it hit Western Europe or eastern China. In the first case, much of the damage would come from a monstrous tsunami but (depending on the asteroid’s size) there might be little dust entering the atmosphere. In the second and third cases the impact would instantly obliterate large concentrations of the population and industrial activity, and throw enormous masses of powdered rocks into the atmosphere, creating a pronounced planet-wide cooling.

美国人既不必担心超新星爆发，也不必担心小行星撞击，但如果他们想通过想象一场不可避免的自然灾难（而且这场灾难可能来自他们国家珍视的地方！）来吓唬自己，那么他们应该考虑黄石超级火山的又一次超级喷发。[72]地质证据表明，在过去的1500万年中，黄石超级火山发生了9次喷发，其中最近三次已知的喷发分别发生在210万年前、130万年前和64万年前。当然，仅仅三次喷发的年代测定并不能作为判断未来火山爆发的依据。虽然无法预测任何周期性，但一个想法仍然涌上心头：如果两次喷发之间的平均间隔为 730,000 年，那么我们还有 90,000 年的等待时间；但如果第一次喷发间隔为 800,000 年，第二次喷发间隔为 660,000 年，那么类似的缩短将表明下一个间隔约为 520,000 年——而新的喷发已经超过 100,000 年了！

Americans should not worry either about supernovas or asteroids, but if they want to scare themselves by thinking about an inevitable natural catastrophe (and one that would emanate from one of the country’s cherished places!) then they should consider another mega-eruption of the Yellowstone supervolcano.[72] Geological evidence shows nine eruptions during the past 15 million years, with the last three known eruptions occurring 2.1 million, 1.3 million, and 640,000 years ago. Of course, the dating of just three events offers no basis for predicting any periodicity, but still a thought intrudes: taking the mean interval of 730,000 between eruptions we would have still 90,000 years of waiting left, but if the first interval was 800,000 years and the second one was 660,000 years then a similar shortening would indicate the next span being some 520,000 years—and a new eruption would be already more than 100,000 years overdue!

无论间隔多久，后果都将取决于火山喷发的规模、持续时间和盛行风向。上次喷发释放了约1000立方公里的火山灰，盛行的西北风会将火山灰柱吹过怀俄明州（最厚的沉积层可达数米）、犹他州和科罗拉多州，最终抵达大平原，影响从南达科他州到德克萨斯州的各州，并将美国一些最肥沃的农田掩埋在10至50厘米厚的火山灰之下。如果能够提前预警（得益于持续的地震监测），再加上一次强度较弱、持续时间较长的喷发，大规模疏散或许成为可能。届时，房屋、基础设施和耕地的损失将远远大于任何直接的人员伤亡。薄薄的一层火山灰可以犁入土壤中（实际上还能提高土壤肥力），但较厚的火山灰层将难以处理，一旦被雨水和融雪冲刷掉，就会造成额外的危险，导致淤积和洪水，并在未来几十年内造成问题。

And whatever the interval, the consequences would depend on the magnitude of the eruption, on its duration, and on prevailing winds. The last eruption released about 1,000 cubic kilometers of volcanic ash, and the prevailing northwesterly winds would carry the plume over Wyoming (where the deepest deposits could be several meters thick), Utah, and Colorado and onto the Great Plains, affecting states from South Dakota to Texas and burying some of the country’s most productive agricultural land under 10–50 centimeters of ash. The combination of advance warning (due to constant seismic monitoring) and a weaker, prolonged eruption might make large-scale evacuation possible, and the loss of housing, infrastructure, and cultivable land would then be far greater than any immediate casualties. A thin covering of volcanic ash could be plowed into the soil (and actually improve its fertility), but thicker layers would be unmanageable and they would pose additional dangers once dislodged by rains and snow melt, resulting in silting and flooding and creating problems for decades to come.

或许，最能说明这种自然风险不会直接致人死亡，但却会造成全球范围内的巨大破坏，并导致大量间接伤亡的例子，就是由日冕物质抛射引发的灾难性地磁暴。[73]日冕是太阳大气层的最外层（只有在日全食期间才能用非特殊仪器观测到），矛盾的是，它的温度比太阳表面高数百倍。日冕物质抛射是指大量（数十亿吨）高速物质的爆炸性喷射，这些物质携带着一个强度远超背景太阳风和行星际磁场的嵌入式磁场。日冕抛射始于日冕层下部磁场的扭曲和重构；它们会产生太阳耀斑，并可以传播（不断膨胀）。它们前进的速度慢至不到 250 公里/秒（大约 7 天到达地球），快至接近 3,000 公里/秒（只需 15 小时即可到达地球）。

Perhaps the best example of a natural risk that would not directly kill anybody, but that would cause enormous planet-wide disruptions resulting in a large number of indirect casualties, is the possibility of a catastrophic geomagnetic storm caused by a coronal mass ejection.[73] The corona is the outermost layer of the Sun’s atmosphere (it can be seen without special instruments only during a total solar eclipse) and is, paradoxically, hundreds of times hotter than the Sun’s surface. Coronal mass ejections are enormous (billions of tons) expulsions of explosively accelerated material that carry an embedded magnetic field whose strength greatly surpasses that of background solar wind and the interplanetary magnetic field. Coronal ejections begin with the twisting and reconfiguration of the magnetic field in the layer’s lower part; they produce solar flares and can travel (expanding as they advance) at speeds as slow as less than 250 km/s (arriving at the Earth in nearly seven days) and as fast as almost 3,000 km/s (reaching the Earth in as little as 15 hours).

已知最大的日冕物质抛射发生在1859年9月1日清晨，当时英国天文学家理查德·卡林顿正在观测并绘制一个巨大的太阳黑子，该黑子喷射出一道巨大的肾形白色耀斑。[74]这比第一部电话（1877年）的出现早了近二十年，比第一个集中式商业发电（1882年）早了二十多年，因此，当时的显著影响仅限于强烈的极光以及对19世纪40年代开始铺设的新兴电报网络的干扰：电线冒火花，信息传递中断或以奇怪的截断方式继续，操作员触电，一些火灾也意外发生。

The largest known coronal mass ejection began on the morning of September 1, 1859, while Richard Carrington, a British astronomer, was observing and drawing a large solar sunspot that emitted a sizable, kidney-shaped white flare.[74] That was nearly two decades before the first telephones (1877) and more than two decades before the first centralized commercial generation of electricity (1882), and hence the notable effects were only intense auroras and disruptions of the newly expanding telegraph network whose laying began in the 1840s: wires were sparking, messaging was interrupted or continued in bizarrely truncated ways, operators got electric shocks, some fires started accidentally.

随后发生的几起强度较大的日冕物质抛射事件分别发生在1903年10月31日至11月1日和1921年5月13日至15日。当时，即使在欧洲和北美，有线电话线路和电网的覆盖范围也相当有限，其他地区则更为稀少。但1989年3月发生的一次规模小得多的日冕物质抛射（并非卡林顿事件）让我们提前领略了如今大规模日冕物质抛射可能造成的破坏。那次事件导致魁北克省整个电网瘫痪了9个小时，影响了600万人的电力供应。[75]三十多年过去了，我们变得更加脆弱：想想看，从手机、电子邮件到国际银行业务，再到每艘船舶、每架飞机，以及如今数千万辆汽车上都配备了的GPS导航系统，所有电子设备都离不开它们。

Some of the subsequent strongest events took place on October 31–November 1, 1903 and May 13–15, 1921, when the extent of both wired telephone links and electricity grids was still fairly limited even in Europe and North America, and very sparse elsewhere. But we got a preview of what a substantial coronal mass ejection could do today in March 1989 when a much smaller (a non-Carrington) event knocked out Quebec’s entire power grid, serving 6 million people, for nine hours.[75] More than three decades later we have become much more vulnerable: just think of everything electronic, from mobile phones to e-mail to international banking, and about GPS-guided navigation on every vessel and airplane and now also on tens of millions of cars.

我们会在撞击发生前就有所察觉：我们对太阳活动的持续监测能够立即探测到任何物质喷射，并提供至少12-15小时的预警时间。但只有当喷射物到达我们部署的太阳和太阳层探测器（SOHO）所在的位置（距离地球约150万公里）时，我们才能评估其强度；到那时，反应时间将缩短到不到一小时，甚至可能只有15分钟。[76]即使是有限的破坏也意味着通信和电网运行中断数小时或数天，而一场大规模的地磁风暴将切断全球范围内的所有连接，使我们陷入瘫痪。没有电，没有信息，没有交通工具，无法使用信用卡付款或从银行取款。

We would find out before it hits: our constant surveyance of the Sun’s activity would instantly detect any mass ejection and provide at least 12–15 hours of prestrike warning. But only when the ejection reaches the point where we have stationed the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO), about 1.5 million kilometers away from the Earth, could we gauge its intensity; and by then the time to react would be reduced to less than an hour, perhaps even to just 15 minutes.[76] Even limited damage would mean hours or days of disrupted communications and grid operations, and a massive geomagnetic storm would sever all of these links on a global scale, leaving us without electricity, without information, without transportation, without the ability to make credit card payments or to withdraw money from banks.

如果全面恢复所有这些至关重要但严重受损的基础设施需要数年，甚至十年才能完成，我们该怎么办？全球损失的估计值相差一个数量级，从 2 万亿美元到 20 万亿美元不等[77] ——但这仅仅是指支出，而不是在长时间没有通讯、照明、空调、医疗设备、制冷和工业生产（因此也缺乏足够的农作物种植投入）期间失去的生命价值。

What would we do if the complete restoration of all these vital but severely crippled infrastructures took years, perhaps even a decade, to accomplish? Estimates of global damage differ by an order of magnitude, from $2 trillion to $20 trillion[77]—but that refers only to expenditures, not to the value of lives lost during prolonged spells without communication, lights, air conditioning, hospital equipment, refrigeration, and industrial production (and hence also without adequate inputs into crop cultivation).

也有一些好消息。2012年的一项研究估计，未来十年内再次发生卡林顿事件的概率为12%，即八分之一。该研究强调，由于此类极端事件极为罕见，其发生率难以估计，“预测未来特定事件几乎是不可能的”。[78]鉴于这种不确定性，巴塞罗那的一组科学家在2019年计算出2020年代再次发生卡林顿事件的风险不会超过0.46%至1.88%，也就不足为奇了。因此，即使是最高概率，也只有五十三分之一，这是一个令人安心得多的概率。[79] 2020年，卡内基梅隆大学的一个研究小组给出了更低的估计，认为未来十年发生至少与2012年卡林顿事件规模相当的事件的概率在1%至9%之间，而发生与1859年卡林顿事件规模相当的事件的概率则在0.02%至1.6%之间。[80]虽然许多专家都清楚地意识到这些概率以及潜在后果的巨大性，但这显然是那种我们永远无法充分准备的风险之一（就像大流行病一样）：我们只能希望下一次大规模日冕喷射事件不会达到或超过卡林顿事件。

There is some good news. A 2012 study estimated a 12 percent probability of another Carrington Event during the coming ten years—or a one-in-eight chance, and it emphasized that the rarity of these extreme events makes their rate occurrence difficult to estimate “and prediction of a specific future event is virtually impossible.”[78] Given this uncertainty, it is not surprising that in 2019 a group of scientists in Barcelona calculated the risk to be no greater than 0.46–1.88 percent during the 2020s, and hence even the highest rate would mean odds of 1 in 53, a considerably more comforting probability.[79] And in 2020 a Carnegie Mellon group offered an even lower estimate, putting a decadal (10-year) probability of between 1 percent and 9 percent for an event of at least the size of the large 2012 event, and between 0.02 percent and 1.6 percent for the size of the 1859 Carrington Event.[80] While many experts are well aware of these odds and of the enormity of the potential consequences, this is clearly one of those risks (much like a pandemic) for which we cannot ever be adequately prepared: we just have to hope that the next massive coronal ejection event will not equal or surpass the Carrington Event.

虽然这可能不是世界此刻想听到的，但病毒大流行注定会以相对较高的频率再次出现，这是一个令人遗憾的事实。尽管它们不可避免地具有一些共同点，但其影响却具有不可预测的特殊性。2020年初，全球约有10亿62岁以上的人口，他们一生中都经历过三次病毒大流行：1957-1959年（H2N2）、1968-1970年（H3N2）和2009年（H1N1）。[ 81]1957-1959 年大流行期间的总死亡率的最佳重建值为 38/100,000（110 万人死亡；全球人口 28.7 亿），1968-1970 年大流行期间的死亡率为 28/100,000（100 万人死亡；全球人口 35.5 亿），而 2009 年的疫情毒性较低，死亡率不超过 3/100,000（约 20 万人死亡；全球人口 68.7 亿）。[82]
